column2: '28Oct'
column3: 1)	" I don't know what the differences might be
column4: because I don't know what Mr. Carter's policies are. I do know what he has said about mine. And I'm only here to tell you that I believe with all my heart that our first priority must be world peace
column5: and that use of force is always and only a last resort
column6: when everything else has failed
column7: and then only with regard to our national security. Now
column8: I believe
column9: also
column10: that this meeting this mission
column11: this responsibility for preserving the peace
column12: which I believe is a responsibility peculiar to our country
column13: and that we cannot shirk our responsibility as a leader of the free world because we're the only ones that can do it. Therefore
column14: the burden of maintaining the peace falls on us. And to maintain that peace requires strength. America has never gotten in a war because we were too strong. We can get into a war by letting events get out of hand
column15: as they have in the last three and a half years under the foreign policies of this Administration of Mr. Carter's
column16: until we're faced each time with a crisis. And good management in preserving the peace requires that we control the events and try to intercept before they become a crisis. I have seen four wars in my lifetime. I'm a father of sons; I have a grandson. I don't ever want to see another generation of young Americans bleed their lives into sandy beachheads in the Pacific
column17: or rice paddies and jungles in the in Asia or the muddy battlefields of Europe.

column2: I have submitted an economic plan that I have worked out in concert with a number of fine economists in this country
column3: all of whom approve it
column4: and believe that over a five year projection
column5: this plan can permit the extra spending for needed refurbishing of our defensive posture
column6: that it can provide for a balanced budget by 1983 if not earlier
column7: and that we can afford - along with the cuts that I have proposed in Government. spending - we can afford the tax cuts I have proposed and probably mainly because Mr. Carter's economic policy has built into the next five years
column8: and on beyond that
column9: a tax increase that will be taking $86 billion more out of the people's pockets than was taken this year. And my tax cut does not come close to eliminating that $86 billion increase. I'm only reducing the amount of the increase. In other words
column10: what I'm talking about is not putting government back to getting less money than government's been getting
column11: but simply cutting the increase in in spending.

column2: I've had to make thousands of decisions since I've been President
column3: serving in the Oval Office. And with each one of those decisions that affect the future of my country
column4: I have learned in the process. I think I'm a much wiser and more experienced man than I was when I debated four years ago against President Ford. I've also learned that there are no simple answers to complicated questions. H. L. Mencken said that for every problem there's a simple answer. It would be neat and plausible and wrong. The fact is that this nation
column5: in the eight years before I became President
column6: had its own military strength decreased. Seven out of eight years
column7: the budget commitments for defense went down
column8: 37% in all. Since I've been in office
column9: we've had a steady
column10: carefully planned
column11: methodical but
column12: very effective increase in our commitment for defense. But what we've done is use that enormous power and prestige and military strength of the United States to preserve the peace. We've not only kept peace for our own country
column13: but we've been able to extend the benefits of peace to others. In the Middle East
column14: we've worked for a peace treaty between Israel and Egypt
column15: successfully
column16: and have tied ourselves together with Israel and Egypt in a common defense capability. This is a very good step forward for our nation's security
column17: and we'll continue to do as we have done in the past. I might also add that there are decisions that are made in the Oval Office by every President which are profound in nature. There are always trouble spots in the world
column18: and how those troubled areas are addressed by a President alone in that Oval Office affects our nation directly
column19: the involvement of the United States and also our American interests. That is a basic decision that has to be made so frequently
column20: by every President who serves. That is what I have tried to do successfully by keeping our country at peace.

column2: in my State of the Union address earlier this year
column3: I pointed out that any threat to the stability or security of the Persian Gulf would be a threat to the security of our own country. In the past
column4: we have not had an adequate military presence in that region. Now we have two major carrier task forces. We have access to facilities in five different areas of that region. And we've made it clear that working with our allies and others
column5: that we are prepared to address any foreseeable eventuality which might interrupt commerce with that crucial area of the world. But in doing this
column6: we have made sure that we address this question peacefully
column7: not injecting American military forces into combat
column8: but letting the strength of our nation be felt in a beneficial way. This
column9: I believe
column10: has assured that our interests will be protected in the Persian Gulf region
column11: as we have done in the Middle East and throughout the world.

column2: I question the figure about the decline in defense spending under the two previous Administrations in the preceding eight years to this Administration. I would call to your attention that we were in a war that wound down during those eight years
column3: which of course made a change in military spending because of turning from war to peace. I also would like to point out that Republican presidents in those years
column4: faced with a Democratic majority in both houses of the Congress
column5: found that their requests for defense budgets were very often cut. Now
column6: Gerald Ford left a five-year projected plan for a military build-up to restore our defenses
column7: and President Carter's administration reduced that by 38%
column8: cut 60 ships out of the Navy building program that had been proposed
column9: and stopped the the B-l
column10: delayed the cruise missile
column11: stopped the production line for the Minuteman missile
column12: stopped the Trident or delayed the Trident submarine
column13: and now is planning a mobile military force that can be delivered to various spots in the world which does make me question his assaults on whether I am the one who is quick to look for use of force.

column2: there are various elements of defense. One is to control nuclear weapons
column3: which I hope we'll get to later on because that is the most important single issue in this campaign. Another one is how to address troubled areas of the world. I think
column4: habitually
column5: Governor Reagan has advocated the injection of military forces into troubled areas
column6: when I and my predecessors - both Democrats and Republicans - have advocated resolving those troubles in those difficult areas of the world peacefully
column7: diplomatically
column8: and through negotiation. In addition to that
column9: the build-up of military forces is good for our country because we've got to have military strength to preserve the peace. But I'll always remember that the best weapons are the ones that are never fired in combat
column10: and the best soldier is one who never has to lay his life down on the field of battle. Strength is imperative for peace
column11: but the two must go hand in hand.

column10: and the best soldier is one who never has to lay his life down on the field of battle. Strength is imperative for peace
column11: but the two must go hand in hand.

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 1)	" I don't know what the differences might be
column4: because I don't know what Mr. Carter's policies are. I do know what he has said about mine. And I'm only here to tell you that I believe with all my heart that our first priority must be world peace
column5: and that use of force is always and only a last resort
column6: when everything else has failed
column7: and then only with regard to our national security. Now
column8: I believe
column9: also
column10: that this meeting this mission
column11: this responsibility for preserving the peace
column12: which I believe is a responsibility peculiar to our country
column13: and that we cannot shirk our responsibility as a leader of the free world because we're the only ones that can do it. Therefore
column14: the burden of maintaining the peace falls on us. And to maintain that peace requires strength. America has never gotten in a war because we were too strong. We can get into a war by letting events get out of hand
column15: as they have in the last three and a half years under the foreign policies of this Administration of Mr. Carter's
column16: until we're faced each time with a crisis. And good management in preserving the peace requires that we control the events and try to intercept before they become a crisis. I have seen four wars in my lifetime. I'm a father of sons; I have a grandson. I don't ever want to see another generation of young Americans bleed their lives into sandy beachheads in the Pacific
column17: or rice paddies and jungles in the in Asia or the muddy battlefields of Europe.

column2: I have submitted an economic plan that I have worked out in concert with a number of fine economists in this country
column3: all of whom approve it
column4: and believe that over a five year projection
column5: this plan can permit the extra spending for needed refurbishing of our defensive posture
column6: that it can provide for a balanced budget by 1983 if not earlier
column7: and that we can afford - along with the cuts that I have proposed in Government. spending - we can afford the tax cuts I have proposed and probably mainly because Mr. Carter's economic policy has built into the next five years
column8: and on beyond that
column9: a tax increase that will be taking $86 billion more out of the people's pockets than was taken this year. And my tax cut does not come close to eliminating that $86 billion increase. I'm only reducing the amount of the increase. In other words
column10: what I'm talking about is not putting government back to getting less money than government's been getting
column11: but simply cutting the increase in in spending.

column2: I've had to make thousands of decisions since I've been President
column3: serving in the Oval Office. And with each one of those decisions that affect the future of my country
column4: I have learned in the process. I think I'm a much wiser and more experienced man than I was when I debated four years ago against President Ford. I've also learned that there are no simple answers to complicated questions. H. L. Mencken said that for every problem there's a simple answer. It would be neat and plausible and wrong. The fact is that this nation
column5: in the eight years before I became President
column6: had its own military strength decreased. Seven out of eight years
column7: the budget commitments for defense went down
column8: 37% in all. Since I've been in office
column9: we've had a steady
column10: carefully planned
column11: methodical but
column12: very effective increase in our commitment for defense. But what we've done is use that enormous power and prestige and military strength of the United States to preserve the peace. We've not only kept peace for our own country
column13: but we've been able to extend the benefits of peace to others. In the Middle East
column14: we've worked for a peace treaty between Israel and Egypt
column15: successfully
column16: and have tied ourselves together with Israel and Egypt in a common defense capability. This is a very good step forward for our nation's security
column17: and we'll continue to do as we have done in the past. I might also add that there are decisions that are made in the Oval Office by every President which are profound in nature. There are always trouble spots in the world
column18: and how those troubled areas are addressed by a President alone in that Oval Office affects our nation directly
column19: the involvement of the United States and also our American interests. That is a basic decision that has to be made so frequently
column20: by every President who serves. That is what I have tried to do successfully by keeping our country at peace.

column2: in my State of the Union address earlier this year
column3: I pointed out that any threat to the stability or security of the Persian Gulf would be a threat to the security of our own country. In the past
column4: we have not had an adequate military presence in that region. Now we have two major carrier task forces. We have access to facilities in five different areas of that region. And we've made it clear that working with our allies and others
column5: that we are prepared to address any foreseeable eventuality which might interrupt commerce with that crucial area of the world. But in doing this
column6: we have made sure that we address this question peacefully
column7: not injecting American military forces into combat
column8: but letting the strength of our nation be felt in a beneficial way. This
column9: I believe
column10: has assured that our interests will be protected in the Persian Gulf region
column11: as we have done in the Middle East and throughout the world.

column2: I question the figure about the decline in defense spending under the two previous Administrations in the preceding eight years to this Administration. I would call to your attention that we were in a war that wound down during those eight years
column3: which of course made a change in military spending because of turning from war to peace. I also would like to point out that Republican presidents in those years
column4: faced with a Democratic majority in both houses of the Congress
column5: found that their requests for defense budgets were very often cut. Now
column6: Gerald Ford left a five-year projected plan for a military build-up to restore our defenses
column7: and President Carter's administration reduced that by 38%
column8: cut 60 ships out of the Navy building program that had been proposed
column9: and stopped the the B-l
column10: delayed the cruise missile
column11: stopped the production line for the Minuteman missile
column12: stopped the Trident or delayed the Trident submarine
column13: and now is planning a mobile military force that can be delivered to various spots in the world which does make me question his assaults on whether I am the one who is quick to look for use of force.

column2: there are various elements of defense. One is to control nuclear weapons
column3: which I hope we'll get to later on because that is the most important single issue in this campaign. Another one is how to address troubled areas of the world. I think
column4: habitually
column5: Governor Reagan has advocated the injection of military forces into troubled areas
column6: when I and my predecessors - both Democrats and Republicans - have advocated resolving those troubles in those difficult areas of the world peacefully
column7: diplomatically
column8: and through negotiation. In addition to that
column9: the build-up of military forces is good for our country because we've got to have military strength to preserve the peace. But I'll always remember that the best weapons are the ones that are never fired in combat
column10: and the best soldier is one who never has to lay his life down on the field of battle. Strength is imperative for peace
column11: but the two must go hand in hand.

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 1)	" I don't know what the differences might be
column4: because I don't know what Mr. Carter's policies are. I do know what he has said about mine. And I'm only here to tell you that I believe with all my heart that our first priority must be world peace
column5: and that use of force is always and only a last resort
column6: when everything else has failed
column7: and then only with regard to our national security. Now
column8: I believe
column9: also
column10: that this meeting this mission
column11: this responsibility for preserving the peace
column12: which I believe is a responsibility peculiar to our country
column13: and that we cannot shirk our responsibility as a leader of the free world because we're the only ones that can do it. Therefore
column14: the burden of maintaining the peace falls on us. And to maintain that peace requires strength. America has never gotten in a war because we were too strong. We can get into a war by letting events get out of hand
column15: as they have in the last three and a half years under the foreign policies of this Administration of Mr. Carter's
column16: until we're faced each time with a crisis. And good management in preserving the peace requires that we control the events and try to intercept before they become a crisis. I have seen four wars in my lifetime. I'm a father of sons; I have a grandson. I don't ever want to see another generation of young Americans bleed their lives into sandy beachheads in the Pacific
column17: or rice paddies and jungles in the in Asia or the muddy battlefields of Europe.

column2: I have submitted an economic plan that I have worked out in concert with a number of fine economists in this country
column3: all of whom approve it
column4: and believe that over a five year projection
column5: this plan can permit the extra spending for needed refurbishing of our defensive posture
column6: that it can provide for a balanced budget by 1983 if not earlier
column7: and that we can afford - along with the cuts that I have proposed in Government. spending - we can afford the tax cuts I have proposed and probably mainly because Mr. Carter's economic policy has built into the next five years
column8: and on beyond that
column9: a tax increase that will be taking $86 billion more out of the people's pockets than was taken this year. And my tax cut does not come close to eliminating that $86 billion increase. I'm only reducing the amount of the increase. In other words
column10: what I'm talking about is not putting government back to getting less money than government's been getting
column11: but simply cutting the increase in in spending.

column2: I've had to make thousands of decisions since I've been President
column3: serving in the Oval Office. And with each one of those decisions that affect the future of my country
column4: I have learned in the process. I think I'm a much wiser and more experienced man than I was when I debated four years ago against President Ford. I've also learned that there are no simple answers to complicated questions. H. L. Mencken said that for every problem there's a simple answer. It would be neat and plausible and wrong. The fact is that this nation
column5: in the eight years before I became President
column6: had its own military strength decreased. Seven out of eight years
column7: the budget commitments for defense went down
column8: 37% in all. Since I've been in office
column9: we've had a steady
column10: carefully planned
column11: methodical but
column12: very effective increase in our commitment for defense. But what we've done is use that enormous power and prestige and military strength of the United States to preserve the peace. We've not only kept peace for our own country
column13: but we've been able to extend the benefits of peace to others. In the Middle East
column14: we've worked for a peace treaty between Israel and Egypt
column15: successfully
column16: and have tied ourselves together with Israel and Egypt in a common defense capability. This is a very good step forward for our nation's security
column17: and we'll continue to do as we have done in the past. I might also add that there are decisions that are made in the Oval Office by every President which are profound in nature. There are always trouble spots in the world
column18: and how those troubled areas are addressed by a President alone in that Oval Office affects our nation directly
column19: the involvement of the United States and also our American interests. That is a basic decision that has to be made so frequently
column20: by every President who serves. That is what I have tried to do successfully by keeping our country at peace.

column2: in my State of the Union address earlier this year
column3: I pointed out that any threat to the stability or security of the Persian Gulf would be a threat to the security of our own country. In the past
column4: we have not had an adequate military presence in that region. Now we have two major carrier task forces. We have access to facilities in five different areas of that region. And we've made it clear that working with our allies and others
column5: that we are prepared to address any foreseeable eventuality which might interrupt commerce with that crucial area of the world. But in doing this
column6: we have made sure that we address this question peacefully
column7: not injecting American military forces into combat
column8: but letting the strength of our nation be felt in a beneficial way. This
column9: I believe
column10: has assured that our interests will be protected in the Persian Gulf region
column11: as we have done in the Middle East and throughout the world.

column2: I question the figure about the decline in defense spending under the two previous Administrations in the preceding eight years to this Administration. I would call to your attention that we were in a war that wound down during those eight years
column3: which of course made a change in military spending because of turning from war to peace. I also would like to point out that Republican presidents in those years
column4: faced with a Democratic majority in both houses of the Congress
column5: found that their requests for defense budgets were very often cut. Now
column6: Gerald Ford left a five-year projected plan for a military build-up to restore our defenses
column7: and President Carter's administration reduced that by 38%
column8: cut 60 ships out of the Navy building program that had been proposed
column9: and stopped the the B-l
column10: delayed the cruise missile
column11: stopped the production line for the Minuteman missile
column12: stopped the Trident or delayed the Trident submarine
column13: and now is planning a mobile military force that can be delivered to various spots in the world which does make me question his assaults on whether I am the one who is quick to look for use of force.

column2: there are various elements of defense. One is to control nuclear weapons
column3: which I hope we'll get to later on because that is the most important single issue in this campaign. Another one is how to address troubled areas of the world. I think
column4: habitually
column5: Governor Reagan has advocated the injection of military forces into troubled areas
column6: when I and my predecessors - both Democrats and Republicans - have advocated resolving those troubles in those difficult areas of the world peacefully
column7: diplomatically
column8: and through negotiation. In addition to that
column9: the build-up of military forces is good for our country because we've got to have military strength to preserve the peace. But I'll always remember that the best weapons are the ones that are never fired in combat
column10: and the best soldier is one who never has to lay his life down on the field of battle. Strength is imperative for peace
column11: but the two must go hand in hand.

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 1)	" I don't know what the differences might be
column4: because I don't know what Mr. Carter's policies are. I do know what he has said about mine. And I'm only here to tell you that I believe with all my heart that our first priority must be world peace
column5: and that use of force is always and only a last resort
column6: when everything else has failed
column7: and then only with regard to our national security. Now
column8: I believe
column9: also
column10: that this meeting this mission
column11: this responsibility for preserving the peace
column12: which I believe is a responsibility peculiar to our country
column13: and that we cannot shirk our responsibility as a leader of the free world because we're the only ones that can do it. Therefore
column14: the burden of maintaining the peace falls on us. And to maintain that peace requires strength. America has never gotten in a war because we were too strong. We can get into a war by letting events get out of hand
column15: as they have in the last three and a half years under the foreign policies of this Administration of Mr. Carter's
column16: until we're faced each time with a crisis. And good management in preserving the peace requires that we control the events and try to intercept before they become a crisis. I have seen four wars in my lifetime. I'm a father of sons; I have a grandson. I don't ever want to see another generation of young Americans bleed their lives into sandy beachheads in the Pacific
column17: or rice paddies and jungles in the in Asia or the muddy battlefields of Europe.

column2: I have submitted an economic plan that I have worked out in concert with a number of fine economists in this country
column3: all of whom approve it
column4: and believe that over a five year projection
column5: this plan can permit the extra spending for needed refurbishing of our defensive posture
column6: that it can provide for a balanced budget by 1983 if not earlier
column7: and that we can afford - along with the cuts that I have proposed in Government. spending - we can afford the tax cuts I have proposed and probably mainly because Mr. Carter's economic policy has built into the next five years
column8: and on beyond that
column9: a tax increase that will be taking $86 billion more out of the people's pockets than was taken this year. And my tax cut does not come close to eliminating that $86 billion increase. I'm only reducing the amount of the increase. In other words
column10: what I'm talking about is not putting government back to getting less money than government's been getting
column11: but simply cutting the increase in in spending.

column2: I've had to make thousands of decisions since I've been President
column3: serving in the Oval Office. And with each one of those decisions that affect the future of my country
column4: I have learned in the process. I think I'm a much wiser and more experienced man than I was when I debated four years ago against President Ford. I've also learned that there are no simple answers to complicated questions. H. L. Mencken said that for every problem there's a simple answer. It would be neat and plausible and wrong. The fact is that this nation
column5: in the eight years before I became President
column6: had its own military strength decreased. Seven out of eight years
column7: the budget commitments for defense went down
column8: 37% in all. Since I've been in office
column9: we've had a steady
column10: carefully planned
column11: methodical but
column12: very effective increase in our commitment for defense. But what we've done is use that enormous power and prestige and military strength of the United States to preserve the peace. We've not only kept peace for our own country
column13: but we've been able to extend the benefits of peace to others. In the Middle East
column14: we've worked for a peace treaty between Israel and Egypt
column15: successfully
column16: and have tied ourselves together with Israel and Egypt in a common defense capability. This is a very good step forward for our nation's security
column17: and we'll continue to do as we have done in the past. I might also add that there are decisions that are made in the Oval Office by every President which are profound in nature. There are always trouble spots in the world
column18: and how those troubled areas are addressed by a President alone in that Oval Office affects our nation directly
column19: the involvement of the United States and also our American interests. That is a basic decision that has to be made so frequently
column20: by every President who serves. That is what I have tried to do successfully by keeping our country at peace.

column2: in my State of the Union address earlier this year
column3: I pointed out that any threat to the stability or security of the Persian Gulf would be a threat to the security of our own country. In the past
column4: we have not had an adequate military presence in that region. Now we have two major carrier task forces. We have access to facilities in five different areas of that region. And we've made it clear that working with our allies and others
column5: that we are prepared to address any foreseeable eventuality which might interrupt commerce with that crucial area of the world. But in doing this
column6: we have made sure that we address this question peacefully
column7: not injecting American military forces into combat
column8: but letting the strength of our nation be felt in a beneficial way. This
column9: I believe
column10: has assured that our interests will be protected in the Persian Gulf region
column11: as we have done in the Middle East and throughout the world.

column2: I question the figure about the decline in defense spending under the two previous Administrations in the preceding eight years to this Administration. I would call to your attention that we were in a war that wound down during those eight years
column3: which of course made a change in military spending because of turning from war to peace. I also would like to point out that Republican presidents in those years
column4: faced with a Democratic majority in both houses of the Congress
column5: found that their requests for defense budgets were very often cut. Now
column6: Gerald Ford left a five-year projected plan for a military build-up to restore our defenses
column7: and President Carter's administration reduced that by 38%
column8: cut 60 ships out of the Navy building program that had been proposed
column9: and stopped the the B-l
column10: delayed the cruise missile
column11: stopped the production line for the Minuteman missile
column12: stopped the Trident or delayed the Trident submarine
column13: and now is planning a mobile military force that can be delivered to various spots in the world which does make me question his assaults on whether I am the one who is quick to look for use of force.

column2: there are various elements of defense. One is to control nuclear weapons
column3: which I hope we'll get to later on because that is the most important single issue in this campaign. Another one is how to address troubled areas of the world. I think
column4: habitually
column5: Governor Reagan has advocated the injection of military forces into troubled areas
column6: when I and my predecessors - both Democrats and Republicans - have advocated resolving those troubles in those difficult areas of the world peacefully
column7: diplomatically
column8: and through negotiation. In addition to that
column9: the build-up of military forces is good for our country because we've got to have military strength to preserve the peace. But I'll always remember that the best weapons are the ones that are never fired in combat
column10: and the best soldier is one who never has to lay his life down on the field of battle. Strength is imperative for peace
column11: but the two must go hand in hand.

column14: we've worked for a peace treaty between Israel and Egypt
column15: successfully
column16: and have tied ourselves together with Israel and Egypt in a common defense capability. This is a very good step forward for our nation's security
column17: and we'll continue to do as we have done in the past. I might also add that there are decisions that are made in the Oval Office by every President which are profound in nature. There are always trouble spots in the world
column18: and how those troubled areas are addressed by a President alone in that Oval Office affects our nation directly
column19: the involvement of the United States and also our American interests. That is a basic decision that has to be made so frequently
column20: by every President who serves. That is what I have tried to do successfully by keeping our country at peace.

column2: in my State of the Union address earlier this year
column3: I pointed out that any threat to the stability or security of the Persian Gulf would be a threat to the security of our own country. In the past
column4: we have not had an adequate military presence in that region. Now we have two major carrier task forces. We have access to facilities in five different areas of that region. And we've made it clear that working with our allies and others
column5: that we are prepared to address any foreseeable eventuality which might interrupt commerce with that crucial area of the world. But in doing this
column6: we have made sure that we address this question peacefully
column7: not injecting American military forces into combat
column8: but letting the strength of our nation be felt in a beneficial way. This
column9: I believe
column10: has assured that our interests will be protected in the Persian Gulf region
column11: as we have done in the Middle East and throughout the world.

column2: I question the figure about the decline in defense spending under the two previous Administrations in the preceding eight years to this Administration. I would call to your attention that we were in a war that wound down during those eight years
column3: which of course made a change in military spending because of turning from war to peace. I also would like to point out that Republican presidents in those years
column4: faced with a Democratic majority in both houses of the Congress
column5: found that their requests for defense budgets were very often cut. Now
column6: Gerald Ford left a five-year projected plan for a military build-up to restore our defenses
column7: and President Carter's administration reduced that by 38%
column8: cut 60 ships out of the Navy building program that had been proposed
column9: and stopped the the B-l
column10: delayed the cruise missile
column11: stopped the production line for the Minuteman missile
column12: stopped the Trident or delayed the Trident submarine
column13: and now is planning a mobile military force that can be delivered to various spots in the world which does make me question his assaults on whether I am the one who is quick to look for use of force.

column2: there are various elements of defense. One is to control nuclear weapons
column3: which I hope we'll get to later on because that is the most important single issue in this campaign. Another one is how to address troubled areas of the world. I think
column4: habitually
column5: Governor Reagan has advocated the injection of military forces into troubled areas
column6: when I and my predecessors - both Democrats and Republicans - have advocated resolving those troubles in those difficult areas of the world peacefully
column7: diplomatically
column8: and through negotiation. In addition to that
column9: the build-up of military forces is good for our country because we've got to have military strength to preserve the peace. But I'll always remember that the best weapons are the ones that are never fired in combat
column10: and the best soldier is one who never has to lay his life down on the field of battle. Strength is imperative for peace
column11: but the two must go hand in hand.

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 1)	" I don't know what the differences might be
column4: because I don't know what Mr. Carter's policies are. I do know what he has said about mine. And I'm only here to tell you that I believe with all my heart that our first priority must be world peace
column5: and that use of force is always and only a last resort
column6: when everything else has failed
column7: and then only with regard to our national security. Now
column8: I believe
column9: also
column10: that this meeting this mission
column11: this responsibility for preserving the peace
column12: which I believe is a responsibility peculiar to our country
column13: and that we cannot shirk our responsibility as a leader of the free world because we're the only ones that can do it. Therefore
column14: the burden of maintaining the peace falls on us. And to maintain that peace requires strength. America has never gotten in a war because we were too strong. We can get into a war by letting events get out of hand
column15: as they have in the last three and a half years under the foreign policies of this Administration of Mr. Carter's
column16: until we're faced each time with a crisis. And good management in preserving the peace requires that we control the events and try to intercept before they become a crisis. I have seen four wars in my lifetime. I'm a father of sons; I have a grandson. I don't ever want to see another generation of young Americans bleed their lives into sandy beachheads in the Pacific
column17: or rice paddies and jungles in the in Asia or the muddy battlefields of Europe.

column2: I have submitted an economic plan that I have worked out in concert with a number of fine economists in this country
column3: all of whom approve it
column4: and believe that over a five year projection
column5: this plan can permit the extra spending for needed refurbishing of our defensive posture
column6: that it can provide for a balanced budget by 1983 if not earlier
column7: and that we can afford - along with the cuts that I have proposed in Government. spending - we can afford the tax cuts I have proposed and probably mainly because Mr. Carter's economic policy has built into the next five years
column8: and on beyond that
column9: a tax increase that will be taking $86 billion more out of the people's pockets than was taken this year. And my tax cut does not come close to eliminating that $86 billion increase. I'm only reducing the amount of the increase. In other words
column10: what I'm talking about is not putting government back to getting less money than government's been getting
column11: but simply cutting the increase in in spending.

column2: I've had to make thousands of decisions since I've been President
column3: serving in the Oval Office. And with each one of those decisions that affect the future of my country
column4: I have learned in the process. I think I'm a much wiser and more experienced man than I was when I debated four years ago against President Ford. I've also learned that there are no simple answers to complicated questions. H. L. Mencken said that for every problem there's a simple answer. It would be neat and plausible and wrong. The fact is that this nation
column5: in the eight years before I became President
column6: had its own military strength decreased. Seven out of eight years
column7: the budget commitments for defense went down
column8: 37% in all. Since I've been in office
column9: we've had a steady
column10: carefully planned
column11: methodical but
column12: very effective increase in our commitment for defense. But what we've done is use that enormous power and prestige and military strength of the United States to preserve the peace. We've not only kept peace for our own country
column13: but we've been able to extend the benefits of peace to others. In the Middle East
column14: we've worked for a peace treaty between Israel and Egypt
column15: successfully
column16: and have tied ourselves together with Israel and Egypt in a common defense capability. This is a very good step forward for our nation's security
column17: and we'll continue to do as we have done in the past. I might also add that there are decisions that are made in the Oval Office by every President which are profound in nature. There are always trouble spots in the world
column18: and how those troubled areas are addressed by a President alone in that Oval Office affects our nation directly
column19: the involvement of the United States and also our American interests. That is a basic decision that has to be made so frequently
column20: by every President who serves. That is what I have tried to do successfully by keeping our country at peace.

column2: in my State of the Union address earlier this year
column3: I pointed out that any threat to the stability or security of the Persian Gulf would be a threat to the security of our own country. In the past
column4: we have not had an adequate military presence in that region. Now we have two major carrier task forces. We have access to facilities in five different areas of that region. And we've made it clear that working with our allies and others
column5: that we are prepared to address any foreseeable eventuality which might interrupt commerce with that crucial area of the world. But in doing this
column6: we have made sure that we address this question peacefully
column7: not injecting American military forces into combat
column8: but letting the strength of our nation be felt in a beneficial way. This
column9: I believe
column10: has assured that our interests will be protected in the Persian Gulf region
column11: as we have done in the Middle East and throughout the world.

column2: I question the figure about the decline in defense spending under the two previous Administrations in the preceding eight years to this Administration. I would call to your attention that we were in a war that wound down during those eight years
column3: which of course made a change in military spending because of turning from war to peace. I also would like to point out that Republican presidents in those years
column4: faced with a Democratic majority in both houses of the Congress
column5: found that their requests for defense budgets were very often cut. Now
column6: Gerald Ford left a five-year projected plan for a military build-up to restore our defenses
column7: and President Carter's administration reduced that by 38%
column8: cut 60 ships out of the Navy building program that had been proposed
column9: and stopped the the B-l
column10: delayed the cruise missile
column11: stopped the production line for the Minuteman missile
column12: stopped the Trident or delayed the Trident submarine
column13: and now is planning a mobile military force that can be delivered to various spots in the world which does make me question his assaults on whether I am the one who is quick to look for use of force.

column2: there are various elements of defense. One is to control nuclear weapons
column3: which I hope we'll get to later on because that is the most important single issue in this campaign. Another one is how to address troubled areas of the world. I think
column4: habitually
column5: Governor Reagan has advocated the injection of military forces into troubled areas
column6: when I and my predecessors - both Democrats and Republicans - have advocated resolving those troubles in those difficult areas of the world peacefully
column7: diplomatically
column8: and through negotiation. In addition to that
column9: the build-up of military forces is good for our country because we've got to have military strength to preserve the peace. But I'll always remember that the best weapons are the ones that are never fired in combat
column10: and the best soldier is one who never has to lay his life down on the field of battle. Strength is imperative for peace
column11: but the two must go hand in hand.

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 1)	" I don't know what the differences might be
column4: because I don't know what Mr. Carter's policies are. I do know what he has said about mine. And I'm only here to tell you that I believe with all my heart that our first priority must be world peace
column5: and that use of force is always and only a last resort
column6: when everything else has failed
column7: and then only with regard to our national security. Now
column8: I believe
column9: also
column10: that this meeting this mission
column11: this responsibility for preserving the peace
column12: which I believe is a responsibility peculiar to our country
column13: and that we cannot shirk our responsibility as a leader of the free world because we're the only ones that can do it. Therefore
column14: the burden of maintaining the peace falls on us. And to maintain that peace requires strength. America has never gotten in a war because we were too strong. We can get into a war by letting events get out of hand
column15: as they have in the last three and a half years under the foreign policies of this Administration of Mr. Carter's
column16: until we're faced each time with a crisis. And good management in preserving the peace requires that we control the events and try to intercept before they become a crisis. I have seen four wars in my lifetime. I'm a father of sons; I have a grandson. I don't ever want to see another generation of young Americans bleed their lives into sandy beachheads in the Pacific
column17: or rice paddies and jungles in the in Asia or the muddy battlefields of Europe.

column2: I have submitted an economic plan that I have worked out in concert with a number of fine economists in this country
column3: all of whom approve it
column4: and believe that over a five year projection
column5: this plan can permit the extra spending for needed refurbishing of our defensive posture
column6: that it can provide for a balanced budget by 1983 if not earlier
column7: and that we can afford - along with the cuts that I have proposed in Government. spending - we can afford the tax cuts I have proposed and probably mainly because Mr. Carter's economic policy has built into the next five years
column8: and on beyond that
column9: a tax increase that will be taking $86 billion more out of the people's pockets than was taken this year. And my tax cut does not come close to eliminating that $86 billion increase. I'm only reducing the amount of the increase. In other words
column10: what I'm talking about is not putting government back to getting less money than government's been getting
column11: but simply cutting the increase in in spending.

column2: I've had to make thousands of decisions since I've been President
column3: serving in the Oval Office. And with each one of those decisions that affect the future of my country
column4: I have learned in the process. I think I'm a much wiser and more experienced man than I was when I debated four years ago against President Ford. I've also learned that there are no simple answers to complicated questions. H. L. Mencken said that for every problem there's a simple answer. It would be neat and plausible and wrong. The fact is that this nation
column5: in the eight years before I became President
column6: had its own military strength decreased. Seven out of eight years
column7: the budget commitments for defense went down
column8: 37% in all. Since I've been in office
column9: we've had a steady
column10: carefully planned
column11: methodical but
column12: very effective increase in our commitment for defense. But what we've done is use that enormous power and prestige and military strength of the United States to preserve the peace. We've not only kept peace for our own country
column13: but we've been able to extend the benefits of peace to others. In the Middle East
column14: we've worked for a peace treaty between Israel and Egypt
column15: successfully
column16: and have tied ourselves together with Israel and Egypt in a common defense capability. This is a very good step forward for our nation's security
column17: and we'll continue to do as we have done in the past. I might also add that there are decisions that are made in the Oval Office by every President which are profound in nature. There are always trouble spots in the world
column18: and how those troubled areas are addressed by a President alone in that Oval Office affects our nation directly
column19: the involvement of the United States and also our American interests. That is a basic decision that has to be made so frequently
column20: by every President who serves. That is what I have tried to do successfully by keeping our country at peace.

column2: in my State of the Union address earlier this year
column3: I pointed out that any threat to the stability or security of the Persian Gulf would be a threat to the security of our own country. In the past
column4: we have not had an adequate military presence in that region. Now we have two major carrier task forces. We have access to facilities in five different areas of that region. And we've made it clear that working with our allies and others
column5: that we are prepared to address any foreseeable eventuality which might interrupt commerce with that crucial area of the world. But in doing this
column6: we have made sure that we address this question peacefully
column7: not injecting American military forces into combat
column8: but letting the strength of our nation be felt in a beneficial way. This
column9: I believe
column10: has assured that our interests will be protected in the Persian Gulf region
column11: as we have done in the Middle East and throughout the world.

column2: I question the figure about the decline in defense spending under the two previous Administrations in the preceding eight years to this Administration. I would call to your attention that we were in a war that wound down during those eight years
column3: which of course made a change in military spending because of turning from war to peace. I also would like to point out that Republican presidents in those years
column4: faced with a Democratic majority in both houses of the Congress
column5: found that their requests for defense budgets were very often cut. Now
column6: Gerald Ford left a five-year projected plan for a military build-up to restore our defenses
column7: and President Carter's administration reduced that by 38%
column8: cut 60 ships out of the Navy building program that had been proposed
column9: and stopped the the B-l
column10: delayed the cruise missile
column11: stopped the production line for the Minuteman missile
column12: stopped the Trident or delayed the Trident submarine
column13: and now is planning a mobile military force that can be delivered to various spots in the world which does make me question his assaults on whether I am the one who is quick to look for use of force.

column2: there are various elements of defense. One is to control nuclear weapons
column3: which I hope we'll get to later on because that is the most important single issue in this campaign. Another one is how to address troubled areas of the world. I think
column4: habitually
column5: Governor Reagan has advocated the injection of military forces into troubled areas
column6: when I and my predecessors - both Democrats and Republicans - have advocated resolving those troubles in those difficult areas of the world peacefully
column7: diplomatically
column8: and through negotiation. In addition to that
column9: the build-up of military forces is good for our country because we've got to have military strength to preserve the peace. But I'll always remember that the best weapons are the ones that are never fired in combat
column10: and the best soldier is one who never has to lay his life down on the field of battle. Strength is imperative for peace
column11: but the two must go hand in hand.

column1: Mr. Stone, I have submitted an economic plan that I have worked out in concert with a number of fine economists in this country, all of whom approve it, and believe that over a five year projection, this plan can permit the extra spending for needed refurbishing of our defensive posture, that it can provide for a balanced budget by 1983 if not earlier, and that we can afford - along with the cuts that I have proposed in Government. column2: '28Oct'
column3: 1)	" I don't know what the differences might be
column4: because I don't know what Mr. Carter's policies are. I do know what he has said about mine. And I'm only here to tell you that I believe with all my heart that our first priority must be world peace
column5: and that use of force is always and only a last resort
column6: when everything else has failed
column7: and then only with regard to our national security. Now
column8: I believe
column9: also
column10: that this meeting this mission
column11: this responsibility for preserving the peace
column12: which I believe is a responsibility peculiar to our country
column13: and that we cannot shirk our responsibility as a leader of the free world because we're the only ones that can do it. Therefore
column14: the burden of maintaining the peace falls on us. And to maintain that peace requires strength. America has never gotten in a war because we were too strong. We can get into a war by letting events get out of hand
column15: as they have in the last three and a half years under the foreign policies of this Administration of Mr. Carter's
column16: until we're faced each time with a crisis. And good management in preserving the peace requires that we control the events and try to intercept before they become a crisis. I have seen four wars in my lifetime. I'm a father of sons; I have a grandson. I don't ever want to see another generation of young Americans bleed their lives into sandy beachheads in the Pacific
column17: or rice paddies and jungles in the in Asia or the muddy battlefields of Europe.

column2: I have submitted an economic plan that I have worked out in concert with a number of fine economists in this country
column3: all of whom approve it
column4: and believe that over a five year projection
column5: this plan can permit the extra spending for needed refurbishing of our defensive posture
column6: that it can provide for a balanced budget by 1983 if not earlier
column7: and that we can afford - along with the cuts that I have proposed in Government. spending - we can afford the tax cuts I have proposed and probably mainly because Mr. Carter's economic policy has built into the next five years
column8: and on beyond that
column9: a tax increase that will be taking $86 billion more out of the people's pockets than was taken this year. And my tax cut does not come close to eliminating that $86 billion increase. I'm only reducing the amount of the increase. In other words
column10: what I'm talking about is not putting government back to getting less money than government's been getting
column11: but simply cutting the increase in in spending.

column2: I've had to make thousands of decisions since I've been President
column3: serving in the Oval Office. And with each one of those decisions that affect the future of my country
column4: I have learned in the process. I think I'm a much wiser and more experienced man than I was when I debated four years ago against President Ford. I've also learned that there are no simple answers to complicated questions. H. L. Mencken said that for every problem there's a simple answer. It would be neat and plausible and wrong. The fact is that this nation
column5: in the eight years before I became President
column6: had its own military strength decreased. Seven out of eight years
column7: the budget commitments for defense went down
column8: 37% in all. Since I've been in office
column9: we've had a steady
column10: carefully planned
column11: methodical but
column12: very effective increase in our commitment for defense. But what we've done is use that enormous power and prestige and military strength of the United States to preserve the peace. We've not only kept peace for our own country
column13: but we've been able to extend the benefits of peace to others. In the Middle East
column14: we've worked for a peace treaty between Israel and Egypt
column15: successfully
column16: and have tied ourselves together with Israel and Egypt in a common defense capability. This is a very good step forward for our nation's security
column17: and we'll continue to do as we have done in the past. I might also add that there are decisions that are made in the Oval Office by every President which are profound in nature. There are always trouble spots in the world
column18: and how those troubled areas are addressed by a President alone in that Oval Office affects our nation directly
column19: the involvement of the United States and also our American interests. That is a basic decision that has to be made so frequently
column20: by every President who serves. That is what I have tried to do successfully by keeping our country at peace.

column2: in my State of the Union address earlier this year
column3: I pointed out that any threat to the stability or security of the Persian Gulf would be a threat to the security of our own country. In the past
column4: we have not had an adequate military presence in that region. Now we have two major carrier task forces. We have access to facilities in five different areas of that region. And we've made it clear that working with our allies and others
column5: that we are prepared to address any foreseeable eventuality which might interrupt commerce with that crucial area of the world. But in doing this
column6: we have made sure that we address this question peacefully
column7: not injecting American military forces into combat
column8: but letting the strength of our nation be felt in a beneficial way. This
column9: I believe
column10: has assured that our interests will be protected in the Persian Gulf region
column11: as we have done in the Middle East and throughout the world.

column2: I question the figure about the decline in defense spending under the two previous Administrations in the preceding eight years to this Administration. I would call to your attention that we were in a war that wound down during those eight years
column3: which of course made a change in military spending because of turning from war to peace. I also would like to point out that Republican presidents in those years
column4: faced with a Democratic majority in both houses of the Congress
column5: found that their requests for defense budgets were very often cut. Now
column6: Gerald Ford left a five-year projected plan for a military build-up to restore our defenses
column7: and President Carter's administration reduced that by 38%
column8: cut 60 ships out of the Navy building program that had been proposed
column9: and stopped the the B-l
column10: delayed the cruise missile
column11: stopped the production line for the Minuteman missile
column12: stopped the Trident or delayed the Trident submarine
column13: and now is planning a mobile military force that can be delivered to various spots in the world which does make me question his assaults on whether I am the one who is quick to look for use of force.

column2: there are various elements of defense. One is to control nuclear weapons
column3: which I hope we'll get to later on because that is the most important single issue in this campaign. Another one is how to address troubled areas of the world. I think
column4: habitually
column5: Governor Reagan has advocated the injection of military forces into troubled areas
column6: when I and my predecessors - both Democrats and Republicans - have advocated resolving those troubles in those difficult areas of the world peacefully
column7: diplomatically
column8: and through negotiation. In addition to that
column9: the build-up of military forces is good for our country because we've got to have military strength to preserve the peace. But I'll always remember that the best weapons are the ones that are never fired in combat
column10: and the best soldier is one who never has to lay his life down on the field of battle. Strength is imperative for peace
column11: but the two must go hand in hand.

column1: Mr. Stone, I have submitted an economic plan that I have worked out in concert with a number of fine economists in this country, all of whom approve it, and believe that over a five year projection, this plan can permit the extra spending for needed refurbishing of our defensive posture, that it can provide for a balanced budget by 1983 if not earlier, and that we can afford - along with the cuts that I have proposed in Government. column2: there are various elements of defense. One is to control nuclear weapons
column3: which I hope we'll get to later on because that is the most important single issue in this campaign. Another one is how to address troubled areas of the world. I think
column4: habitually
column5: Governor Reagan has advocated the injection of military forces into troubled areas
column6: when I and my predecessors - both Democrats and Republicans - have advocated resolving those troubles in those difficult areas of the world peacefully
column7: diplomatically
column8: and through negotiation. In addition to that
column9: the build-up of military forces is good for our country because we've got to have military strength to preserve the peace. But I'll always remember that the best weapons are the ones that are never fired in combat
column10: and the best soldier is one who never has to lay his life down on the field of battle. Strength is imperative for peace
column11: but the two must go hand in hand.

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 1)	" I don't know what the differences might be
column4: because I don't know what Mr. Carter's policies are. I do know what he has said about mine. And I'm only here to tell you that I believe with all my heart that our first priority must be world peace
column5: and that use of force is always and only a last resort
column6: when everything else has failed
column7: and then only with regard to our national security. Now
column8: I believe
column9: also
column10: that this meeting this mission
column11: this responsibility for preserving the peace
column12: which I believe is a responsibility peculiar to our country
column13: and that we cannot shirk our responsibility as a leader of the free world because we're the only ones that can do it. Therefore
column14: the burden of maintaining the peace falls on us. And to maintain that peace requires strength. America has never gotten in a war because we were too strong. We can get into a war by letting events get out of hand
column15: as they have in the last three and a half years under the foreign policies of this Administration of Mr. Carter's
column16: until we're faced each time with a crisis. And good management in preserving the peace requires that we control the events and try to intercept before they become a crisis. I have seen four wars in my lifetime. I'm a father of sons; I have a grandson. I don't ever want to see another generation of young Americans bleed their lives into sandy beachheads in the Pacific
column17: or rice paddies and jungles in the in Asia or the muddy battlefields of Europe.

column2: I have submitted an economic plan that I have worked out in concert with a number of fine economists in this country
column3: all of whom approve it
column4: and believe that over a five year projection
column5: this plan can permit the extra spending for needed refurbishing of our defensive posture
column6: that it can provide for a balanced budget by 1983 if not earlier
column7: and that we can afford - along with the cuts that I have proposed in Government. spending - we can afford the tax cuts I have proposed and probably mainly because Mr. Carter's economic policy has built into the next five years
column8: and on beyond that
column9: a tax increase that will be taking $86 billion more out of the people's pockets than was taken this year. And my tax cut does not come close to eliminating that $86 billion increase. I'm only reducing the amount of the increase. In other words
column10: what I'm talking about is not putting government back to getting less money than government's been getting
column11: but simply cutting the increase in in spending.

column2: I've had to make thousands of decisions since I've been President
column3: serving in the Oval Office. And with each one of those decisions that affect the future of my country
column4: I have learned in the process. I think I'm a much wiser and more experienced man than I was when I debated four years ago against President Ford. I've also learned that there are no simple answers to complicated questions. H. L. Mencken said that for every problem there's a simple answer. It would be neat and plausible and wrong. The fact is that this nation
column5: in the eight years before I became President
column6: had its own military strength decreased. Seven out of eight years
column7: the budget commitments for defense went down
column8: 37% in all. Since I've been in office
column9: we've had a steady
column10: carefully planned
column11: methodical but
column12: very effective increase in our commitment for defense. But what we've done is use that enormous power and prestige and military strength of the United States to preserve the peace. We've not only kept peace for our own country
column13: but we've been able to extend the benefits of peace to others. In the Middle East
column14: we've worked for a peace treaty between Israel and Egypt
column15: successfully
column16: and have tied ourselves together with Israel and Egypt in a common defense capability. This is a very good step forward for our nation's security
column17: and we'll continue to do as we have done in the past. I might also add that there are decisions that are made in the Oval Office by every President which are profound in nature. There are always trouble spots in the world
column18: and how those troubled areas are addressed by a President alone in that Oval Office affects our nation directly
column19: the involvement of the United States and also our American interests. That is a basic decision that has to be made so frequently
column20: by every President who serves. That is what I have tried to do successfully by keeping our country at peace.

column2: in my State of the Union address earlier this year
column3: I pointed out that any threat to the stability or security of the Persian Gulf would be a threat to the security of our own country. In the past
column4: we have not had an adequate military presence in that region. Now we have two major carrier task forces. We have access to facilities in five different areas of that region. And we've made it clear that working with our allies and others
column5: that we are prepared to address any foreseeable eventuality which might interrupt commerce with that crucial area of the world. But in doing this
column6: we have made sure that we address this question peacefully
column7: not injecting American military forces into combat
column8: but letting the strength of our nation be felt in a beneficial way. This
column9: I believe
column10: has assured that our interests will be protected in the Persian Gulf region
column11: as we have done in the Middle East and throughout the world.

column2: I question the figure about the decline in defense spending under the two previous Administrations in the preceding eight years to this Administration. I would call to your attention that we were in a war that wound down during those eight years
column3: which of course made a change in military spending because of turning from war to peace. I also would like to point out that Republican presidents in those years
column4: faced with a Democratic majority in both houses of the Congress
column5: found that their requests for defense budgets were very often cut. Now
column6: Gerald Ford left a five-year projected plan for a military build-up to restore our defenses
column7: and President Carter's administration reduced that by 38%
column8: cut 60 ships out of the Navy building program that had been proposed
column9: and stopped the the B-l
column10: delayed the cruise missile
column11: stopped the production line for the Minuteman missile
column12: stopped the Trident or delayed the Trident submarine
column13: and now is planning a mobile military force that can be delivered to various spots in the world which does make me question his assaults on whether I am the one who is quick to look for use of force.

column2: there are various elements of defense. One is to control nuclear weapons
column3: which I hope we'll get to later on because that is the most important single issue in this campaign. Another one is how to address troubled areas of the world. I think
column4: habitually
column5: Governor Reagan has advocated the injection of military forces into troubled areas
column6: when I and my predecessors - both Democrats and Republicans - have advocated resolving those troubles in those difficult areas of the world peacefully
column7: diplomatically
column8: and through negotiation. In addition to that
column9: the build-up of military forces is good for our country because we've got to have military strength to preserve the peace. But I'll always remember that the best weapons are the ones that are never fired in combat
column10: and the best soldier is one who never has to lay his life down on the field of battle. Strength is imperative for peace
column11: but the two must go hand in hand.

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 1)	" I don't know what the differences might be
column4: because I don't know what Mr. Carter's policies are. I do know what he has said about mine. And I'm only here to tell you that I believe with all my heart that our first priority must be world peace
column5: and that use of force is always and only a last resort
column6: when everything else has failed
column7: and then only with regard to our national security. Now
column8: I believe
column9: also
column10: that this meeting this mission
column11: this responsibility for preserving the peace
column12: which I believe is a responsibility peculiar to our country
column13: and that we cannot shirk our responsibility as a leader of the free world because we're the only ones that can do it. Therefore
column14: the burden of maintaining the peace falls on us. And to maintain that peace requires strength. America has never gotten in a war because we were too strong. We can get into a war by letting events get out of hand
column15: as they have in the last three and a half years under the foreign policies of this Administration of Mr. Carter's
column16: until we're faced each time with a crisis. And good management in preserving the peace requires that we control the events and try to intercept before they become a crisis. I have seen four wars in my lifetime. I'm a father of sons; I have a grandson. I don't ever want to see another generation of young Americans bleed their lives into sandy beachheads in the Pacific
column17: or rice paddies and jungles in the in Asia or the muddy battlefields of Europe.

column2: I have submitted an economic plan that I have worked out in concert with a number of fine economists in this country
column3: all of whom approve it
column4: and believe that over a five year projection
column5: this plan can permit the extra spending for needed refurbishing of our defensive posture
column6: that it can provide for a balanced budget by 1983 if not earlier
column7: and that we can afford - along with the cuts that I have proposed in Government. spending - we can afford the tax cuts I have proposed and probably mainly because Mr. Carter's economic policy has built into the next five years
column8: and on beyond that
column9: a tax increase that will be taking $86 billion more out of the people's pockets than was taken this year. And my tax cut does not come close to eliminating that $86 billion increase. I'm only reducing the amount of the increase. In other words
column10: what I'm talking about is not putting government back to getting less money than government's been getting
column11: but simply cutting the increase in in spending.

column2: I've had to make thousands of decisions since I've been President
column3: serving in the Oval Office. And with each one of those decisions that affect the future of my country
column4: I have learned in the process. I think I'm a much wiser and more experienced man than I was when I debated four years ago against President Ford. I've also learned that there are no simple answers to complicated questions. H. L. Mencken said that for every problem there's a simple answer. It would be neat and plausible and wrong. The fact is that this nation
column5: in the eight years before I became President
column6: had its own military strength decreased. Seven out of eight years
column7: the budget commitments for defense went down
column8: 37% in all. Since I've been in office
column9: we've had a steady
column10: carefully planned
column11: methodical but
column12: very effective increase in our commitment for defense. But what we've done is use that enormous power and prestige and military strength of the United States to preserve the peace. We've not only kept peace for our own country
column13: but we've been able to extend the benefits of peace to others. In the Middle East
column14: we've worked for a peace treaty between Israel and Egypt
column15: successfully
column16: and have tied ourselves together with Israel and Egypt in a common defense capability. This is a very good step forward for our nation's security
column17: and we'll continue to do as we have done in the past. I might also add that there are decisions that are made in the Oval Office by every President which are profound in nature. There are always trouble spots in the world
column18: and how those troubled areas are addressed by a President alone in that Oval Office affects our nation directly
column19: the involvement of the United States and also our American interests. That is a basic decision that has to be made so frequently
column20: by every President who serves. That is what I have tried to do successfully by keeping our country at peace.

column2: in my State of the Union address earlier this year
column3: I pointed out that any threat to the stability or security of the Persian Gulf would be a threat to the security of our own country. In the past
column4: we have not had an adequate military presence in that region. Now we have two major carrier task forces. We have access to facilities in five different areas of that region. And we've made it clear that working with our allies and others
column5: that we are prepared to address any foreseeable eventuality which might interrupt commerce with that crucial area of the world. But in doing this
column6: we have made sure that we address this question peacefully
column7: not injecting American military forces into combat
column8: but letting the strength of our nation be felt in a beneficial way. This
column9: I believe
column10: has assured that our interests will be protected in the Persian Gulf region
column11: as we have done in the Middle East and throughout the world.

column2: I question the figure about the decline in defense spending under the two previous Administrations in the preceding eight years to this Administration. I would call to your attention that we were in a war that wound down during those eight years
column3: which of course made a change in military spending because of turning from war to peace. I also would like to point out that Republican presidents in those years
column4: faced with a Democratic majority in both houses of the Congress
column5: found that their requests for defense budgets were very often cut. Now
column6: Gerald Ford left a five-year projected plan for a military build-up to restore our defenses
column7: and President Carter's administration reduced that by 38%
column8: cut 60 ships out of the Navy building program that had been proposed
column9: and stopped the the B-l
column10: delayed the cruise missile
column11: stopped the production line for the Minuteman missile
column12: stopped the Trident or delayed the Trident submarine
column13: and now is planning a mobile military force that can be delivered to various spots in the world which does make me question his assaults on whether I am the one who is quick to look for use of force.

column2: there are various elements of defense. One is to control nuclear weapons
column3: which I hope we'll get to later on because that is the most important single issue in this campaign. Another one is how to address troubled areas of the world. I think
column4: habitually
column5: Governor Reagan has advocated the injection of military forces into troubled areas
column6: when I and my predecessors - both Democrats and Republicans - have advocated resolving those troubles in those difficult areas of the world peacefully
column7: diplomatically
column8: and through negotiation. In addition to that
column9: the build-up of military forces is good for our country because we've got to have military strength to preserve the peace. But I'll always remember that the best weapons are the ones that are never fired in combat
column10: and the best soldier is one who never has to lay his life down on the field of battle. Strength is imperative for peace
column11: but the two must go hand in hand.

column46: I have learned in the process.'
column47: ""I think I'm a much wiser and more experienced man than I was when I debated four years ago against President Ford.""
column48: ""I've also learned that there are no simple answers to complicated questions.""
column49: ""H. L. Mencken said that for every problem there's a simple answer.""

column51: 'The fact is that this nation
column52: in the eight years before I became President

column54: 'Seven out of eight years
