column2: '28Oct'
column3: 2)	" Again it's important to put the situation in perspective. In 1974
column4: we had a so-called oil shock
column5: wherein the price of OPEC oil was raised to an extraordinary degree. We had an even worse oil shock in 1979. In 1974
column6: we had the worst recession
column7: the deepest and most penetrating recession since the Second World War. The recession that resulted this time was the briefest since the Second World War. In addition
column8: we've brought down inflation. Earlier this year
column9: in the first quarter
column10: we did have a very severe inflation pressure brought about by the OPEC price increase. It averaged about 18% in the first quarter of this year. In the second quarter
column11: we had dropped it down to about 13%. The most recent figures
column12: the last three months
column13: on the third quarter of this year
column14: the inflation rate is 7% - still too high
column15: but it illustrates very vividly that in addition to providing an enormous number of jobs - nine million new jobs in the last three and a half years - that the inflationary threat is still urgent on us. I notice that Governor Reagan recently mentioned the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal. which his own running mate
column16: George Bush
column17: described as voodoo economics
column18: and said that it would result in a 30% inflation rate. And Business Week
column19: which is not a Democratic publication
column20: said that this Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal - and I quote them
column21: I think - was completely irresponsible and would result in inflationary pressures which would destroy this nation. So our proposals are very sound and very carefully considered to stimulate jobs
column22: to improve the industrial complex of this country
column23: to create tools for American workers
column24: and at the same time would be anti-inflationary in nature. So to add nine million new jobs
column26: and to plan for the future with an energy policy now intact as a foundation is our plan for the years ahead.

column1: Yes. We have demanded that the American people sacrifice
column2: and they have done very well. As a matter of fact
column3: we're importing today about one-third less oil from overseas than we did just a year ago. We've had a 25% reduction since the first year I was in office. At the same time
column4: as I have said earlier
column5: we have added about nine million net new jobs in that period of time - a record never before achieved. Also
column6: the new energy policy has been predicated on two factors: One is conservation
column7: which requires sacrifice
column8: and the other one
column9: increase in production of American energy
column10: which is going along very well - more coal this year than ever before in American history
column11: more oil and gas wells drilled this year than ever before in history. The new economic revitalization program that we have in mind
column12: which will be implemented next year
column13: would result in tax credits which would let business invest in new tools and new factories to create even more new jobs - about one million in the next two years. And we also have planned a youth employment program which would encompass 600
column14: 000 jobs for young people. This has already passed the House
column15: and it has an excellent prospect to pass the Senate.

column2: I think this idea that has been spawned here in our country that inflation somehow came upon us like a plague and therefore it's uncontrollable and no one can do anything about it
column3: is entirely spurious and it's dangerous to say this to the people. When Mr. Carter became President
column4: inflation was 4.8%
column5: as you said. It had been cut in two by President Gerald Ford. It is now running at 12.7%. President Carter also has spoken of the new jobs created. Well
column6: we always
column7: with the normal growth in our country and increase in population
column8: increase the number of jobs. But that can't hide the fact that there are eight million men and women out of work in America today
column9: and two million of those lost their jobs in just the last few months. Mr. Carter had also promised that he would not use unemployment as a tool to fight against inflation. And yet
column10: his 1980 economic message stated that we would reduce productivity and gross national product and increase unemployment in order to get a handle on inflation
column11: because in January
column12: at the beginning of the year
column13: it was more than 18%. Since then
column14: he has blamed the people for inflation
column15: OPEC
column16: he has blamed the Federal Reserve system
column17: he has blamed the lack of productivity of the American people
column18: he has then accused the people of living too well and that we must share in scarcity
column19: we must sacrifice and get used to doing with less. We don't have inflation because the people are living too well. We have inflation because the Government is living too well. And the last statement
column20: just a few days ago
column21: was a speech to the effect that we have inflation because Government revenues have not kept pace with Government spending. I see my time is running out here. I'll have to get this out very fast. Yes
column22: you can lick inflation by increasing productivity and by decreasing the cost of government to the place that we have balanced budgets
column23: and are no longer grinding out printing press money
column24: flooding the market with it because the Government is spending more than it takes in. And my economic plan calls for that. The President's economic plan calls for increasing the taxes to the point that we finally take so much money away from the people that we can balance the budget in that way. But we will have a very poor nation and a very unsound economy if we follow that path.

column2: when they think about cutting Government spending
column3: they think in terms of eliminating necessary programs or wiping out something
column4: some service that Government is supposed to perform. I believe that there is enough extravagance and fat in government. As a matter of fact
column5: one of the secretaries of HEW under Mr. Carter testified that he thought there was $7 billion worth of fraud and waste in welfare and in the medical programs associated with it. We've had the Central Accounting. Office estimate that there is probably tens of billions of dollars that is lost in fraud alone
column6: and they have added that waste adds even more to that. We have a program for a gradual reduction of Government spending based on these theories
column7: and I have a task force now that has been working on where those cuts could be made. I'm confident that it can be done and that it will reduce inflation because I did it in California. And inflation went down below the national average in California when we returned the money to the people and reduced Government spending.

column2: the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal
column3: is one of the most highly inflationary ideas that ever has been presented to the American public. He would actually have to cut Government spending by at least $130 billion in order to balance the budget under this ridiculous proposal. I notice that his task force that is working for his future plans had some of their ideas revealed in The Wall Street Journal this week. One of those ideas was to repeal the minimum wage
column4: and several times this year
column5: Governor Reagan has said that the major cause of unemployment is the minimum wage. This is a heartless kind of approach to the working families of our country
column6: which is typical of many Republican leaders of the past
column7: but
column8: I think
column9: has been accentuated under Governor Reagan. In California - I'm surprised Governor Reagan brought this up - he had the three largest tax increases in the history of that state under his administration. He more than doubled state spending while he was Governor - 122% increase - and had between a 20% and 30% increase in the number of employees

column2: sir.

column1: Yes. The figures that the President has just used about California is a distortion of the situation there
column2: because while I was Governor of California
column3: our spending in California increased less per capita than the spending in Georgia while Mr. Carter was Governor of Georgia in the same four years. The size of government increased only one-sixth in California of what it increased in proportion to the population in Georgia. And the idea that my tax-cut proposal is inflationary: I would like to ask the President why is it inflationary to let the people keep more of their money and spend it the way that they like
column4: and it isn't inflationary to let him take that money and spend it the way he wants?

column4: as I have said earlier
column5: we have added about nine million net new jobs in that period of time - a record never before achieved. Also
column6: the new energy policy has been predicated on two factors: One is conservation
column7: which requires sacrifice
column8: and the other one
column9: increase in production of American energy
column10: which is going along very well - more coal this year than ever before in American history
column11: more oil and gas wells drilled this year than ever before in history. The new economic revitalization program that we have in mind
column12: which will be implemented next year
column13: would result in tax credits which would let business invest in new tools and new factories to create even more new jobs - about one million in the next two years. And we also have planned a youth employment program which would encompass 600
column14: 000 jobs for young people. This has already passed the House
column15: and it has an excellent prospect to pass the Senate.

column2: I think this idea that has been spawned here in our country that inflation somehow came upon us like a plague and therefore it's uncontrollable and no one can do anything about it
column3: is entirely spurious and it's dangerous to say this to the people. When Mr. Carter became President
column4: inflation was 4.8%
column5: as you said. It had been cut in two by President Gerald Ford. It is now running at 12.7%. President Carter also has spoken of the new jobs created. Well
column6: we always
column7: with the normal growth in our country and increase in population
column8: increase the number of jobs. But that can't hide the fact that there are eight million men and women out of work in America today
column9: and two million of those lost their jobs in just the last few months. Mr. Carter had also promised that he would not use unemployment as a tool to fight against inflation. And yet
column10: his 1980 economic message stated that we would reduce productivity and gross national product and increase unemployment in order to get a handle on inflation
column11: because in January
column12: at the beginning of the year
column13: it was more than 18%. Since then
column14: he has blamed the people for inflation
column15: OPEC
column16: he has blamed the Federal Reserve system
column17: he has blamed the lack of productivity of the American people
column18: he has then accused the people of living too well and that we must share in scarcity
column19: we must sacrifice and get used to doing with less. We don't have inflation because the people are living too well. We have inflation because the Government is living too well. And the last statement
column20: just a few days ago
column21: was a speech to the effect that we have inflation because Government revenues have not kept pace with Government spending. I see my time is running out here. I'll have to get this out very fast. Yes
column22: you can lick inflation by increasing productivity and by decreasing the cost of government to the place that we have balanced budgets
column23: and are no longer grinding out printing press money
column24: flooding the market with it because the Government is spending more than it takes in. And my economic plan calls for that. The President's economic plan calls for increasing the taxes to the point that we finally take so much money away from the people that we can balance the budget in that way. But we will have a very poor nation and a very unsound economy if we follow that path.

column2: when they think about cutting Government spending
column3: they think in terms of eliminating necessary programs or wiping out something
column4: some service that Government is supposed to perform. I believe that there is enough extravagance and fat in government. As a matter of fact
column5: one of the secretaries of HEW under Mr. Carter testified that he thought there was $7 billion worth of fraud and waste in welfare and in the medical programs associated with it. We've had the Central Accounting. Office estimate that there is probably tens of billions of dollars that is lost in fraud alone
column6: and they have added that waste adds even more to that. We have a program for a gradual reduction of Government spending based on these theories
column7: and I have a task force now that has been working on where those cuts could be made. I'm confident that it can be done and that it will reduce inflation because I did it in California. And inflation went down below the national average in California when we returned the money to the people and reduced Government spending.

column2: the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal
column3: is one of the most highly inflationary ideas that ever has been presented to the American public. He would actually have to cut Government spending by at least $130 billion in order to balance the budget under this ridiculous proposal. I notice that his task force that is working for his future plans had some of their ideas revealed in The Wall Street Journal this week. One of those ideas was to repeal the minimum wage
column4: and several times this year
column5: Governor Reagan has said that the major cause of unemployment is the minimum wage. This is a heartless kind of approach to the working families of our country
column6: which is typical of many Republican leaders of the past
column7: but
column8: I think
column9: has been accentuated under Governor Reagan. In California - I'm surprised Governor Reagan brought this up - he had the three largest tax increases in the history of that state under his administration. He more than doubled state spending while he was Governor - 122% increase - and had between a 20% and 30% increase in the number of employees

column2: sir.

column1: Yes. The figures that the President has just used about California is a distortion of the situation there
column2: because while I was Governor of California
column3: our spending in California increased less per capita than the spending in Georgia while Mr. Carter was Governor of Georgia in the same four years. The size of government increased only one-sixth in California of what it increased in proportion to the population in Georgia. And the idea that my tax-cut proposal is inflationary: I would like to ask the President why is it inflationary to let the people keep more of their money and spend it the way that they like
column4: and it isn't inflationary to let him take that money and spend it the way he wants?

column3: 2)	" Again it's important to put the situation in perspective. In 1974
column4: we had a so-called oil shock
column5: wherein the price of OPEC oil was raised to an extraordinary degree. We had an even worse oil shock in 1979. In 1974
column6: we had the worst recession
column7: the deepest and most penetrating recession since the Second World War. The recession that resulted this time was the briefest since the Second World War. In addition
column8: we've brought down inflation. Earlier this year
column9: in the first quarter
column10: we did have a very severe inflation pressure brought about by the OPEC price increase. It averaged about 18% in the first quarter of this year. In the second quarter
column11: we had dropped it down to about 13%. The most recent figures
column12: the last three months
column13: on the third quarter of this year
column14: the inflation rate is 7% - still too high
column15: but it illustrates very vividly that in addition to providing an enormous number of jobs - nine million new jobs in the last three and a half years - that the inflationary threat is still urgent on us. I notice that Governor Reagan recently mentioned the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal. which his own running mate
column16: George Bush
column17: described as voodoo economics
column18: and said that it would result in a 30% inflation rate. And Business Week
column19: which is not a Democratic publication
column20: said that this Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal - and I quote them
column21: I think - was completely irresponsible and would result in inflationary pressures which would destroy this nation. So our proposals are very sound and very carefully considered to stimulate jobs
column22: to improve the industrial complex of this country
column23: to create tools for American workers
column24: and at the same time would be anti-inflationary in nature. So to add nine million new jobs
column26: and to plan for the future with an energy policy now intact as a foundation is our plan for the years ahead.

column1: Yes. We have demanded that the American people sacrifice
column2: and they have done very well. As a matter of fact
column3: we're importing today about one-third less oil from overseas than we did just a year ago. We've had a 25% reduction since the first year I was in office. At the same time
column4: as I have said earlier
column5: we have added about nine million net new jobs in that period of time - a record never before achieved. Also
column6: the new energy policy has been predicated on two factors: One is conservation
column7: which requires sacrifice
column8: and the other one
column9: increase in production of American energy
column10: which is going along very well - more coal this year than ever before in American history
column11: more oil and gas wells drilled this year than ever before in history. The new economic revitalization program that we have in mind
column12: which will be implemented next year
column13: would result in tax credits which would let business invest in new tools and new factories to create even more new jobs - about one million in the next two years. And we also have planned a youth employment program which would encompass 600
column14: 000 jobs for young people. This has already passed the House
column15: and it has an excellent prospect to pass the Senate.

column2: I think this idea that has been spawned here in our country that inflation somehow came upon us like a plague and therefore it's uncontrollable and no one can do anything about it
column3: is entirely spurious and it's dangerous to say this to the people. When Mr. Carter became President
column4: inflation was 4.8%
column5: as you said. It had been cut in two by President Gerald Ford. It is now running at 12.7%. President Carter also has spoken of the new jobs created. Well
column6: we always
column7: with the normal growth in our country and increase in population
column8: increase the number of jobs. But that can't hide the fact that there are eight million men and women out of work in America today
column9: and two million of those lost their jobs in just the last few months. Mr. Carter had also promised that he would not use unemployment as a tool to fight against inflation. And yet
column10: his 1980 economic message stated that we would reduce productivity and gross national product and increase unemployment in order to get a handle on inflation
column11: because in January
column12: at the beginning of the year
column13: it was more than 18%. Since then
column14: he has blamed the people for inflation
column15: OPEC
column16: he has blamed the Federal Reserve system
column17: he has blamed the lack of productivity of the American people
column18: he has then accused the people of living too well and that we must share in scarcity
column19: we must sacrifice and get used to doing with less. We don't have inflation because the people are living too well. We have inflation because the Government is living too well. And the last statement
column20: just a few days ago
column21: was a speech to the effect that we have inflation because Government revenues have not kept pace with Government spending. I see my time is running out here. I'll have to get this out very fast. Yes
column22: you can lick inflation by increasing productivity and by decreasing the cost of government to the place that we have balanced budgets
column23: and are no longer grinding out printing press money
column24: flooding the market with it because the Government is spending more than it takes in. And my economic plan calls for that. The President's economic plan calls for increasing the taxes to the point that we finally take so much money away from the people that we can balance the budget in that way. But we will have a very poor nation and a very unsound economy if we follow that path.

column2: when they think about cutting Government spending
column3: they think in terms of eliminating necessary programs or wiping out something
column4: some service that Government is supposed to perform. I believe that there is enough extravagance and fat in government. As a matter of fact
column5: one of the secretaries of HEW under Mr. Carter testified that he thought there was $7 billion worth of fraud and waste in welfare and in the medical programs associated with it. We've had the Central Accounting. Office estimate that there is probably tens of billions of dollars that is lost in fraud alone
column6: and they have added that waste adds even more to that. We have a program for a gradual reduction of Government spending based on these theories
column7: and I have a task force now that has been working on where those cuts could be made. I'm confident that it can be done and that it will reduce inflation because I did it in California. And inflation went down below the national average in California when we returned the money to the people and reduced Government spending.

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 2)	" Again it's important to put the situation in perspective. In 1974
column4: we had a so-called oil shock
column5: wherein the price of OPEC oil was raised to an extraordinary degree. We had an even worse oil shock in 1979. In 1974
column6: we had the worst recession
column7: the deepest and most penetrating recession since the Second World War. The recession that resulted this time was the briefest since the Second World War. In addition
column8: we've brought down inflation. Earlier this year
column9: in the first quarter
column10: we did have a very severe inflation pressure brought about by the OPEC price increase. It averaged about 18% in the first quarter of this year. In the second quarter
column11: we had dropped it down to about 13%. The most recent figures
column12: the last three months
column13: on the third quarter of this year
column14: the inflation rate is 7% - still too high
column15: but it illustrates very vividly that in addition to providing an enormous number of jobs - nine million new jobs in the last three and a half years - that the inflationary threat is still urgent on us. I notice that Governor Reagan recently mentioned the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal. which his own running mate
column16: George Bush
column17: described as voodoo economics
column18: and said that it would result in a 30% inflation rate. And Business Week
column19: which is not a Democratic publication
column20: said that this Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal - and I quote them
column21: I think - was completely irresponsible and would result in inflationary pressures which would destroy this nation. So our proposals are very sound and very carefully considered to stimulate jobs
column22: to improve the industrial complex of this country
column23: to create tools for American workers
column24: and at the same time would be anti-inflationary in nature. So to add nine million new jobs
column26: and to plan for the future with an energy policy now intact as a foundation is our plan for the years ahead.

column1: Yes. We have demanded that the American people sacrifice
column2: and they have done very well. As a matter of fact
column3: we're importing today about one-third less oil from overseas than we did just a year ago. We've had a 25% reduction since the first year I was in office. At the same time
column4: as I have said earlier
column5: we have added about nine million net new jobs in that period of time - a record never before achieved. Also
column6: the new energy policy has been predicated on two factors: One is conservation
column7: which requires sacrifice
column8: and the other one
column9: increase in production of American energy
column10: which is going along very well - more coal this year than ever before in American history
column11: more oil and gas wells drilled this year than ever before in history. The new economic revitalization program that we have in mind
column12: which will be implemented next year
column13: would result in tax credits which would let business invest in new tools and new factories to create even more new jobs - about one million in the next two years. And we also have planned a youth employment program which would encompass 600
column14: 000 jobs for young people. This has already passed the House
column15: and it has an excellent prospect to pass the Senate.

column2: I think this idea that has been spawned here in our country that inflation somehow came upon us like a plague and therefore it's uncontrollable and no one can do anything about it
column3: is entirely spurious and it's dangerous to say this to the people. When Mr. Carter became President
column4: inflation was 4.8%
column5: as you said. It had been cut in two by President Gerald Ford. It is now running at 12.7%. President Carter also has spoken of the new jobs created. Well
column6: we always
column7: with the normal growth in our country and increase in population
column8: increase the number of jobs. But that can't hide the fact that there are eight million men and women out of work in America today
column9: and two million of those lost their jobs in just the last few months. Mr. Carter had also promised that he would not use unemployment as a tool to fight against inflation. And yet
column10: his 1980 economic message stated that we would reduce productivity and gross national product and increase unemployment in order to get a handle on inflation
column11: because in January
column12: at the beginning of the year
column13: it was more than 18%. Since then
column14: he has blamed the people for inflation
column15: OPEC
column16: he has blamed the Federal Reserve system
column17: he has blamed the lack of productivity of the American people
column18: he has then accused the people of living too well and that we must share in scarcity
column19: we must sacrifice and get used to doing with less. We don't have inflation because the people are living too well. We have inflation because the Government is living too well. And the last statement
column20: just a few days ago
column21: was a speech to the effect that we have inflation because Government revenues have not kept pace with Government spending. I see my time is running out here. I'll have to get this out very fast. Yes
column22: you can lick inflation by increasing productivity and by decreasing the cost of government to the place that we have balanced budgets
column23: and are no longer grinding out printing press money
column24: flooding the market with it because the Government is spending more than it takes in. And my economic plan calls for that. The President's economic plan calls for increasing the taxes to the point that we finally take so much money away from the people that we can balance the budget in that way. But we will have a very poor nation and a very unsound economy if we follow that path.

column2: when they think about cutting Government spending
column3: they think in terms of eliminating necessary programs or wiping out something
column4: some service that Government is supposed to perform. I believe that there is enough extravagance and fat in government. As a matter of fact
column5: one of the secretaries of HEW under Mr. Carter testified that he thought there was $7 billion worth of fraud and waste in welfare and in the medical programs associated with it. We've had the Central Accounting. Office estimate that there is probably tens of billions of dollars that is lost in fraud alone
column6: and they have added that waste adds even more to that. We have a program for a gradual reduction of Government spending based on these theories
column7: and I have a task force now that has been working on where those cuts could be made. I'm confident that it can be done and that it will reduce inflation because I did it in California. And inflation went down below the national average in California when we returned the money to the people and reduced Government spending.

column3: 2)	" Again it's important to put the situation in perspective. In 1974
column4: we had a so-called oil shock
column5: wherein the price of OPEC oil was raised to an extraordinary degree. We had an even worse oil shock in 1979. In 1974
column6: we had the worst recession
column7: the deepest and most penetrating recession since the Second World War. The recession that resulted this time was the briefest since the Second World War. In addition
column8: we've brought down inflation. Earlier this year
column9: in the first quarter
column10: we did have a very severe inflation pressure brought about by the OPEC price increase. It averaged about 18% in the first quarter of this year. In the second quarter
column11: we had dropped it down to about 13%. The most recent figures
column12: the last three months
column13: on the third quarter of this year
column14: the inflation rate is 7% - still too high
column15: but it illustrates very vividly that in addition to providing an enormous number of jobs - nine million new jobs in the last three and a half years - that the inflationary threat is still urgent on us. I notice that Governor Reagan recently mentioned the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal. which his own running mate
column16: George Bush
column17: described as voodoo economics
column18: and said that it would result in a 30% inflation rate. And Business Week
column19: which is not a Democratic publication
column20: said that this Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal - and I quote them
column21: I think - was completely irresponsible and would result in inflationary pressures which would destroy this nation. So our proposals are very sound and very carefully considered to stimulate jobs
column22: to improve the industrial complex of this country
column23: to create tools for American workers
column24: and at the same time would be anti-inflationary in nature. So to add nine million new jobs
column26: and to plan for the future with an energy policy now intact as a foundation is our plan for the years ahead.

column1: Yes. We have demanded that the American people sacrifice
column2: and they have done very well. As a matter of fact
column3: we're importing today about one-third less oil from overseas than we did just a year ago. We've had a 25% reduction since the first year I was in office. At the same time
column4: as I have said earlier
column5: we have added about nine million net new jobs in that period of time - a record never before achieved. Also
column6: the new energy policy has been predicated on two factors: One is conservation
column7: which requires sacrifice
column8: and the other one
column9: increase in production of American energy
column10: which is going along very well - more coal this year than ever before in American history
column11: more oil and gas wells drilled this year than ever before in history. The new economic revitalization program that we have in mind
column12: which will be implemented next year
column13: would result in tax credits which would let business invest in new tools and new factories to create even more new jobs - about one million in the next two years. And we also have planned a youth employment program which would encompass 600
column14: 000 jobs for young people. This has already passed the House
column15: and it has an excellent prospect to pass the Senate.

column2: I think this idea that has been spawned here in our country that inflation somehow came upon us like a plague and therefore it's uncontrollable and no one can do anything about it
column3: is entirely spurious and it's dangerous to say this to the people. When Mr. Carter became President
column4: inflation was 4.8%
column5: as you said. It had been cut in two by President Gerald Ford. It is now running at 12.7%. President Carter also has spoken of the new jobs created. Well
column6: we always
column7: with the normal growth in our country and increase in population
column8: increase the number of jobs. But that can't hide the fact that there are eight million men and women out of work in America today
column9: and two million of those lost their jobs in just the last few months. Mr. Carter had also promised that he would not use unemployment as a tool to fight against inflation. And yet
column10: his 1980 economic message stated that we would reduce productivity and gross national product and increase unemployment in order to get a handle on inflation
column11: because in January
column12: at the beginning of the year
column13: it was more than 18%. Since then
column14: he has blamed the people for inflation
column15: OPEC
column16: he has blamed the Federal Reserve system
column17: he has blamed the lack of productivity of the American people
column18: he has then accused the people of living too well and that we must share in scarcity
column19: we must sacrifice and get used to doing with less. We don't have inflation because the people are living too well. We have inflation because the Government is living too well. And the last statement
column20: just a few days ago
column21: was a speech to the effect that we have inflation because Government revenues have not kept pace with Government spending. I see my time is running out here. I'll have to get this out very fast. Yes
column22: you can lick inflation by increasing productivity and by decreasing the cost of government to the place that we have balanced budgets
column23: and are no longer grinding out printing press money
column24: flooding the market with it because the Government is spending more than it takes in. And my economic plan calls for that. The President's economic plan calls for increasing the taxes to the point that we finally take so much money away from the people that we can balance the budget in that way. But we will have a very poor nation and a very unsound economy if we follow that path.

column2: when they think about cutting Government spending
column3: they think in terms of eliminating necessary programs or wiping out something
column4: some service that Government is supposed to perform. I believe that there is enough extravagance and fat in government. As a matter of fact
column5: one of the secretaries of HEW under Mr. Carter testified that he thought there was $7 billion worth of fraud and waste in welfare and in the medical programs associated with it. We've had the Central Accounting. Office estimate that there is probably tens of billions of dollars that is lost in fraud alone
column6: and they have added that waste adds even more to that. We have a program for a gradual reduction of Government spending based on these theories
column7: and I have a task force now that has been working on where those cuts could be made. I'm confident that it can be done and that it will reduce inflation because I did it in California. And inflation went down below the national average in California when we returned the money to the people and reduced Government spending.

column2: the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal
column3: is one of the most highly inflationary ideas that ever has been presented to the American public. He would actually have to cut Government spending by at least $130 billion in order to balance the budget under this ridiculous proposal. I notice that his task force that is working for his future plans had some of their ideas revealed in The Wall Street Journal this week. One of those ideas was to repeal the minimum wage
column4: and several times this year
column5: Governor Reagan has said that the major cause of unemployment is the minimum wage. This is a heartless kind of approach to the working families of our country
column6: which is typical of many Republican leaders of the past
column7: but
column8: I think
column9: has been accentuated under Governor Reagan. In California - I'm surprised Governor Reagan brought this up - he had the three largest tax increases in the history of that state under his administration. He more than doubled state spending while he was Governor - 122% increase - and had between a 20% and 30% increase in the number of employees

column2: sir.

column1: Yes. The figures that the President has just used about California is a distortion of the situation there
column2: because while I was Governor of California
column3: our spending in California increased less per capita than the spending in Georgia while Mr. Carter was Governor of Georgia in the same four years. The size of government increased only one-sixth in California of what it increased in proportion to the population in Georgia. And the idea that my tax-cut proposal is inflationary: I would like to ask the President why is it inflationary to let the people keep more of their money and spend it the way that they like
column4: and it isn't inflationary to let him take that money and spend it the way he wants?

column3: 2)	" Again it's important to put the situation in perspective. In 1974
column4: we had a so-called oil shock
column5: wherein the price of OPEC oil was raised to an extraordinary degree. We had an even worse oil shock in 1979. In 1974
column6: we had the worst recession
column7: the deepest and most penetrating recession since the Second World War. The recession that resulted this time was the briefest since the Second World War. In addition
column8: we've brought down inflation. Earlier this year
column9: in the first quarter
column10: we did have a very severe inflation pressure brought about by the OPEC price increase. It averaged about 18% in the first quarter of this year. In the second quarter
column11: we had dropped it down to about 13%. The most recent figures
column12: the last three months
column13: on the third quarter of this year
column14: the inflation rate is 7% - still too high
column15: but it illustrates very vividly that in addition to providing an enormous number of jobs - nine million new jobs in the last three and a half years - that the inflationary threat is still urgent on us. I notice that Governor Reagan recently mentioned the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal. which his own running mate
column16: George Bush
column17: described as voodoo economics
column18: and said that it would result in a 30% inflation rate. And Business Week
column19: which is not a Democratic publication
column20: said that this Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal - and I quote them
column21: I think - was completely irresponsible and would result in inflationary pressures which would destroy this nation. So our proposals are very sound and very carefully considered to stimulate jobs
column22: to improve the industrial complex of this country
column23: to create tools for American workers
column24: and at the same time would be anti-inflationary in nature. So to add nine million new jobs
column26: and to plan for the future with an energy policy now intact as a foundation is our plan for the years ahead.

column1: Yes. We have demanded that the American people sacrifice
column2: and they have done very well. As a matter of fact
column3: we're importing today about one-third less oil from overseas than we did just a year ago. We've had a 25% reduction since the first year I was in office. At the same time
column4: as I have said earlier
column5: we have added about nine million net new jobs in that period of time - a record never before achieved. Also
column6: the new energy policy has been predicated on two factors: One is conservation
column7: which requires sacrifice
column8: and the other one
column9: increase in production of American energy
column10: which is going along very well - more coal this year than ever before in American history
column11: more oil and gas wells drilled this year than ever before in history. The new economic revitalization program that we have in mind
column12: which will be implemented next year
column13: would result in tax credits which would let business invest in new tools and new factories to create even more new jobs - about one million in the next two years. And we also have planned a youth employment program which would encompass 600
column14: 000 jobs for young people. This has already passed the House
column15: and it has an excellent prospect to pass the Senate.

column2: I think this idea that has been spawned here in our country that inflation somehow came upon us like a plague and therefore it's uncontrollable and no one can do anything about it
column3: is entirely spurious and it's dangerous to say this to the people. When Mr. Carter became President
column4: inflation was 4.8%
column5: as you said. It had been cut in two by President Gerald Ford. It is now running at 12.7%. President Carter also has spoken of the new jobs created. Well
column6: we always
column7: with the normal growth in our country and increase in population
column8: increase the number of jobs. But that can't hide the fact that there are eight million men and women out of work in America today
column9: and two million of those lost their jobs in just the last few months. Mr. Carter had also promised that he would not use unemployment as a tool to fight against inflation. And yet
column10: his 1980 economic message stated that we would reduce productivity and gross national product and increase unemployment in order to get a handle on inflation
column11: because in January
column12: at the beginning of the year
column13: it was more than 18%. Since then
column14: he has blamed the people for inflation
column15: OPEC
column16: he has blamed the Federal Reserve system
column17: he has blamed the lack of productivity of the American people
column18: he has then accused the people of living too well and that we must share in scarcity
column19: we must sacrifice and get used to doing with less. We don't have inflation because the people are living too well. We have inflation because the Government is living too well. And the last statement
column20: just a few days ago
column21: was a speech to the effect that we have inflation because Government revenues have not kept pace with Government spending. I see my time is running out here. I'll have to get this out very fast. Yes
column22: you can lick inflation by increasing productivity and by decreasing the cost of government to the place that we have balanced budgets
column23: and are no longer grinding out printing press money
column24: flooding the market with it because the Government is spending more than it takes in. And my economic plan calls for that. The President's economic plan calls for increasing the taxes to the point that we finally take so much money away from the people that we can balance the budget in that way. But we will have a very poor nation and a very unsound economy if we follow that path.

column2: when they think about cutting Government spending
column3: they think in terms of eliminating necessary programs or wiping out something
column4: some service that Government is supposed to perform. I believe that there is enough extravagance and fat in government. As a matter of fact
column5: one of the secretaries of HEW under Mr. Carter testified that he thought there was $7 billion worth of fraud and waste in welfare and in the medical programs associated with it. We've had the Central Accounting. Office estimate that there is probably tens of billions of dollars that is lost in fraud alone
column6: and they have added that waste adds even more to that. We have a program for a gradual reduction of Government spending based on these theories
column7: and I have a task force now that has been working on where those cuts could be made. I'm confident that it can be done and that it will reduce inflation because I did it in California. And inflation went down below the national average in California when we returned the money to the people and reduced Government spending.

column2: the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal
column3: is one of the most highly inflationary ideas that ever has been presented to the American public. He would actually have to cut Government spending by at least $130 billion in order to balance the budget under this ridiculous proposal. I notice that his task force that is working for his future plans had some of their ideas revealed in The Wall Street Journal this week. One of those ideas was to repeal the minimum wage
column4: and several times this year
column5: Governor Reagan has said that the major cause of unemployment is the minimum wage. This is a heartless kind of approach to the working families of our country
column6: which is typical of many Republican leaders of the past
column7: but
column8: I think
column9: has been accentuated under Governor Reagan. In California - I'm surprised Governor Reagan brought this up - he had the three largest tax increases in the history of that state under his administration. He more than doubled state spending while he was Governor - 122% increase - and had between a 20% and 30% increase in the number of employees

column1: Yes. The figures that the President has just used about California is a distortion of the situation there

column3: our spending in California increased less per capita than the spending in Georgia while Mr. Carter was Governor of Georgia in the same four years. The size of government increased only one-sixth in California of what it increased in proportion to the population in Georgia. And the idea that my tax-cut proposal is inflationary: I would like to ask the President why is it inflationary to let the people keep more of their money and spend it the way that they like

column3: 2)	" Again it's important to put the situation in perspective. In 1974
column4: we had a so-called oil shock
column5: wherein the price of OPEC oil was raised to an extraordinary degree. We had an even worse oil shock in 1979. In 1974
column6: we had the worst recession
column7: the deepest and most penetrating recession since the Second World War. The recession that resulted this time was the briefest since the Second World War. In addition
column8: we've brought down inflation. Earlier this year
column9: in the first quarter
column10: we did have a very severe inflation pressure brought about by the OPEC price increase. It averaged about 18% in the first quarter of this year. In the second quarter
column11: we had dropped it down to about 13%. The most recent figures
column12: the last three months
column13: on the third quarter of this year
column14: the inflation rate is 7% - still too high
column15: but it illustrates very vividly that in addition to providing an enormous number of jobs - nine million new jobs in the last three and a half years - that the inflationary threat is still urgent on us. I notice that Governor Reagan recently mentioned the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal. which his own running mate
column16: George Bush
column17: described as voodoo economics
column18: and said that it would result in a 30% inflation rate. And Business Week
column19: which is not a Democratic publication
column20: said that this Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal - and I quote them
column21: I think - was completely irresponsible and would result in inflationary pressures which would destroy this nation. So our proposals are very sound and very carefully considered to stimulate jobs
column22: to improve the industrial complex of this country
column23: to create tools for American workers
column24: and at the same time would be anti-inflationary in nature. So to add nine million new jobs

column1: Yes. We have demanded that the American people sacrifice
column2: and they have done very well. As a matter of fact
column3: we're importing today about one-third less oil from overseas than we did just a year ago. We've had a 25% reduction since the first year I was in office. At the same time
column4: as I have said earlier
column5: we have added about nine million net new jobs in that period of time - a record never before achieved. Also
column6: the new energy policy has been predicated on two factors: One is conservation
column7: which requires sacrifice
column8: and the other one
column9: increase in production of American energy
column10: which is going along very well - more coal this year than ever before in American history
column11: more oil and gas wells drilled this year than ever before in history. The new economic revitalization program that we have in mind
column12: which will be implemented next year
column13: would result in tax credits which would let business invest in new tools and new factories to create even more new jobs - about one million in the next two years. And we also have planned a youth employment program which would encompass 600
column14: 000 jobs for young people. This has already passed the House
column15: and it has an excellent prospect to pass the Senate.

column2: I think this idea that has been spawned here in our country that inflation somehow came upon us like a plague and therefore it's uncontrollable and no one can do anything about it
column3: is entirely spurious and it's dangerous to say this to the people. When Mr. Carter became President
column4: inflation was 4.8%
column5: as you said. It had been cut in two by President Gerald Ford. It is now running at 12.7%. President Carter also has spoken of the new jobs created. Well
column6: we always
column7: with the normal growth in our country and increase in population
column8: increase the number of jobs. But that can't hide the fact that there are eight million men and women out of work in America today
column9: and two million of those lost their jobs in just the last few months. Mr. Carter had also promised that he would not use unemployment as a tool to fight against inflation. And yet
column10: his 1980 economic message stated that we would reduce productivity and gross national product and increase unemployment in order to get a handle on inflation
column11: because in January
column12: at the beginning of the year
column13: it was more than 18%. Since then
column14: he has blamed the people for inflation
column15: OPEC
column16: he has blamed the Federal Reserve system
column17: he has blamed the lack of productivity of the American people
column18: he has then accused the people of living too well and that we must share in scarcity
column19: we must sacrifice and get used to doing with less. We don't have inflation because the people are living too well. We have inflation because the Government is living too well. And the last statement
column20: just a few days ago
column21: was a speech to the effect that we have inflation because Government revenues have not kept pace with Government spending. I see my time is running out here. I'll have to get this out very fast. Yes
column22: you can lick inflation by increasing productivity and by decreasing the cost of government to the place that we have balanced budgets
column23: and are no longer grinding out printing press money
column24: flooding the market with it because the Government is spending more than it takes in. And my economic plan calls for that. The President's economic plan calls for increasing the taxes to the point that we finally take so much money away from the people that we can balance the budget in that way. But we will have a very poor nation and a very unsound economy if we follow that path.

column2: when they think about cutting Government spending
column3: they think in terms of eliminating necessary programs or wiping out something
column4: some service that Government is supposed to perform. I believe that there is enough extravagance and fat in government. As a matter of fact
column5: one of the secretaries of HEW under Mr. Carter testified that he thought there was $7 billion worth of fraud and waste in welfare and in the medical programs associated with it. We've had the Central Accounting. Office estimate that there is probably tens of billions of dollars that is lost in fraud alone
column6: and they have added that waste adds even more to that. We have a program for a gradual reduction of Government spending based on these theories

column3: 2)	" Again it's important to put the situation in perspective. In 1974
column4: we had a so-called oil shock
column5: wherein the price of OPEC oil was raised to an extraordinary degree. We had an even worse oil shock in 1979. In 1974
column6: we had the worst recession
column7: the deepest and most penetrating recession since the Second World War. The recession that resulted this time was the briefest since the Second World War. In addition
column8: we've brought down inflation. Earlier this year
column9: in the first quarter
column10: we did have a very severe inflation pressure brought about by the OPEC price increase. It averaged about 18% in the first quarter of this year. In the second quarter
column11: we had dropped it down to about 13%. The most recent figures
column12: the last three months
column13: on the third quarter of this year
column14: the inflation rate is 7% - still too high
column15: but it illustrates very vividly that in addition to providing an enormous number of jobs - nine million new jobs in the last three and a half years - that the inflationary threat is still urgent on us. I notice that Governor Reagan recently mentioned the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal. which his own running mate
column16: George Bush
column17: described as voodoo economics
column18: and said that it would result in a 30% inflation rate. And Business Week
column19: which is not a Democratic publication
column20: said that this Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal - and I quote them
column21: I think - was completely irresponsible and would result in inflationary pressures which would destroy this nation. So our proposals are very sound and very carefully considered to stimulate jobs
column22: to improve the industrial complex of this country
column23: to create tools for American workers
column24: and at the same time would be anti-inflationary in nature. So to add nine million new jobs
column26: and to plan for the future with an energy policy now intact as a foundation is our plan for the years ahead.

column1: Yes. We have demanded that the American people sacrifice
column2: and they have done very well. As a matter of fact
column3: we're importing today about one-third less oil from overseas than we did just a year ago. We've had a 25% reduction since the first year I was in office. At the same time
column4: as I have said earlier
column5: we have added about nine million net new jobs in that period of time - a record never before achieved. Also
column6: the new energy policy has been predicated on two factors: One is conservation
column7: which requires sacrifice
column8: and the other one
column9: increase in production of American energy
column10: which is going along very well - more coal this year than ever before in American history
column11: more oil and gas wells drilled this year than ever before in history. The new economic revitalization program that we have in mind
column12: which will be implemented next year
column13: would result in tax credits which would let business invest in new tools and new factories to create even more new jobs - about one million in the next two years. And we also have planned a youth employment program which would encompass 600
column14: 000 jobs for young people. This has already passed the House
column15: and it has an excellent prospect to pass the Senate.

column2: I think this idea that has been spawned here in our country that inflation somehow came upon us like a plague and therefore it's uncontrollable and no one can do anything about it
column3: is entirely spurious and it's dangerous to say this to the people. When Mr. Carter became President
column4: inflation was 4.8%
column5: as you said. It had been cut in two by President Gerald Ford. It is now running at 12.7%. President Carter also has spoken of the new jobs created. Well
column6: we always
column7: with the normal growth in our country and increase in population
column8: increase the number of jobs. But that can't hide the fact that there are eight million men and women out of work in America today
column9: and two million of those lost their jobs in just the last few months. Mr. Carter had also promised that he would not use unemployment as a tool to fight against inflation. And yet
column10: his 1980 economic message stated that we would reduce productivity and gross national product and increase unemployment in order to get a handle on inflation
column11: because in January
column12: at the beginning of the year
column13: it was more than 18%. Since then
column14: he has blamed the people for inflation
column15: OPEC
column16: he has blamed the Federal Reserve system
column17: he has blamed the lack of productivity of the American people
column18: he has then accused the people of living too well and that we must share in scarcity
column19: we must sacrifice and get used to doing with less. We don't have inflation because the people are living too well. We have inflation because the Government is living too well. And the last statement
column20: just a few days ago
column21: was a speech to the effect that we have inflation because Government revenues have not kept pace with Government spending. I see my time is running out here. I'll have to get this out very fast. Yes
column22: you can lick inflation by increasing productivity and by decreasing the cost of government to the place that we have balanced budgets
column23: and are no longer grinding out printing press money
column24: flooding the market with it because the Government is spending more than it takes in. And my economic plan calls for that. The President's economic plan calls for increasing the taxes to the point that we finally take so much money away from the people that we can balance the budget in that way. But we will have a very poor nation and a very unsound economy if we follow that path.

column2: when they think about cutting Government spending

column4: some service that Government is supposed to perform. I believe that there is enough extravagance and fat in government. As a matter of fact
column5: one of the secretaries of HEW under Mr. Carter testified that he thought there was $7 billion worth of fraud and waste in welfare and in the medical programs associated with it. We've had the Central Accounting. Office estimate that there is probably tens of billions of dollars that is lost in fraud alone
column6: and they have added that waste adds even more to that. We have a program for a gradual reduction of Government spending based on these theories

And inflation went down below the national average in California when we returned the money to the people and reduced Government spending.

column3: 2)	" Again it's important to put the situation in perspective. In 1974
column4: we had a so-called oil shock
column5: wherein the price of OPEC oil was raised to an extraordinary degree. We had an even worse oil shock in 1979. In 1974
column6: we had the worst recession
column7: the deepest and most penetrating recession since the Second World War. The recession that resulted this time was the briefest since the Second World War. In addition
column8: we've brought down inflation. Earlier this year
column9: in the first quarter
column10: we did have a very severe inflation pressure brought about by the OPEC price increase. It averaged about 18% in the first quarter of this year. In the second quarter
column11: we had dropped it down to about 13%. The most recent figures
column12: the last three months
column13: on the third quarter of this year
column14: the inflation rate is 7% - still too high
column15: but it illustrates very vividly that in addition to providing an enormous number of jobs - nine million new jobs in the last three and a half years - that the inflationary threat is still urgent on us. I notice that Governor Reagan recently mentioned the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal. which his own running mate
column16: George Bush
column17: described as voodoo economics
column18: and said that it would result in a 30% inflation rate. And Business Week
column19: which is not a Democratic publication
column20: said that this Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal - and I quote them
column21: I think - was completely irresponsible and would result in inflationary pressures which would destroy this nation. So our proposals are very sound and very carefully considered to stimulate jobs
column22: to improve the industrial complex of this country
column23: to create tools for American workers
column24: and at the same time would be anti-inflationary in nature. So to add nine million new jobs
column26: and to plan for the future with an energy policy now intact as a foundation is our plan for the years ahead.

column1: Yes. We have demanded that the American people sacrifice
column2: and they have done very well. As a matter of fact
column3: we're importing today about one-third less oil from overseas than we did just a year ago. We've had a 25% reduction since the first year I was in office. At the same time
column4: as I have said earlier
column5: we have added about nine million net new jobs in that period of time - a record never before achieved. Also
column6: the new energy policy has been predicated on two factors: One is conservation
column7: which requires sacrifice
column8: and the other one
column9: increase in production of American energy
column10: which is going along very well - more coal this year than ever before in American history
column11: more oil and gas wells drilled this year than ever before in history. The new economic revitalization program that we have in mind
column12: which will be implemented next year
column13: would result in tax credits which would let business invest in new tools and new factories to create even more new jobs - about one million in the next two years. And we also have planned a youth employment program which would encompass 600
column14: 000 jobs for young people. This has already passed the House
column15: and it has an excellent prospect to pass the Senate.

column2: I think this idea that has been spawned here in our country that inflation somehow came upon us like a plague and therefore it's uncontrollable and no one can do anything about it
column3: is entirely spurious and it's dangerous to say this to the people. When Mr. Carter became President
column4: inflation was 4.8%
column5: as you said. It had been cut in two by President Gerald Ford. It is now running at 12.7%. President Carter also has spoken of the new jobs created. Well
column6: we always
column7: with the normal growth in our country and increase in population
column8: increase the number of jobs. But that can't hide the fact that there are eight million men and women out of work in America today
column9: and two million of those lost their jobs in just the last few months. Mr. Carter had also promised that he would not use unemployment as a tool to fight against inflation. And yet
column10: his 1980 economic message stated that we would reduce productivity and gross national product and increase unemployment in order to get a handle on inflation
column11: because in January
column12: at the beginning of the year
column13: it was more than 18%. Since then
column14: he has blamed the people for inflation
column15: OPEC
column16: he has blamed the Federal Reserve system
column17: he has blamed the lack of productivity of the American people
column18: he has then accused the people of living too well and that we must share in scarcity
column19: we must sacrifice and get used to doing with less. We don't have inflation because the people are living too well. We have inflation because the Government is living too well. And the last statement
column20: just a few days ago
column21: was a speech to the effect that we have inflation because Government revenues have not kept pace with Government spending. I see my time is running out here. I'll have to get this out very fast. Yes
column22: you can lick inflation by increasing productivity and by decreasing the cost of government to the place that we have balanced budgets
column23: and are no longer grinding out printing press money
column24: flooding the market with it because the Government is spending more than it takes in. And my economic plan calls for that. The President's economic plan calls for increasing the taxes to the point that we finally take so much money away from the people that we can balance the budget in that way. But we will have a very poor nation and a very unsound economy if we follow that path.

column2: when they think about cutting Government spending
column3: they think in terms of eliminating necessary programs or wiping out something
column4: some service that Government is supposed to perform. I believe that there is enough extravagance and fat in government. As a matter of fact
column5: one of the secretaries of HEW under Mr. Carter testified that he thought there was $7 billion worth of fraud and waste in welfare and in the medical programs associated with it. We've had the Central Accounting. Office estimate that there is probably tens of billions of dollars that is lost in fraud alone
column6: and they have added that waste adds even more to that. We have a program for a gradual reduction of Government spending based on these theories
column7: and I have a task force now that has been working on where those cuts could be made. I'm confident that it can be done and that it will reduce inflation because I did it in California. And inflation went down below the national average in California when we returned the money to the people and reduced Government spending.

column2: the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal
column3: is one of the most highly inflationary ideas that ever has been presented to the American public. He would actually have to cut Government spending by at least $130 billion in order to balance the budget under this ridiculous proposal. I notice that his task force that is working for his future plans had some of their ideas revealed in The Wall Street Journal this week. One of those ideas was to repeal the minimum wage
column4: and several times this year
column5: Governor Reagan has said that the major cause of unemployment is the minimum wage. This is a heartless kind of approach to the working families of our country
column6: which is typical of many Republican leaders of the past
column7: but
column8: I think
column9: has been accentuated under Governor Reagan. In California - I'm surprised Governor Reagan brought this up - he had the three largest tax increases in the history of that state under his administration. He more than doubled state spending while he was Governor - 122% increase - and had between a 20% and 30% increase in the number of employees

column2: sir.

column1: Yes. The figures that the President has just used about California is a distortion of the situation there
column2: because while I was Governor of California
column3: our spending in California increased less per capita than the spending in Georgia while Mr. Carter was Governor of Georgia in the same four years. The size of government increased only one-sixth in California of what it increased in proportion to the population in Georgia. And the idea that my tax-cut proposal is inflationary: I would like to ask the President why is it inflationary to let the people keep more of their money and spend it the way that they like
column4: and it isn't inflationary to let him take that money and spend it the way he wants?

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 2)	" Again it's important to put the situation in perspective. In 1974
column4: we had a so-called oil shock
column5: wherein the price of OPEC oil was raised to an extraordinary degree. We had an even worse oil shock in 1979. In 1974
column6: we had the worst recession
column7: the deepest and most penetrating recession since the Second World War. The recession that resulted this time was the briefest since the Second World War. In addition
column8: we've brought down inflation. Earlier this year
column9: in the first quarter
column10: we did have a very severe inflation pressure brought about by the OPEC price increase. It averaged about 18% in the first quarter of this year. In the second quarter
column11: we had dropped it down to about 13%. The most recent figures
column12: the last three months
column13: on the third quarter of this year
column14: the inflation rate is 7% - still too high
column15: but it illustrates very vividly that in addition to providing an enormous number of jobs - nine million new jobs in the last three and a half years - that the inflationary threat is still urgent on us. I notice that Governor Reagan recently mentioned the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal. which his own running mate
column16: George Bush
column17: described as voodoo economics
column18: and said that it would result in a 30% inflation rate. And Business Week
column19: which is not a Democratic publication
column20: said that this Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal - and I quote them
column21: I think - was completely irresponsible and would result in inflationary pressures which would destroy this nation. So our proposals are very sound and very carefully considered to stimulate jobs
column22: to improve the industrial complex of this country
column23: to create tools for American workers
column24: and at the same time would be anti-inflationary in nature. So to add nine million new jobs
column26: and to plan for the future with an energy policy now intact as a foundation is our plan for the years ahead.

column1: Yes. We have demanded that the American people sacrifice
column2: and they have done very well. As a matter of fact
column3: we're importing today about one-third less oil from overseas than we did just a year ago. We've had a 25% reduction since the first year I was in office. At the same time
column4: as I have said earlier
column5: we have added about nine million net new jobs in that period of time - a record never before achieved. Also
column6: the new energy policy has been predicated on two factors: One is conservation
column7: which requires sacrifice
column8: and the other one
column9: increase in production of American energy
column10: which is going along very well - more coal this year than ever before in American history
column11: more oil and gas wells drilled this year than ever before in history. The new economic revitalization program that we have in mind
column12: which will be implemented next year
column13: would result in tax credits which would let business invest in new tools and new factories to create even more new jobs - about one million in the next two years. And we also have planned a youth employment program which would encompass 600
column14: 000 jobs for young people. This has already passed the House
column15: and it has an excellent prospect to pass the Senate.

column2: I think this idea that has been spawned here in our country that inflation somehow came upon us like a plague and therefore it's uncontrollable and no one can do anything about it
column3: is entirely spurious and it's dangerous to say this to the people. When Mr. Carter became President
column4: inflation was 4.8%
column5: as you said. It had been cut in two by President Gerald Ford. It is now running at 12.7%. President Carter also has spoken of the new jobs created. Well
column6: we always
column7: with the normal growth in our country and increase in population
column8: increase the number of jobs. But that can't hide the fact that there are eight million men and women out of work in America today
column9: and two million of those lost their jobs in just the last few months. Mr. Carter had also promised that he would not use unemployment as a tool to fight against inflation. And yet
column10: his 1980 economic message stated that we would reduce productivity and gross national product and increase unemployment in order to get a handle on inflation
column11: because in January
column12: at the beginning of the year
column13: it was more than 18%. Since then
column14: he has blamed the people for inflation
column15: OPEC
column16: he has blamed the Federal Reserve system
column17: he has blamed the lack of productivity of the American people
column18: he has then accused the people of living too well and that we must share in scarcity
column19: we must sacrifice and get used to doing with less. We don't have inflation because the people are living too well. We have inflation because the Government is living too well. And the last statement
column20: just a few days ago
column21: was a speech to the effect that we have inflation because Government revenues have not kept pace with Government spending. I see my time is running out here. I'll have to get this out very fast. Yes
column22: you can lick inflation by increasing productivity and by decreasing the cost of government to the place that we have balanced budgets
column23: and are no longer grinding out printing press money
column24: flooding the market with it because the Government is spending more than it takes in. And my economic plan calls for that. The President's economic plan calls for increasing the taxes to the point that we finally take so much money away from the people that we can balance the budget in that way. But we will have a very poor nation and a very unsound economy if we follow that path.

column2: when they think about cutting Government spending
column3: they think in terms of eliminating necessary programs or wiping out something
column4: some service that Government is supposed to perform. I believe that there is enough extravagance and fat in government. As a matter of fact
column5: one of the secretaries of HEW under Mr. Carter testified that he thought there was $7 billion worth of fraud and waste in welfare and in the medical programs associated with it. We've had the Central Accounting. Office estimate that there is probably tens of billions of dollars that is lost in fraud alone
column6: and they have added that waste adds even more to that. We have a program for a gradual reduction of Government spending based on these theories
column7: and I have a task force now that has been working on where those cuts could be made. I'm confident that it can be done and that it will reduce inflation because I did it in California. And inflation went down below the national average in California when we returned the money to the people and reduced Government spending.

column2: the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal
column3: is one of the most highly inflationary ideas that ever has been presented to the American public. He would actually have to cut Government spending by at least $130 billion in order to balance the budget under this ridiculous proposal. I notice that his task force that is working for his future plans had some of their ideas revealed in The Wall Street Journal this week. One of those ideas was to repeal the minimum wage
column4: and several times this year
column5: Governor Reagan has said that the major cause of unemployment is the minimum wage. This is a heartless kind of approach to the working families of our country
column6: which is typical of many Republican leaders of the past
column7: but
column8: I think
column9: has been accentuated under Governor Reagan. In California - I'm surprised Governor Reagan brought this up - he had the three largest tax increases in the history of that state under his administration. He more than doubled state spending while he was Governor - 122% increase - and had between a 20% and 30% increase in the number of employees

column2: sir.

column1: Yes. The figures that the President has just used about California is a distortion of the situation there
column2: because while I was Governor of California
column3: our spending in California increased less per capita than the spending in Georgia while Mr. Carter was Governor of Georgia in the same four years. The size of government increased only one-sixth in California of what it increased in proportion to the population in Georgia. And the idea that my tax-cut proposal is inflationary: I would like to ask the President why is it inflationary to let the people keep more of their money and spend it the way that they like
column4: and it isn't inflationary to let him take that money and spend it the way he wants?
