column5: as you said. It had been cut in two by President Gerald Ford. It is now running at 12.7%. President Carter also has spoken of the new jobs created. Well
column6: we always
column7: with the normal growth in our country and increase in population
column8: increase the number of jobs. But that can't hide the fact that there are eight million men and women out of work in America today
column9: and two million of those lost their jobs in just the last few months. Mr. Carter had also promised that he would not use unemployment as a tool to fight against inflation. And yet
column10: his 1980 economic message stated that we would reduce productivity and gross national product and increase unemployment in order to get a handle on inflation
column11: because in January
column12: at the beginning of the year
column13: it was more than 18%. Since then
column14: he has blamed the people for inflation
column15: OPEC
column16: he has blamed the Federal Reserve system
column17: he has blamed the lack of productivity of the American people
column18: he has then accused the people of living too well and that we must share in scarcity
column19: we must sacrifice and get used to doing with less. We don't have inflation because the people are living too well. We have inflation because the Government is living too well. And the last statement
column20: just a few days ago
column21: was a speech to the effect that we have inflation because Government revenues have not kept pace with Government spending. I see my time is running out here. I'll have to get this out very fast. Yes
column22: you can lick inflation by increasing productivity and by decreasing the cost of government to the place that we have balanced budgets
column23: and are no longer grinding out printing press money
column24: flooding the market with it because the Government is spending more than it takes in. And my economic plan calls for that. The President's economic plan calls for increasing the taxes to the point that we finally take so much money away from the people that we can balance the budget in that way. But we will have a very poor nation and a very unsound economy if we follow that path.

column2: when they think about cutting Government spending
column3: they think in terms of eliminating necessary programs or wiping out something
column4: some service that Government is supposed to perform. I believe that there is enough extravagance and fat in government. As a matter of fact
column5: one of the secretaries of HEW under Mr. Carter testified that he thought there was $7 billion worth of fraud and waste in welfare and in the medical programs associated with it. We've had the Central Accounting. Office estimate that there is probably tens of billions of dollars that is lost in fraud alone
column6: and they have added that waste adds even more to that. We have a program for a gradual reduction of Government spending based on these theories
column7: and I have a task force now that has been working on where those cuts could be made. I'm confident that it can be done and that it will reduce inflation because I did it in California. And inflation went down below the national average in California when we returned the money to the people and reduced Government spending.

column2: the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal
column3: is one of the most highly inflationary ideas that ever has been presented to the American public. He would actually have to cut Government spending by at least $130 billion in order to balance the budget under this ridiculous proposal. I notice that his task force that is working for his future plans had some of their ideas revealed in The Wall Street Journal this week. One of those ideas was to repeal the minimum wage
column4: and several times this year
column5: Governor Reagan has said that the major cause of unemployment is the minimum wage. This is a heartless kind of approach to the working families of our country
column6: which is typical of many Republican leaders of the past
column7: but
column8: I think
column9: has been accentuated under Governor Reagan. In California - I'm surprised Governor Reagan brought this up - he had the three largest tax increases in the history of that state under his administration. He more than doubled state spending while he was Governor - 122% increase - and had between a 20% and 30% increase in the number of employees

column1: Yes. The figures that the President has just used about California is a distortion of the situation there
column2: because while I was Governor of California
column3: our spending in California increased less per capita than the spending in Georgia while Mr. Carter was Governor of Georgia in the same four years. The size of government increased only one-sixth in California of what it increased in proportion to the population in Georgia. And the idea that my tax-cut proposal is inflationary: I would like to ask the President why is it inflationary to let the people keep more of their money and spend it the way that they like
column4: and it isn't inflationary to let him take that money and spend it the way he wants?

column3: 2)	" Again it's important to put the situation in perspective. In 1974
column4: we had a so-called oil shock
column5: wherein the price of OPEC oil was raised to an extraordinary degree. We had an even worse oil shock in 1979. In 1974
column6: we had the worst recession
column7: the deepest and most penetrating recession since the Second World War. The recession that resulted this time was the briefest since the Second World War. In addition
column8: we've brought down inflation. Earlier this year
column9: in the first quarter
column10: we did have a very severe inflation pressure brought about by the OPEC price increase. It averaged about 18% in the first quarter of this year. In the second quarter
column11: we had dropped it down to about 13%. The most recent figures
column12: the last three months
column13: on the third quarter of this year
column14: the inflation rate is 7% - still too high
column15: but it illustrates very vividly that in addition to providing an enormous number of jobs - nine million new jobs in the last three and a half years - that the inflationary threat is still urgent on us. I notice that Governor Reagan recently mentioned the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal. which his own running mate
column16: George Bush
column17: described as voodoo economics
column18: and said that it would result in a 30% inflation rate. And Business Week
column19: which is not a Democratic publication
column20: said that this Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal - and I quote them
column21: I think - was completely irresponsible and would result in inflationary pressures which would destroy this nation. So our proposals are very sound and very carefully considered to stimulate jobs
column22: to improve the industrial complex of this country
column23: to create tools for American workers
column24: and at the same time would be anti-inflationary in nature. So to add nine million new jobs
column26: and to plan for the future with an energy policy now intact as a foundation is our plan for the years ahead.

column1: Yes. We have demanded that the American people sacrifice
column2: and they have done very well. As a matter of fact
column3: we're importing today about one-third less oil from overseas than we did just a year ago. We've had a 25% reduction since the first year I was in office. At the same time
column4: as I have said earlier
column5: we have added about nine million net new jobs in that period of time - a record never before achieved. Also
column6: the new energy policy has been predicated on two factors: One is conservation
column7: which requires sacrifice
column8: and the other one
column9: increase in production of American energy
column10: which is going along very well - more coal this year than ever before in American history
column11: more oil and gas wells drilled this year than ever before in history. The new economic revitalization program that we have in mind
column12: which will be implemented next year
column13: would result in tax credits which would let business invest in new tools and new factories to create even more new jobs - about one million in the next two years. And we also have planned a youth employment program which would encompass 600
column14: 000 jobs for young people. This has already passed the House
column15: and it has an excellent prospect to pass the Senate.

column2: I think this idea that has been spawned here in our country that inflation somehow came upon us like a plague and therefore it's uncontrollable and no one can do anything about it
column3: is entirely spurious and it's dangerous to say this to the people. When Mr. Carter became President
column4: inflation was 4.8%
column5: as you said. It had been cut in two by President Gerald Ford. It is now running at 12.7%. President Carter also has spoken of the new jobs created. Well
column6: we always
column7: with the normal growth in our country and increase in population
column8: increase the number of jobs. But that can't hide the fact that there are eight million men and women out of work in America today
column9: and two million of those lost their jobs in just the last few months. Mr. Carter had also promised that he would not use unemployment as a tool to fight against inflation. And yet
column10: his 1980 economic message stated that we would reduce productivity and gross national product and increase unemployment in order to get a handle on inflation
column11: because in January
column12: at the beginning of the year
column13: it was more than 18%. Since then
column14: he has blamed the people for inflation
column15: OPEC
column16: he has blamed the Federal Reserve system
column17: he has blamed the lack of productivity of the American people
column18: he has then accused the people of living too well and that we must share in scarcity
column19: we must sacrifice and get used to doing with less. We don't have inflation because the people are living too well. We have inflation because the Government is living too well. And the last statement
column20: just a few days ago
column21: was a speech to the effect that we have inflation because Government revenues have not kept pace with Government spending. I see my time is running out here. I'll have to get this out very fast. Yes
column22: you can lick inflation by increasing productivity and by decreasing the cost of government to the place that we have balanced budgets
column23: and are no longer grinding out printing press money
column24: flooding the market with it because the Government is spending more than it takes in. And my economic plan calls for that. The President's economic plan calls for increasing the taxes to the point that we finally take so much money away from the people that we can balance the budget in that way. But we will have a very poor nation and a very unsound economy if we follow that path.

column2: when they think about cutting Government spending
column3: they think in terms of eliminating necessary programs or wiping out something
column4: some service that Government is supposed to perform. I believe that there is enough extravagance and fat in government. As a matter of fact
column5: one of the secretaries of HEW under Mr. Carter testified that he thought there was $7 billion worth of fraud and waste in welfare and in the medical programs associated with it. We've had the Central Accounting. Office estimate that there is probably tens of billions of dollars that is lost in fraud alone
column6: and they have added that waste adds even more to that. We have a program for a gradual reduction of Government spending based on these theories
column7: and I have a task force now that has been working on where those cuts could be made. I'm confident that it can be done and that it will reduce inflation because I did it in California. And inflation went down below the national average in California when we returned the money to the people and reduced Government spending.

column2: the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal
column3: is one of the most highly inflationary ideas that ever has been presented to the American public. He would actually have to cut Government spending by at least $130 billion in order to balance the budget under this ridiculous proposal. I notice that his task force that is working for his future plans had some of their ideas revealed in The Wall Street Journal this week. One of those ideas was to repeal the minimum wage
column4: and several times this year
column5: Governor Reagan has said that the major cause of unemployment is the minimum wage. This is a heartless kind of approach to the working families of our country
column6: which is typical of many Republican leaders of the past

column9: has been accentuated under Governor Reagan. column4: we had a so-called oil shock
column5: wherein the price of OPEC oil was raised to an extraordinary degree. We had an even worse oil shock in 1979. In 1974
column6: we had the worst recession
column7: the deepest and most penetrating recession since the Second World War. The recession that resulted this time was the briefest since the Second World War. In addition
column8: we've brought down inflation. Earlier this year
column9: in the first quarter
column10: we did have a very severe inflation pressure brought about by the OPEC price increase. It averaged about 18% in the first quarter of this year. In the second quarter
column11: we had dropped it down to about 13%. The most recent figures
column12: the last three months
column13: on the third quarter of this year
column14: the inflation rate is 7% - still too high
column15: but it illustrates very vividly that in addition to providing an enormous number of jobs - nine million new jobs in the last three and a half years - that the inflationary threat is still urgent on us. I notice that Governor Reagan recently mentioned the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal. which his own running mate
column16: George Bush
column17: described as voodoo economics
column18: and said that it would result in a 30% inflation rate. And Business Week
column19: which is not a Democratic publication
column20: said that this Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal - and I quote them
column21: I think - was completely irresponsible and would result in inflationary pressures which would destroy this nation. So our proposals are very sound and very carefully considered to stimulate jobs
column22: to improve the industrial complex of this country
column23: to create tools for American workers
column24: and at the same time would be anti-inflationary in nature. So to add nine million new jobs

column1: Yes. We have demanded that the American people sacrifice
column2: and they have done very well. As a matter of fact
column3: we're importing today about one-third less oil from overseas than we did just a year ago. We've had a 25% reduction since the first year I was in office. At the same time
column4: as I have said earlier
column5: we have added about nine million net new jobs in that period of time - a record never before achieved. Also
column6: the new energy policy has been predicated on two factors: One is conservation
column7: which requires sacrifice
column8: and the other one
column9: increase in production of American energy
column10: which is going along very well - more coal this year than ever before in American history
column11: more oil and gas wells drilled this year than ever before in history. The new economic revitalization program that we have in mind
column12: which will be implemented next year
column13: would result in tax credits which would let business invest in new tools and new factories to create even more new jobs - about one million in the next two years. And we also have planned a youth employment program which would encompass 600
column14: 000 jobs for young people. This has already passed the House
column15: and it has an excellent prospect to pass the Senate.

column2: I think this idea that has been spawned here in our country that inflation somehow came upon us like a plague and therefore it's uncontrollable and no one can do anything about it
column3: is entirely spurious and it's dangerous to say this to the people. When Mr. Carter became President
column4: inflation was 4.8%
column5: as you said. It had been cut in two by President Gerald Ford. It is now running at 12.7%. President Carter also has spoken of the new jobs created. Well
column6: we always
column7: with the normal growth in our country and increase in population
column8: increase the number of jobs. But that can't hide the fact that there are eight million men and women out of work in America today
column9: and two million of those lost their jobs in just the last few months. Mr. Carter had also promised that he would not use unemployment as a tool to fight against inflation. And yet
column10: his 1980 economic message stated that we would reduce productivity and gross national product and increase unemployment in order to get a handle on inflation
column11: because in January

column18: he has then accused the people of living too well and that we must share in scarcity
column19: we must sacrifice and get used to doing with less. We don't have inflation because the people are living too well. We have inflation because the Government is living too well. And the last statement
column20: just a few days ago
column21: was a speech to the effect that we have inflation because Government revenues have not kept pace with Government spending. I see my time is running out here. I'll have to get this out very fast. Yes
column22: you can lick inflation by increasing productivity and by decreasing the cost of government to the place that we have balanced budgets
column23: and are no longer grinding out printing press money
column24: flooding the market with it because the Government is spending more than it takes in. And my economic plan calls for that. The President's economic plan calls for increasing the taxes to the point that we finally take so much money away from the people that we can balance the budget in that way. But we will have a very poor nation and a very unsound economy if we follow that path.

column2: when they think about cutting Government spending

column6: and they have added that waste adds even more to that. We have a program for a gradual reduction of Government spending based on these theories

column3: 2)	" Again it's important to put the situation in perspective. In 1974
column4: we had a so-called oil shock
column5: wherein the price of OPEC oil was raised to an extraordinary degree. We had an even worse oil shock in 1979. In 1974
column6: we had the worst recession
column7: the deepest and most penetrating recession since the Second World War. The recession that resulted this time was the briefest since the Second World War. In addition
column8: we've brought down inflation. Earlier this year
column9: in the first quarter
column10: we did have a very severe inflation pressure brought about by the OPEC price increase. It averaged about 18% in the first quarter of this year. In the second quarter
column11: we had dropped it down to about 13%. The most recent figures
column12: the last three months
column13: on the third quarter of this year
column14: the inflation rate is 7% - still too high
column15: but it illustrates very vividly that in addition to providing an enormous number of jobs - nine million new jobs in the last three and a half years - that the inflationary threat is still urgent on us. I notice that Governor Reagan recently mentioned the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal. which his own running mate
column16: George Bush
column17: described as voodoo economics
column18: and said that it would result in a 30% inflation rate. And Business Week
column19: which is not a Democratic publication
column20: said that this Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal - and I quote them
column21: I think - was completely irresponsible and would result in inflationary pressures which would destroy this nation. So our proposals are very sound and very carefully considered to stimulate jobs
column22: to improve the industrial complex of this country
column23: to create tools for American workers
column24: and at the same time would be anti-inflationary in nature. So to add nine million new jobs
column26: and to plan for the future with an energy policy now intact as a foundation is our plan for the years ahead.

column1: Yes. We have demanded that the American people sacrifice
column2: and they have done very well. As a matter of fact
column3: we're importing today about one-third less oil from overseas than we did just a year ago. We've had a 25% reduction since the first year I was in office. At the same time
column4: as I have said earlier
column5: we have added about nine million net new jobs in that period of time - a record never before achieved. Also
column6: the new energy policy has been predicated on two factors: One is conservation
column7: which requires sacrifice
column8: and the other one
column9: increase in production of American energy
column10: which is going along very well - more coal this year than ever before in American history
column11: more oil and gas wells drilled this year than ever before in history. The new economic revitalization program that we have in mind
column12: which will be implemented next year
column13: would result in tax credits which would let business invest in new tools and new factories to create even more new jobs - about one million in the next two years. And we also have planned a youth employment program which would encompass 600
column14: 000 jobs for young people. This has already passed the House
column15: and it has an excellent prospect to pass the Senate.

column2: I think this idea that has been spawned here in our country that inflation somehow came upon us like a plague and therefore it's uncontrollable and no one can do anything about it
column3: is entirely spurious and it's dangerous to say this to the people. When Mr. Carter became President
column4: inflation was 4.8%
column5: as you said. It had been cut in two by President Gerald Ford. It is now running at 12.7%. President Carter also has spoken of the new jobs created. Well
column6: we always
column7: with the normal growth in our country and increase in population
column8: increase the number of jobs. But that can't hide the fact that there are eight million men and women out of work in America today
column9: and two million of those lost their jobs in just the last few months. Mr. Carter had also promised that he would not use unemployment as a tool to fight against inflation. And yet
column10: his 1980 economic message stated that we would reduce productivity and gross national product and increase unemployment in order to get a handle on inflation
column11: because in January
column12: at the beginning of the year
column13: it was more than 18%. Since then
column14: he has blamed the people for inflation
column15: OPEC
column16: he has blamed the Federal Reserve system
column17: he has blamed the lack of productivity of the American people
column18: he has then accused the people of living too well and that we must share in scarcity
column19: we must sacrifice and get used to doing with less. We don't have inflation because the people are living too well. We have inflation because the Government is living too well. And the last statement
column20: just a few days ago
column21: was a speech to the effect that we have inflation because Government revenues have not kept pace with Government spending. I see my time is running out here. I'll have to get this out very fast. Yes
column22: you can lick inflation by increasing productivity and by decreasing the cost of government to the place that we have balanced budgets
column23: and are no longer grinding out printing press money
column24: flooding the market with it because the Government is spending more than it takes in. And my economic plan calls for that. The President's economic plan calls for increasing the taxes to the point that we finally take so much money away from the people that we can balance the budget in that way. But we will have a very poor nation and a very unsound economy if we follow that path.

column2: when they think about cutting Government spending
column3: they think in terms of eliminating necessary programs or wiping out something
column4: some service that Government is supposed to perform. I believe that there is enough extravagance and fat in government. As a matter of fact
column5: one of the secretaries of HEW under Mr. Carter testified that he thought there was $7 billion worth of fraud and waste in welfare and in the medical programs associated with it. We've had the Central Accounting. Office estimate that there is probably tens of billions of dollars that is lost in fraud alone
column6: and they have added that waste adds even more to that. We have a program for a gradual reduction of Government spending based on these theories
column7: and I have a task force now that has been working on where those cuts could be made. I'm confident that it can be done and that it will reduce inflation because I did it in California. And inflation went down below the national average in California when we returned the money to the people and reduced Government spending.

column2: the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal
column3: is one of the most highly inflationary ideas that ever has been presented to the American public. He would actually have to cut Government spending by at least $130 billion in order to balance the budget under this ridiculous proposal. I notice that his task force that is working for his future plans had some of their ideas revealed in The Wall Street Journal this week. One of those ideas was to repeal the minimum wage
column4: and several times this year
column5: Governor Reagan has said that the major cause of unemployment is the minimum wage. This is a heartless kind of approach to the working families of our country
column6: which is typical of many Republican leaders of the past
column7: but
column8: I think
column9: has been accentuated under Governor Reagan. In California - I'm surprised Governor Reagan brought this up - he had the three largest tax increases in the history of that state under his administration. He more than doubled state spending while he was Governor - 122% increase - and had between a 20% and 30% increase in the number of employees

column2: sir.

column1: Yes. The figures that the President has just used about California is a distortion of the situation there
column2: because while I was Governor of California
column3: our spending in California increased less per capita than the spending in Georgia while Mr. Carter was Governor of Georgia in the same four years. The size of government increased only one-sixth in California of what it increased in proportion to the population in Georgia. And the idea that my tax-cut proposal is inflationary: I would like to ask the President why is it inflationary to let the people keep more of their money and spend it the way that they like
column4: and it isn't inflationary to let him take that money and spend it the way he wants?

column3: 2)	" Again it's important to put the situation in perspective. In 1974
column4: we had a so-called oil shock
column5: wherein the price of OPEC oil was raised to an extraordinary degree. We had an even worse oil shock in 1979. In 1974
column6: we had the worst recession
column7: the deepest and most penetrating recession since the Second World War. The recession that resulted this time was the briefest since the Second World War. In addition
column8: we've brought down inflation. Earlier this year
column9: in the first quarter
column10: we did have a very severe inflation pressure brought about by the OPEC price increase. It averaged about 18% in the first quarter of this year. In the second quarter
column11: we had dropped it down to about 13%. The most recent figures
column12: the last three months
column13: on the third quarter of this year
column14: the inflation rate is 7% - still too high
column15: but it illustrates very vividly that in addition to providing an enormous number of jobs - nine million new jobs in the last three and a half years - that the inflationary threat is still urgent on us. I notice that Governor Reagan recently mentioned the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal. which his own running mate
column16: George Bush
column17: described as voodoo economics
column18: and said that it would result in a 30% inflation rate. And Business Week
column19: which is not a Democratic publication
column20: said that this Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal - and I quote them
column21: I think - was completely irresponsible and would result in inflationary pressures which would destroy this nation. So our proposals are very sound and very carefully considered to stimulate jobs
column22: to improve the industrial complex of this country
column23: to create tools for American workers
column24: and at the same time would be anti-inflationary in nature. So to add nine million new jobs
column26: and to plan for the future with an energy policy now intact as a foundation is our plan for the years ahead.

column1: Yes. We have demanded that the American people sacrifice
column2: and they have done very well. As a matter of fact
column3: we're importing today about one-third less oil from overseas than we did just a year ago. We've had a 25% reduction since the first year I was in office. At the same time
column4: as I have said earlier
column5: we have added about nine million net new jobs in that period of time - a record never before achieved. Also
column6: the new energy policy has been predicated on two factors: One is conservation
column7: which requires sacrifice
column8: and the other one
column9: increase in production of American energy
column10: which is going along very well - more coal this year than ever before in American history
column11: more oil and gas wells drilled this year than ever before in history. The new economic revitalization program that we have in mind
column12: which will be implemented next year
column13: would result in tax credits which would let business invest in new tools and new factories to create even more new jobs - about one million in the next two years. And we also have planned a youth employment program which would encompass 600
column14: 000 jobs for young people. This has already passed the House
column15: and it has an excellent prospect to pass the Senate.

column2: I think this idea that has been spawned here in our country that inflation somehow came upon us like a plague and therefore it's uncontrollable and no one can do anything about it
column3: is entirely spurious and it's dangerous to say this to the people. When Mr. Carter became President
column4: inflation was 4.8%
column5: as you said. It had been cut in two by President Gerald Ford. It is now running at 12.7%. President Carter also has spoken of the new jobs created. Well
column6: we always
column7: with the normal growth in our country and increase in population
column8: increase the number of jobs. But that can't hide the fact that there are eight million men and women out of work in America today
column9: and two million of those lost their jobs in just the last few months. Mr. Carter had also promised that he would not use unemployment as a tool to fight against inflation. And yet
column10: his 1980 economic message stated that we would reduce productivity and gross national product and increase unemployment in order to get a handle on inflation
column11: because in January
column12: at the beginning of the year
column13: it was more than 18%. Since then
column14: he has blamed the people for inflation
column15: OPEC
column16: he has blamed the Federal Reserve system
column17: he has blamed the lack of productivity of the American people
column18: he has then accused the people of living too well and that we must share in scarcity
column19: we must sacrifice and get used to doing with less. We don't have inflation because the people are living too well. We have inflation because the Government is living too well. And the last statement
column20: just a few days ago
column21: was a speech to the effect that we have inflation because Government revenues have not kept pace with Government spending. I see my time is running out here. I'll have to get this out very fast. Yes
column22: you can lick inflation by increasing productivity and by decreasing the cost of government to the place that we have balanced budgets
column23: and are no longer grinding out printing press money
column24: flooding the market with it because the Government is spending more than it takes in. And my economic plan calls for that. The President's economic plan calls for increasing the taxes to the point that we finally take so much money away from the people that we can balance the budget in that way. But we will have a very poor nation and a very unsound economy if we follow that path.

column2: when they think about cutting Government spending
column3: they think in terms of eliminating necessary programs or wiping out something
column4: some service that Government is supposed to perform. I believe that there is enough extravagance and fat in government. As a matter of fact
column5: one of the secretaries of HEW under Mr. Carter testified that he thought there was $7 billion worth of fraud and waste in welfare and in the medical programs associated with it. We've had the Central Accounting. Office estimate that there is probably tens of billions of dollars that is lost in fraud alone
column6: and they have added that waste adds even more to that. We have a program for a gradual reduction of Government spending based on these theories
column7: and I have a task force now that has been working on where those cuts could be made. I'm confident that it can be done and that it will reduce inflation because I did it in California. And inflation went down below the national average in California when we returned the money to the people and reduced Government spending.

column2: the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal
column3: is one of the most highly inflationary ideas that ever has been presented to the American public. He would actually have to cut Government spending by at least $130 billion in order to balance the budget under this ridiculous proposal. I notice that his task force that is working for his future plans had some of their ideas revealed in The Wall Street Journal this week. One of those ideas was to repeal the minimum wage
column4: and several times this year
column5: Governor Reagan has said that the major cause of unemployment is the minimum wage. This is a heartless kind of approach to the working families of our country
column6: which is typical of many Republican leaders of the past
column7: but
column8: I think
column9: has been accentuated under Governor Reagan. In California - I'm surprised Governor Reagan brought this up - he had the three largest tax increases in the history of that state under his administration. He more than doubled state spending while he was Governor - 122% increase - and had between a 20% and 30% increase in the number of employees

column2: sir.

column1: Yes. The figures that the President has just used about California is a distortion of the situation there
column2: because while I was Governor of California
column3: our spending in California increased less per capita than the spending in Georgia while Mr. Carter was Governor of Georgia in the same four years. The size of government increased only one-sixth in California of what it increased in proportion to the population in Georgia. And the idea that my tax-cut proposal is inflationary: I would like to ask the President why is it inflationary to let the people keep more of their money and spend it the way that they like
column4: and it isn't inflationary to let him take that money and spend it the way he wants?

column3: 3)	" I have been talking to a number of Congressmen who have much the same idea that I have
column4: and that is that in the inner city areas
column5: that in cooperation with the local government and the national Government
column6: and using tax incentives and with cooperating with the private sector
column7: that we have development zones. Let the local entity
column8: the city
column9: declare this particular area
column10: based on the standards of the percentage of people on welfare
column11: unemployed
column12: and so forth
column13: in that area. And then
column14: through tax incentives
column15: induce the creation of businesses providing jobs and so forth in those areas. The elements of government through these tax incentives For example
column16: a business that would not have
column17: for a period of time
column18: an increase in the property tax reflecting its development of the unused property that it was making wouldn't be any loss to the city because the city isn't getting any tax from that now. And there would simply be a delay
column19: and on the other hand
column20: many of the people who would then be given jobs are presently wards of the Government and it wouldn't hurt to give them a tax incentive
column21: because they... that wouldn't be costing Government anything either. I think there are things to do in this regard. I stood in the South Bronx on the exact spot that President Carter stood on in 1977. You have to see it to believe it. It looks like a bombed-out city - great
column22: gaunt skeletons of buildings. Windows smashed out
column23: painted on one of them ""Unkept promises;"" on another
column24: ""Despair."" And this was the spot at which President Carter had promised that he was going to bring in a vast program to rebuild this department. There are whole or this area there are whole blocks of land that are left bare
column25: just bulldozed down flat. And nothing has been done
column26: and they are now charging to take tourists there to see this terrible desolation. I talked to a man just briefly there who asked me one simple question: ""Do I have reason to hope that I can someday take care of my family again? Nothing has been done.""

column1: I believe in it. I am eternally optimistic
column2: and I happen to believe that we've made great progress from the days when I was young and when this country didn't even know it had a racial problem. I know those things can grow out of despair in an inner city
column3: when there's hopelessness at home
column4: lack of work
column5: and so forth. But I believe that all of us together
column6: and I believe the Presidency is what Teddy Roosevelt said it was. It's a bully pulpit. And I think that something can be done from there
column7: because a goal for all of us should be that one day
column8: things will be done neither because of nor in spite of any of the differences between us - ethnic differences or racial differences
column9: whatever they may be - that we will have total equal opportunity for all people. And I would do everything I could in my power to bring that about.

column2: Mr. Hilliard. When I was campaigning in 1976
column3: everywhere I went
column4: the mayors and local officials were in despair about the rapidly deteriorating central cities of our nation. We initiated a very fine urban renewal program
column5: working with the mayors
column6: the governors
column7: and other interested officials. This has been a very successful effort. That's one of the main reasons that we've had such an increase in the number of people employed. Of the nine million people put to work in new jobs since I've been in office
column8: 1.3 million of those has been among black Americans
column9: and another million among those who speak Spanish. We now are planning to continue the revitalization program with increased commitments of rapid transit
column10: mass transit. Under the windfall profits tax
column11: we expect to spend about $43 billion in the next 10 years to rebuild the transportation systems of our country. We also are pursuing housing programs. We've had a 73% increase in the allotment of Federal funds for improved education. These are the kinds of efforts worked on a joint basis with community leaders
column12: particularly in the minority areas of the central cities that have been deteriorating so rapidly in the past. It's very important to us that this be done with the full involvement of minority citizens. I have brought into the top level
column13: top levels of government
column14: into the White House
column15: into administrative offices of the Executive branch
column16: into the judicial system
column17: highly qualified black and Spanish citizens and women who in the past had been excluded. I noticed that Governor Reagan said that when he was a young man that there was no knowledge of a racial problem in this country. Those who suffered from discrimination because of race or sex certainly knew we had a racial problem. We have gone a long way toward correcting these problems
column18: but we still have a long way to go.

column1: Ours is a nation of refugees
column2: a nation of immigrants. Almost all of our citizens came here from other lands and now have hopes
column3: which are being realized
column4: for a better life
column5: preserving their ethnic commitments
column6: their family structures
column7: their religious beliefs
column8: preserving their relationships with their relatives in foreign countries
column9: but still holding themselves together in a very coherent society
column10: which gives our nation its strength. In the past
column11: those minority groups have often been excluded from participation in the affairs of government. Since I've been President
column12: I've appointed
column13: for instance
column14: more than twice as many black Federal judges as all previous presidents in the history of this country. I've done the same thing in the appointment of women
column15: and also Spanish-speaking Americans. To involve them in the administration of government and the feeling that they belong to the societal structure that makes decisions in the judiciary and in the executive branch is a very important commitment which I am trying to realize and will continue to do so in the future.

column1: Yes. The President talks of Government programs
column2: and they have their place. But as governor
column3: when I was at that end of the line and receiving some of these grants for Government programs
column4: I saw that so many of them were dead-end. They were public employment that these people who really want to get out into the private job market where there are jobs with a future. Now
column5: the President spoke a moment ago about that I was against the minimum wage. I wish he could have been with me when I sat with a group of teenagers who were black
column6: and who were telling me about their unemployment problems
column7: and that it was the minimum wage that had done away with the jobs that they once could get. And indeed
column8: every time it has increased you will find there is an increase in minority unemployment among young people. And therefore
column9: I have been in favor of a separate minimum for them. With regard to the great progress that has been made with this Government spending
column10: the rate of black unemployment in Detroit
column11: Michigan

column1: It's obvious that we still have a long way to go in fully incorporating the minority groups into the mainstream of American life. We have made good progress
column2: and there is no doubt in my mind that the commitment to unemployment compensation
column3: the minimum wage
column4: welfare
column5: national health insurance
column6: those kinds of commitments that have typified the Democratic party since ancient history in this country's political life are a very important element of the future. In all those elements
column7: Governor Reagan has repeatedly spoken out against them
column8: which
column9: to me
column10: shows a very great insensitivity to giving deprived families a better chance in life. This
column11: to me
column12: is a very important difference between him and me in this election
column13: and I believe the American people will judge accordingly. There is no doubt in my mind that in the downtown central cities
column14: with the
column15: with the new commitment on an energy policy
column16: with a chance to revitalize homes and to make them more fuel efficient
column17: with a chance for our synthetic fuels program
column18: solar power
column19: this will give us an additional opportunity for jobs which will pay rich dividends.

column5: that in cooperation with the local government and the national Government
column6: and using tax incentives and with cooperating with the private sector
column7: that we have development zones. Let the local entity
column8: the city
column9: declare this particular area
column10: based on the standards of the percentage of people on welfare
column11: unemployed
column12: and so forth
column13: in that area. And then
column14: through tax incentives
column15: induce the creation of businesses providing jobs and so forth in those areas. The elements of government through these tax incentives For example
column16: a business that would not have
column17: for a period of time
column18: an increase in the property tax reflecting its development of the unused property that it was making wouldn't be any loss to the city because the city isn't getting any tax from that now. And there would simply be a delay
column19: and on the other hand
column20: many of the people who would then be given jobs are presently wards of the Government and it wouldn't hurt to give them a tax incentive
column21: because they... that wouldn't be costing Government anything either. I think there are things to do in this regard. I stood in the South Bronx on the exact spot that President Carter stood on in 1977. You have to see it to believe it. It looks like a bombed-out city - great
column22: gaunt skeletons of buildings. Windows smashed out
column23: painted on one of them ""Unkept promises;"" on another

column1: I believe in it. I am eternally optimistic
column2: and I happen to believe that we've made great progress from the days when I was young and when this country didn't even know it had a racial problem. I know those things can grow out of despair in an inner city
column3: when there's hopelessness at home
column4: lack of work
column5: and so forth. But I believe that all of us together
column6: and I believe the Presidency is what Teddy Roosevelt said it was. It's a bully pulpit. And I think that something can be done from there
column7: because a goal for all of us should be that one day
column8: things will be done neither because of nor in spite of any of the differences between us - ethnic differences or racial differences
column9: whatever they may be - that we will have total equal opportunity for all people. And I would do everything I could in my power to bring that about.

column2: Mr. Hilliard. When I was campaigning in 1976
column3: everywhere I went
column4: the mayors and local officials were in despair about the rapidly deteriorating central cities of our nation. We initiated a very fine urban renewal program
column5: working with the mayors
column6: the governors
column7: and other interested officials. This has been a very successful effort. That's one of the main reasons that we've had such an increase in the number of people employed. Of the nine million people put to work in new jobs since I've been in office
column8: 1.3 million of those has been among black Americans
column9: and another million among those who speak Spanish. We now are planning to continue the revitalization program with increased commitments of rapid transit
column10: mass transit. Under the windfall profits tax
column11: we expect to spend about $43 billion in the next 10 years to rebuild the transportation systems of our country. We also are pursuing housing programs. We've had a 73% increase in the allotment of Federal funds for improved education. These are the kinds of efforts worked on a joint basis with community leaders
column12: particularly in the minority areas of the central cities that have been deteriorating so rapidly in the past. It's very important to us that this be done with the full involvement of minority citizens. I have brought into the top level
column13: top levels of government
column14: into the White House
column15: into administrative offices of the Executive branch
column16: into the judicial system
column17: highly qualified black and Spanish citizens and women who in the past had been excluded. I noticed that Governor Reagan said that when he was a young man that there was no knowledge of a racial problem in this country. Those who suffered from discrimination because of race or sex certainly knew we had a racial problem. We have gone a long way toward correcting these problems
column18: but we still have a long way to go.

column1: Ours is a nation of refugees
column2: a nation of immigrants. Almost all of our citizens came here from other lands and now have hopes
column3: which are being realized
column4: for a better life
column5: preserving their ethnic commitments
column6: their family structures
column7: their religious beliefs
column8: preserving their relationships with their relatives in foreign countries
column9: but still holding themselves together in a very coherent society
column10: which gives our nation its strength. In the past
column11: those minority groups have often been excluded from participation in the affairs of government. Since I've been President
column12: I've appointed
column13: for instance
column14: more than twice as many black Federal judges as all previous presidents in the history of this country. I've done the same thing in the appointment of women
column15: and also Spanish-speaking Americans. To involve them in the administration of government and the feeling that they belong to the societal structure that makes decisions in the judiciary and in the executive branch is a very important commitment which I am trying to realize and will continue to do so in the future.

column1: Yes. The President talks of Government programs
column2: and they have their place. But as governor
column3: when I was at that end of the line and receiving some of these grants for Government programs
column4: I saw that so many of them were dead-end. They were public employment that these people who really want to get out into the private job market where there are jobs with a future. Now
column5: the President spoke a moment ago about that I was against the minimum wage. I wish he could have been with me when I sat with a group of teenagers who were black
column6: and who were telling me about their unemployment problems
column7: and that it was the minimum wage that had done away with the jobs that they once could get. And indeed
column8: every time it has increased you will find there is an increase in minority unemployment among young people. And therefore
column9: I have been in favor of a separate minimum for them. With regard to the great progress that has been made with this Government spending
column10: the rate of black unemployment in Detroit
column11: Michigan

column1: It's obvious that we still have a long way to go in fully incorporating the minority groups into the mainstream of American life. We have made good progress

column3: the minimum wage

column5: national health insurance
column6: those kinds of commitments that have typified the Democratic party since ancient history in this country's political life are a very important element of the future. In all those elements

column8: which
column9: to me
column10: shows a very great insensitivity to giving deprived families a better chance in life. This
column11: to me
column12: is a very important difference between him and me in this election
column13: and I believe the American people will judge accordingly. There is no doubt in my mind that in the downtown central cities
column14: with the
column15: with the new commitment on an energy policy
column16: with a chance to revitalize homes and to make them more fuel efficient
column17: with a chance for our synthetic fuels program
column18: solar power
column19: this will give us an additional opportunity for jobs which will pay rich dividends.

column1: I believe in it. I am eternally optimistic
column2: and I happen to believe that we've made great progress from the days when I was young and when this country didn't even know it had a racial problem. I know those things can grow out of despair in an inner city
column3: when there's hopelessness at home
column4: lack of work
column5: and so forth. But I believe that all of us together
column6: and I believe the Presidency is what Teddy Roosevelt said it was. It's a bully pulpit. And I think that something can be done from there
column7: because a goal for all of us should be that one day
column8: things will be done neither because of nor in spite of any of the differences between us - ethnic differences or racial differences
column9: whatever they may be - that we will have total equal opportunity for all people. And I would do everything I could in my power to bring that about.

column2: Mr. Hilliard. When I was campaigning in 1976
column3: everywhere I went
column4: the mayors and local officials were in despair about the rapidly deteriorating central cities of our nation. We initiated a very fine urban renewal program
column5: working with the mayors
column6: the governors
column7: and other interested officials. This has been a very successful effort. That's one of the main reasons that we've had such an increase in the number of people employed. Of the nine million people put to work in new jobs since I've been in office
column8: 1.3 million of those has been among black Americans
column9: and another million among those who speak Spanish. We now are planning to continue the revitalization program with increased commitments of rapid transit
column10: mass transit. Under the windfall profits tax
column11: we expect to spend about $43 billion in the next 10 years to rebuild the transportation systems of our country. We also are pursuing housing programs. We've had a 73% increase in the allotment of Federal funds for improved education. These are the kinds of efforts worked on a joint basis with community leaders
column12: particularly in the minority areas of the central cities that have been deteriorating so rapidly in the past. It's very important to us that this be done with the full involvement of minority citizens. I have brought into the top level
column13: top levels of government
column14: into the White House
column15: into administrative offices of the Executive branch
column16: into the judicial system
column17: highly qualified black and Spanish citizens and women who in the past had been excluded. I noticed that Governor Reagan said that when he was a young man that there was no knowledge of a racial problem in this country. Those who suffered from discrimination because of race or sex certainly knew we had a racial problem. We have gone a long way toward correcting these problems
column18: but we still have a long way to go.

column1: I believe in it. I am eternally optimistic
column2: and I happen to believe that we've made great progress from the days when I was young and when this country didn't even know it had a racial problem. I know those things can grow out of despair in an inner city
column3: when there's hopelessness at home
column4: lack of work
column5: and so forth. But I believe that all of us together
column6: and I believe the Presidency is what Teddy Roosevelt said it was. It's a bully pulpit. And I think that something can be done from there
column7: because a goal for all of us should be that one day
column8: things will be done neither because of nor in spite of any of the differences between us - ethnic differences or racial differences
column9: whatever they may be - that we will have total equal opportunity for all people. And I would do everything I could in my power to bring that about.

column2: Mr. Hilliard. When I was campaigning in 1976
column3: everywhere I went
column4: the mayors and local officials were in despair about the rapidly deteriorating central cities of our nation. We initiated a very fine urban renewal program
column5: working with the mayors
column6: the governors
column7: and other interested officials. This has been a very successful effort. That's one of the main reasons that we've had such an increase in the number of people employed. Of the nine million people put to work in new jobs since I've been in office
column8: 1.3 million of those has been among black Americans
column9: and another million among those who speak Spanish. We now are planning to continue the revitalization program with increased commitments of rapid transit
column10: mass transit. Under the windfall profits tax
column11: we expect to spend about $43 billion in the next 10 years to rebuild the transportation systems of our country. We also are pursuing housing programs. We've had a 73% increase in the allotment of Federal funds for improved education. These are the kinds of efforts worked on a joint basis with community leaders
column12: particularly in the minority areas of the central cities that have been deteriorating so rapidly in the past. It's very important to us that this be done with the full involvement of minority citizens. I have brought into the top level
column13: top levels of government
column14: into the White House
column15: into administrative offices of the Executive branch
column16: into the judicial system
column17: highly qualified black and Spanish citizens and women who in the past had been excluded. I noticed that Governor Reagan said that when he was a young man that there was no knowledge of a racial problem in this country. Those who suffered from discrimination because of race or sex certainly knew we had a racial problem. We have gone a long way toward correcting these problems
column18: but we still have a long way to go.

column1: Ours is a nation of refugees
column2: a nation of immigrants. Almost all of our citizens came here from other lands and now have hopes
column3: which are being realized
column4: for a better life
column5: preserving their ethnic commitments
column6: their family structures
column7: their religious beliefs
column8: preserving their relationships with their relatives in foreign countries
column9: but still holding themselves together in a very coherent society
column10: which gives our nation its strength. In the past
column11: those minority groups have often been excluded from participation in the affairs of government. Since I've been President
column12: I've appointed
column13: for instance
column14: more than twice as many black Federal judges as all previous presidents in the history of this country. I've done the same thing in the appointment of women
column15: and also Spanish-speaking Americans. To involve them in the administration of government and the feeling that they belong to the societal structure that makes decisions in the judiciary and in the executive branch is a very important commitment which I am trying to realize and will continue to do so in the future.

column1: Yes. The President talks of Government programs
column2: and they have their place. But as governor
column3: when I was at that end of the line and receiving some of these grants for Government programs
column4: I saw that so many of them were dead-end. They were public employment that these people who really want to get out into the private job market where there are jobs with a future. Now
column5: the President spoke a moment ago about that I was against the minimum wage. I wish he could have been with me when I sat with a group of teenagers who were black
column6: and who were telling me about their unemployment problems
column7: and that it was the minimum wage that had done away with the jobs that they once could get. And indeed
column8: every time it has increased you will find there is an increase in minority unemployment among young people. And therefore
column9: I have been in favor of a separate minimum for them. With regard to the great progress that has been made with this Government spending
column10: the rate of black unemployment in Detroit

column5: that in cooperation with the local government and the national Government
column6: and using tax incentives and with cooperating with the private sector
column7: that we have development zones. Let the local entity
column8: the city

column10: based on the standards of the percentage of people on welfare
column11: unemployed
column12: and so forth
column13: in that area. And then

column15: induce the creation of businesses providing jobs and so forth in those areas. The elements of government through these tax incentives For example

column17: for a period of time
column18: an increase in the property tax reflecting its development of the unused property that it was making wouldn't be any loss to the city because the city isn't getting any tax from that now. And there would simply be a delay
column19: and on the other hand

column21: because they... that wouldn't be costing Government anything either. I think there are things to do in this regard. I stood in the South Bronx on the exact spot that President Carter stood on in 1977. You have to see it to believe it. It looks like a bombed-out city - great

column23: painted on one of them ""Unkept promises;"" on another

column1: I believe in it. I am eternally optimistic
column2: and I happen to believe that we've made great progress from the days when I was young and when this country didn't even know it had a racial problem. I know those things can grow out of despair in an inner city
column3: when there's hopelessness at home
column4: lack of work
column5: and so forth. But I believe that all of us together
column6: and I believe the Presidency is what Teddy Roosevelt said it was. It's a bully pulpit. And I think that something can be done from there
column7: because a goal for all of us should be that one day
column8: things will be done neither because of nor in spite of any of the differences between us - ethnic differences or racial differences
column9: whatever they may be - that we will have total equal opportunity for all people. And I would do everything I could in my power to bring that about.

column2: Mr. Hilliard. When I was campaigning in 1976
column3: everywhere I went
column4: the mayors and local officials were in despair about the rapidly deteriorating central cities of our nation. We initiated a very fine urban renewal program
column5: working with the mayors
column6: the governors
column7: and other interested officials. This has been a very successful effort. That's one of the main reasons that we've had such an increase in the number of people employed. Of the nine million people put to work in new jobs since I've been in office
column8: 1.3 million of those has been among black Americans
column9: and another million among those who speak Spanish. We now are planning to continue the revitalization program with increased commitments of rapid transit
column10: mass transit. Under the windfall profits tax
column11: we expect to spend about $43 billion in the next 10 years to rebuild the transportation systems of our country. We also are pursuing housing programs. We've had a 73% increase in the allotment of Federal funds for improved education. These are the kinds of efforts worked on a joint basis with community leaders
column12: particularly in the minority areas of the central cities that have been deteriorating so rapidly in the past. It's very important to us that this be done with the full involvement of minority citizens. I have brought into the top level
column13: top levels of government
column14: into the White House
column15: into administrative offices of the Executive branch
column16: into the judicial system
column17: highly qualified black and Spanish citizens and women who in the past had been excluded. I noticed that Governor Reagan said that when he was a young man that there was no knowledge of a racial problem in this country. Those who suffered from discrimination because of race or sex certainly knew we had a racial problem. We have gone a long way toward correcting these problems
column18: but we still have a long way to go.

column1: Ours is a nation of refugees
column2: a nation of immigrants. Almost all of our citizens came here from other lands and now have hopes
column3: which are being realized
column4: for a better life
column5: preserving their ethnic commitments
column6: their family structures
column7: their religious beliefs
column8: preserving their relationships with their relatives in foreign countries
column9: but still holding themselves together in a very coherent society
column10: which gives our nation its strength. In the past
column11: those minority groups have often been excluded from participation in the affairs of government. Since I've been President
column12: I've appointed
column13: for instance
column14: more than twice as many black Federal judges as all previous presidents in the history of this country. I've done the same thing in the appointment of women
column15: and also Spanish-speaking Americans. To involve them in the administration of government and the feeling that they belong to the societal structure that makes decisions in the judiciary and in the executive branch is a very important commitment which I am trying to realize and will continue to do so in the future.

column1: Yes. The President talks of Government programs

column5: the President spoke a moment ago about that I was against the minimum wage. I wish he could have been with me when I sat with a group of teenagers who were black
column6: and who were telling me about their unemployment problems
column7: and that it was the minimum wage that had done away with the jobs that they once could get. And indeed
column8: every time it has increased you will find there is an increase in minority unemployment among young people. And therefore
column9: I have been in favor of a separate minimum for them. With regard to the great progress that has been made with this Government spending
column10: the rate of black unemployment in Detroit

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 3)	" I have been talking to a number of Congressmen who have much the same idea that I have
column4: and that is that in the inner city areas
column5: that in cooperation with the local government and the national Government
column6: and using tax incentives and with cooperating with the private sector
column7: that we have development zones. Let the local entity
column8: the city
column9: declare this particular area
column10: based on the standards of the percentage of people on welfare
column11: unemployed
column12: and so forth
column13: in that area. And then
column14: through tax incentives
column15: induce the creation of businesses providing jobs and so forth in those areas. The elements of government through these tax incentives For example
column16: a business that would not have
column17: for a period of time
column18: an increase in the property tax reflecting its development of the unused property that it was making wouldn't be any loss to the city because the city isn't getting any tax from that now. And there would simply be a delay
column19: and on the other hand
column20: many of the people who would then be given jobs are presently wards of the Government and it wouldn't hurt to give them a tax incentive
column21: because they... that wouldn't be costing Government anything either. I think there are things to do in this regard. I stood in the South Bronx on the exact spot that President Carter stood on in 1977. You have to see it to believe it. It looks like a bombed-out city - great
column22: gaunt skeletons of buildings. Windows smashed out
column23: painted on one of them ""Unkept promises;"" on another
column24: ""Despair."" And this was the spot at which President Carter had promised that he was going to bring in a vast program to rebuild this department. There are whole or this area there are whole blocks of land that are left bare
column25: just bulldozed down flat. And nothing has been done
column26: and they are now charging to take tourists there to see this terrible desolation. I talked to a man just briefly there who asked me one simple question: ""Do I have reason to hope that I can someday take care of my family again? Nothing has been done.""

column1: I believe in it. I am eternally optimistic
column2: and I happen to believe that we've made great progress from the days when I was young and when this country didn't even know it had a racial problem. I know those things can grow out of despair in an inner city
column3: when there's hopelessness at home
column4: lack of work
column5: and so forth. But I believe that all of us together
column6: and I believe the Presidency is what Teddy Roosevelt said it was. It's a bully pulpit. And I think that something can be done from there
column7: because a goal for all of us should be that one day
column8: things will be done neither because of nor in spite of any of the differences between us - ethnic differences or racial differences
column9: whatever they may be - that we will have total equal opportunity for all people. And I would do everything I could in my power to bring that about.

column2: Mr. Hilliard. When I was campaigning in 1976
column3: everywhere I went
column4: the mayors and local officials were in despair about the rapidly deteriorating central cities of our nation. We initiated a very fine urban renewal program
column5: working with the mayors
column6: the governors
column7: and other interested officials. This has been a very successful effort. That's one of the main reasons that we've had such an increase in the number of people employed. Of the nine million people put to work in new jobs since I've been in office
column8: 1.3 million of those has been among black Americans
column9: and another million among those who speak Spanish. We now are planning to continue the revitalization program with increased commitments of rapid transit
column10: mass transit. Under the windfall profits tax
column11: we expect to spend about $43 billion in the next 10 years to rebuild the transportation systems of our country. We also are pursuing housing programs. We've had a 73% increase in the allotment of Federal funds for improved education. These are the kinds of efforts worked on a joint basis with community leaders
column12: particularly in the minority areas of the central cities that have been deteriorating so rapidly in the past. It's very important to us that this be done with the full involvement of minority citizens. I have brought into the top level
column13: top levels of government
column14: into the White House
column15: into administrative offices of the Executive branch
column16: into the judicial system
column17: highly qualified black and Spanish citizens and women who in the past had been excluded. I noticed that Governor Reagan said that when he was a young man that there was no knowledge of a racial problem in this country. Those who suffered from discrimination because of race or sex certainly knew we had a racial problem. We have gone a long way toward correcting these problems
column18: but we still have a long way to go.

column1: Ours is a nation of refugees
column2: a nation of immigrants. Almost all of our citizens came here from other lands and now have hopes
column3: which are being realized
column4: for a better life
column5: preserving their ethnic commitments
column6: their family structures
column7: their religious beliefs
column8: preserving their relationships with their relatives in foreign countries
column9: but still holding themselves together in a very coherent society
column10: which gives our nation its strength. In the past
column11: those minority groups have often been excluded from participation in the affairs of government. Since I've been President
column12: I've appointed
column13: for instance
column14: more than twice as many black Federal judges as all previous presidents in the history of this country. I've done the same thing in the appointment of women
column15: and also Spanish-speaking Americans. To involve them in the administration of government and the feeling that they belong to the societal structure that makes decisions in the judiciary and in the executive branch is a very important commitment which I am trying to realize and will continue to do so in the future.

column1: Yes. The President talks of Government programs
column2: and they have their place. But as governor
column3: when I was at that end of the line and receiving some of these grants for Government programs
column4: I saw that so many of them were dead-end. They were public employment that these people who really want to get out into the private job market where there are jobs with a future. Now
column5: the President spoke a moment ago about that I was against the minimum wage. I wish he could have been with me when I sat with a group of teenagers who were black
column6: and who were telling me about their unemployment problems
column7: and that it was the minimum wage that had done away with the jobs that they once could get. And indeed
column8: every time it has increased you will find there is an increase in minority unemployment among young people. And therefore
column9: I have been in favor of a separate minimum for them. With regard to the great progress that has been made with this Government spending
column10: the rate of black unemployment in Detroit
column11: Michigan

column1: It's obvious that we still have a long way to go in fully incorporating the minority groups into the mainstream of American life. We have made good progress
column2: and there is no doubt in my mind that the commitment to unemployment compensation
column3: the minimum wage
column4: welfare
column5: national health insurance
column6: those kinds of commitments that have typified the Democratic party since ancient history in this country's political life are a very important element of the future. In all those elements
column7: Governor Reagan has repeatedly spoken out against them
column8: which
column9: to me
column10: shows a very great insensitivity to giving deprived families a better chance in life. This
column11: to me
column12: is a very important difference between him and me in this election
column13: and I believe the American people will judge accordingly. There is no doubt in my mind that in the downtown central cities
column14: with the
column15: with the new commitment on an energy policy
column16: with a chance to revitalize homes and to make them more fuel efficient
column17: with a chance for our synthetic fuels program
column18: solar power
column19: this will give us an additional opportunity for jobs which will pay rich dividends.
