column23: painted on one of them ""Unkept promises;"" on another
column24: ""Despair."" And this was the spot at which President Carter had promised that he was going to bring in a vast program to rebuild this department. There are whole or this area there are whole blocks of land that are left bare
column25: just bulldozed down flat. And nothing has been done
column26: and they are now charging to take tourists there to see this terrible desolation. I talked to a man just briefly there who asked me one simple question: ""Do I have reason to hope that I can someday take care of my family again? Nothing has been done.""

column1: I believe in it. I am eternally optimistic
column2: and I happen to believe that we've made great progress from the days when I was young and when this country didn't even know it had a racial problem. I know those things can grow out of despair in an inner city
column3: when there's hopelessness at home
column4: lack of work
column5: and so forth. But I believe that all of us together
column6: and I believe the Presidency is what Teddy Roosevelt said it was. It's a bully pulpit. And I think that something can be done from there
column7: because a goal for all of us should be that one day
column8: things will be done neither because of nor in spite of any of the differences between us - ethnic differences or racial differences
column9: whatever they may be - that we will have total equal opportunity for all people. And I would do everything I could in my power to bring that about.

column2: Mr. Hilliard. When I was campaigning in 1976
column3: everywhere I went
column4: the mayors and local officials were in despair about the rapidly deteriorating central cities of our nation. We initiated a very fine urban renewal program
column5: working with the mayors
column6: the governors
column7: and other interested officials. This has been a very successful effort. That's one of the main reasons that we've had such an increase in the number of people employed. Of the nine million people put to work in new jobs since I've been in office
column8: 1.3 million of those has been among black Americans
column9: and another million among those who speak Spanish. We now are planning to continue the revitalization program with increased commitments of rapid transit
column10: mass transit. Under the windfall profits tax
column11: we expect to spend about $43 billion in the next 10 years to rebuild the transportation systems of our country. We also are pursuing housing programs. We've had a 73% increase in the allotment of Federal funds for improved education. These are the kinds of efforts worked on a joint basis with community leaders
column12: particularly in the minority areas of the central cities that have been deteriorating so rapidly in the past. It's very important to us that this be done with the full involvement of minority citizens. I have brought into the top level
column13: top levels of government
column14: into the White House
column15: into administrative offices of the Executive branch
column16: into the judicial system
column17: highly qualified black and Spanish citizens and women who in the past had been excluded. I noticed that Governor Reagan said that when he was a young man that there was no knowledge of a racial problem in this country. Those who suffered from discrimination because of race or sex certainly knew we had a racial problem. We have gone a long way toward correcting these problems
column18: but we still have a long way to go.

column1: Ours is a nation of refugees
column2: a nation of immigrants. Almost all of our citizens came here from other lands and now have hopes
column3: which are being realized
column4: for a better life
column5: preserving their ethnic commitments
column6: their family structures
column7: their religious beliefs
column8: preserving their relationships with their relatives in foreign countries
column9: but still holding themselves together in a very coherent society
column10: which gives our nation its strength. In the past
column11: those minority groups have often been excluded from participation in the affairs of government. Since I've been President
column12: I've appointed
column13: for instance
column14: more than twice as many black Federal judges as all previous presidents in the history of this country. I've done the same thing in the appointment of women
column15: and also Spanish-speaking Americans. To involve them in the administration of government and the feeling that they belong to the societal structure that makes decisions in the judiciary and in the executive branch is a very important commitment which I am trying to realize and will continue to do so in the future.

column1: Yes. The President talks of Government programs
column2: and they have their place. But as governor
column3: when I was at that end of the line and receiving some of these grants for Government programs
column4: I saw that so many of them were dead-end. They were public employment that these people who really want to get out into the private job market where there are jobs with a future. Now
column5: the President spoke a moment ago about that I was against the minimum wage. I wish he could have been with me when I sat with a group of teenagers who were black
column6: and who were telling me about their unemployment problems
column7: and that it was the minimum wage that had done away with the jobs that they once could get. And indeed
column8: every time it has increased you will find there is an increase in minority unemployment among young people. And therefore
column9: I have been in favor of a separate minimum for them. With regard to the great progress that has been made with this Government spending
column10: the rate of black unemployment in Detroit
column11: Michigan

column5: national health insurance
column6: those kinds of commitments that have typified the Democratic party since ancient history in this country's political life are a very important element of the future. In all those elements

column8: which
column9: to me

column11: to me

column13: and I believe the American people will judge accordingly. There is no doubt in my mind that in the downtown central cities
column14: with the
column15: with the new commitment on an energy policy
column16: with a chance to revitalize homes and to make them more fuel efficient
column17: with a chance for our synthetic fuels program
column18: solar power
column19: this will give us an additional opportunity for jobs which will pay rich dividends.

column1: I believe in it. I am eternally optimistic
column2: and I happen to believe that we've made great progress from the days when I was young and when this country didn't even know it had a racial problem. I know those things can grow out of despair in an inner city
column3: when there's hopelessness at home
column4: lack of work
column5: and so forth. But I believe that all of us together
column6: and I believe the Presidency is what Teddy Roosevelt said it was. It's a bully pulpit. And I think that something can be done from there
column7: because a goal for all of us should be that one day
column8: things will be done neither because of nor in spite of any of the differences between us - ethnic differences or racial differences
column9: whatever they may be - that we will have total equal opportunity for all people. And I would do everything I could in my power to bring that about.

column2: Mr. Hilliard. When I was campaigning in 1976
column3: everywhere I went
column4: the mayors and local officials were in despair about the rapidly deteriorating central cities of our nation. We initiated a very fine urban renewal program
column5: working with the mayors
column6: the governors
column7: and other interested officials. This has been a very successful effort. That's one of the main reasons that we've had such an increase in the number of people employed. Of the nine million people put to work in new jobs since I've been in office
column8: 1.3 million of those has been among black Americans
column9: and another million among those who speak Spanish. We now are planning to continue the revitalization program with increased commitments of rapid transit
column10: mass transit. Under the windfall profits tax
column11: we expect to spend about $43 billion in the next 10 years to rebuild the transportation systems of our country. We also are pursuing housing programs. We've had a 73% increase in the allotment of Federal funds for improved education. These are the kinds of efforts worked on a joint basis with community leaders
column12: particularly in the minority areas of the central cities that have been deteriorating so rapidly in the past. It's very important to us that this be done with the full involvement of minority citizens. I have brought into the top level

column14: into the White House
column15: into administrative offices of the Executive branch
column16: into the judicial system
column17: highly qualified black and Spanish citizens and women who in the past had been excluded. I noticed that Governor Reagan said that when he was a young man that there was no knowledge of a racial problem in this country. Those who suffered from discrimination because of race or sex certainly knew we had a racial problem. We have gone a long way toward correcting these problems
column18: but we still have a long way to go.

column1: I believe in it. I am eternally optimistic
column2: and I happen to believe that we've made great progress from the days when I was young and when this country didn't even know it had a racial problem. I know those things can grow out of despair in an inner city
column3: when there's hopelessness at home
column4: lack of work
column5: and so forth. But I believe that all of us together
column6: and I believe the Presidency is what Teddy Roosevelt said it was. It's a bully pulpit. And I think that something can be done from there
column7: because a goal for all of us should be that one day
column8: things will be done neither because of nor in spite of any of the differences between us - ethnic differences or racial differences
column9: whatever they may be - that we will have total equal opportunity for all people. And I would do everything I could in my power to bring that about.

column2: Mr. Hilliard. When I was campaigning in 1976
column3: everywhere I went
column4: the mayors and local officials were in despair about the rapidly deteriorating central cities of our nation. We initiated a very fine urban renewal program
column5: working with the mayors
column6: the governors
column7: and other interested officials. This has been a very successful effort. That's one of the main reasons that we've had such an increase in the number of people employed. Of the nine million people put to work in new jobs since I've been in office
column8: 1.3 million of those has been among black Americans
column9: and another million among those who speak Spanish. We now are planning to continue the revitalization program with increased commitments of rapid transit
column10: mass transit. Under the windfall profits tax
column11: we expect to spend about $43 billion in the next 10 years to rebuild the transportation systems of our country. We also are pursuing housing programs. We've had a 73% increase in the allotment of Federal funds for improved education. These are the kinds of efforts worked on a joint basis with community leaders
column12: particularly in the minority areas of the central cities that have been deteriorating so rapidly in the past. It's very important to us that this be done with the full involvement of minority citizens. I have brought into the top level
column13: top levels of government
column14: into the White House
column15: into administrative offices of the Executive branch
column16: into the judicial system
column17: highly qualified black and Spanish citizens and women who in the past had been excluded. I noticed that Governor Reagan said that when he was a young man that there was no knowledge of a racial problem in this country. Those who suffered from discrimination because of race or sex certainly knew we had a racial problem. We have gone a long way toward correcting these problems
column18: but we still have a long way to go.

column1: Ours is a nation of refugees
column2: a nation of immigrants. Almost all of our citizens came here from other lands and now have hopes
column3: which are being realized
column4: for a better life
column5: preserving their ethnic commitments
column6: their family structures
column7: their religious beliefs
column8: preserving their relationships with their relatives in foreign countries
column9: but still holding themselves together in a very coherent society
column10: which gives our nation its strength. In the past
column11: those minority groups have often been excluded from participation in the affairs of government. Since I've been President
column12: I've appointed
column13: for instance
column14: more than twice as many black Federal judges as all previous presidents in the history of this country. I've done the same thing in the appointment of women
column15: and also Spanish-speaking Americans. To involve them in the administration of government and the feeling that they belong to the societal structure that makes decisions in the judiciary and in the executive branch is a very important commitment which I am trying to realize and will continue to do so in the future.

column1: Yes. The President talks of Government programs
column2: and they have their place. But as governor
column3: when I was at that end of the line and receiving some of these grants for Government programs
column4: I saw that so many of them were dead-end. They were public employment that these people who really want to get out into the private job market where there are jobs with a future. Now
column5: the President spoke a moment ago about that I was against the minimum wage. I wish he could have been with me when I sat with a group of teenagers who were black
column6: and who were telling me about their unemployment problems
column7: and that it was the minimum wage that had done away with the jobs that they once could get. And indeed
column8: every time it has increased you will find there is an increase in minority unemployment among young people. And therefore
column9: I have been in favor of a separate minimum for them. With regard to the great progress that has been made with this Government spending
column10: the rate of black unemployment in Detroit
column11: Michigan

column1: It's obvious that we still have a long way to go in fully incorporating the minority groups into the mainstream of American life. We have made good progress
column2: and there is no doubt in my mind that the commitment to unemployment compensation
column3: the minimum wage
column4: welfare
column5: national health insurance
column6: those kinds of commitments that have typified the Democratic party since ancient history in this country's political life are a very important element of the future. In all those elements
column7: Governor Reagan has repeatedly spoken out against them
column8: which
column9: to me
column10: shows a very great insensitivity to giving deprived families a better chance in life. This
column11: to me
column12: is a very important difference between him and me in this election
column13: and I believe the American people will judge accordingly. There is no doubt in my mind that in the downtown central cities
column14: with the
column15: with the new commitment on an energy policy
column16: with a chance to revitalize homes and to make them more fuel efficient
column17: with a chance for our synthetic fuels program
column18: solar power
column19: this will give us an additional opportunity for jobs which will pay rich dividends.

column4: and that is that in the inner city areas
column5: that in cooperation with the local government and the national Government
column6: and using tax incentives and with cooperating with the private sector
column7: that we have development zones. Let the local entity

column12: and so forth

column17: for a period of time
column18: an increase in the property tax reflecting its development of the unused property that it was making wouldn't be any loss to the city because the city isn't getting any tax from that now. And there would simply be a delay
column19: and on the other hand
column20: many of the people who would then be given jobs are presently wards of the Government and it wouldn't hurt to give them a tax incentive
column21: because they... that wouldn't be costing Government anything either. I think there are things to do in this regard. I stood in the South Bronx on the exact spot that President Carter stood on in 1977. You have to see it to believe it. It looks like a bombed-out city - great
column22: gaunt skeletons of buildings. Windows smashed out
column23: painted on one of them ""Unkept promises;"" on another
column24: ""Despair."" And this was the spot at which President Carter had promised that he was going to bring in a vast program to rebuild this department. There are whole or this area there are whole blocks of land that are left bare
column25: just bulldozed down flat. And nothing has been done
column26: and they are now charging to take tourists there to see this terrible desolation. I talked to a man just briefly there who asked me one simple question: ""Do I have reason to hope that I can someday take care of my family again? Nothing has been done.""

column1: I believe in it. I am eternally optimistic
column2: and I happen to believe that we've made great progress from the days when I was young and when this country didn't even know it had a racial problem. I know those things can grow out of despair in an inner city
column3: when there's hopelessness at home
column4: lack of work
column5: and so forth. But I believe that all of us together
column6: and I believe the Presidency is what Teddy Roosevelt said it was. It's a bully pulpit. And I think that something can be done from there
column7: because a goal for all of us should be that one day
column8: things will be done neither because of nor in spite of any of the differences between us - ethnic differences or racial differences
column9: whatever they may be - that we will have total equal opportunity for all people. And I would do everything I could in my power to bring that about.

column2: Mr. Hilliard. When I was campaigning in 1976
column3: everywhere I went
column4: the mayors and local officials were in despair about the rapidly deteriorating central cities of our nation. We initiated a very fine urban renewal program
column5: working with the mayors
column6: the governors
column7: and other interested officials. This has been a very successful effort. That's one of the main reasons that we've had such an increase in the number of people employed. Of the nine million people put to work in new jobs since I've been in office
column8: 1.3 million of those has been among black Americans
column9: and another million among those who speak Spanish. We now are planning to continue the revitalization program with increased commitments of rapid transit
column10: mass transit. Under the windfall profits tax
column11: we expect to spend about $43 billion in the next 10 years to rebuild the transportation systems of our country. We also are pursuing housing programs. We've had a 73% increase in the allotment of Federal funds for improved education. These are the kinds of efforts worked on a joint basis with community leaders
column12: particularly in the minority areas of the central cities that have been deteriorating so rapidly in the past. It's very important to us that this be done with the full involvement of minority citizens. I have brought into the top level
column13: top levels of government
column14: into the White House
column15: into administrative offices of the Executive branch
column16: into the judicial system
column17: highly qualified black and Spanish citizens and women who in the past had been excluded. I noticed that Governor Reagan said that when he was a young man that there was no knowledge of a racial problem in this country. Those who suffered from discrimination because of race or sex certainly knew we had a racial problem. We have gone a long way toward correcting these problems
column18: but we still have a long way to go.

column1: Ours is a nation of refugees
column2: a nation of immigrants. Almost all of our citizens came here from other lands and now have hopes
column3: which are being realized
column4: for a better life
column5: preserving their ethnic commitments
column6: their family structures
column7: their religious beliefs
column8: preserving their relationships with their relatives in foreign countries
column9: but still holding themselves together in a very coherent society
column10: which gives our nation its strength. In the past
column11: those minority groups have often been excluded from participation in the affairs of government. Since I've been President
column12: I've appointed
column13: for instance
column14: more than twice as many black Federal judges as all previous presidents in the history of this country. I've done the same thing in the appointment of women
column15: and also Spanish-speaking Americans. To involve them in the administration of government and the feeling that they belong to the societal structure that makes decisions in the judiciary and in the executive branch is a very important commitment which I am trying to realize and will continue to do so in the future.

column1: Yes. The President talks of Government programs
column2: and they have their place. But as governor
column3: when I was at that end of the line and receiving some of these grants for Government programs
column4: I saw that so many of them were dead-end. They were public employment that these people who really want to get out into the private job market where there are jobs with a future. Now
column5: the President spoke a moment ago about that I was against the minimum wage. I wish he could have been with me when I sat with a group of teenagers who were black
column6: and who were telling me about their unemployment problems
column7: and that it was the minimum wage that had done away with the jobs that they once could get. And indeed
column8: every time it has increased you will find there is an increase in minority unemployment among young people. And therefore
column9: I have been in favor of a separate minimum for them. With regard to the great progress that has been made with this Government spending

column17: with a chance for our synthetic fuels program
column18: solar power
column19: this will give us an additional opportunity for jobs which will pay rich dividends.

column3: 3)	" I have been talking to a number of Congressmen who have much the same idea that I have
column4: and that is that in the inner city areas
column5: that in cooperation with the local government and the national Government
column6: and using tax incentives and with cooperating with the private sector
column7: that we have development zones. Let the local entity
column8: the city
column9: declare this particular area
column10: based on the standards of the percentage of people on welfare
column11: unemployed
column12: and so forth
column13: in that area. And then
column14: through tax incentives
column15: induce the creation of businesses providing jobs and so forth in those areas. The elements of government through these tax incentives For example
column16: a business that would not have
column17: for a period of time
column18: an increase in the property tax reflecting its development of the unused property that it was making wouldn't be any loss to the city because the city isn't getting any tax from that now. And there would simply be a delay
column19: and on the other hand
column20: many of the people who would then be given jobs are presently wards of the Government and it wouldn't hurt to give them a tax incentive
column21: because they... that wouldn't be costing Government anything either. I think there are things to do in this regard. I stood in the South Bronx on the exact spot that President Carter stood on in 1977. You have to see it to believe it. It looks like a bombed-out city - great
column22: gaunt skeletons of buildings. Windows smashed out
column23: painted on one of them ""Unkept promises;"" on another
column24: ""Despair."" And this was the spot at which President Carter had promised that he was going to bring in a vast program to rebuild this department. There are whole or this area there are whole blocks of land that are left bare
column25: just bulldozed down flat. And nothing has been done
column26: and they are now charging to take tourists there to see this terrible desolation. I talked to a man just briefly there who asked me one simple question: ""Do I have reason to hope that I can someday take care of my family again? Nothing has been done.""

column1: I believe in it. I am eternally optimistic
column2: and I happen to believe that we've made great progress from the days when I was young and when this country didn't even know it had a racial problem. I know those things can grow out of despair in an inner city
column3: when there's hopelessness at home
column4: lack of work
column5: and so forth. But I believe that all of us together
column6: and I believe the Presidency is what Teddy Roosevelt said it was. It's a bully pulpit. And I think that something can be done from there
column7: because a goal for all of us should be that one day
column8: things will be done neither because of nor in spite of any of the differences between us - ethnic differences or racial differences
column9: whatever they may be - that we will have total equal opportunity for all people. And I would do everything I could in my power to bring that about.

column2: Mr. Hilliard. When I was campaigning in 1976
column3: everywhere I went
column4: the mayors and local officials were in despair about the rapidly deteriorating central cities of our nation. We initiated a very fine urban renewal program
column5: working with the mayors
column6: the governors
column7: and other interested officials. This has been a very successful effort. That's one of the main reasons that we've had such an increase in the number of people employed. Of the nine million people put to work in new jobs since I've been in office
column8: 1.3 million of those has been among black Americans
column9: and another million among those who speak Spanish. We now are planning to continue the revitalization program with increased commitments of rapid transit
column10: mass transit. Under the windfall profits tax
column11: we expect to spend about $43 billion in the next 10 years to rebuild the transportation systems of our country. We also are pursuing housing programs. We've had a 73% increase in the allotment of Federal funds for improved education. These are the kinds of efforts worked on a joint basis with community leaders
column12: particularly in the minority areas of the central cities that have been deteriorating so rapidly in the past. It's very important to us that this be done with the full involvement of minority citizens. I have brought into the top level
column13: top levels of government
column14: into the White House
column15: into administrative offices of the Executive branch
column16: into the judicial system
column17: highly qualified black and Spanish citizens and women who in the past had been excluded. I noticed that Governor Reagan said that when he was a young man that there was no knowledge of a racial problem in this country. Those who suffered from discrimination because of race or sex certainly knew we had a racial problem. We have gone a long way toward correcting these problems
column18: but we still have a long way to go.

column7: against those who live in Israel
column8: by the PLO and other terrorist organizations. Ultimately
column9: the most serious terrorist threat is if one of those radical nations
column10: who believe in terrorism as a policy
column11: should have atomic weapons. Both I and all my predecessors have had a deep commitment to controlling the proliferation of nuclear weapons. In countries like Libya or Iraq
column12: we have even alienated some of our closest trade partners because we have insisted upon the control of the spread of nuclear weapons to those potentially terrorist countries. When Governor Reagan has been asked about that
column13: he makes the very disturbing comment that non-proliferation
column14: or the control of the spread of nuclear weapons
column15: is none of our business. And recently when he was asked specifically about Iraq
column16: he said there is nothing we can do about it. This ultimate terrorist threat is the most fearsome of all
column17: and it's part of a pattern where our country must stand firm to control terrorism of all kinds.

column1: We will maintain our position of neutrality in the Iran and Iraq war. We have no plans to sell additional materiel or goods to Iran
column2: that might be of a warlike nature. When I made my decision to stop all trade with Iran as a result of the taking of our hostages
column3: I announced then
column4: and have consistently maintained since then
column5: that if the hostages are released safely
column6: we would make delivery on those items which Iran owns - which they have bought and paid for - also
column7: that the frozen Iranian assets would be released. That's been a consistent policy
column8: one I intend to carry out.

column2: you've asked that question twice. I think you ought to have at least one answer to it. I have been accused lately of having a secret plan with regard to the hostages. Now
column3: this comes from an answer that I've made at least 50 times during this campaign to the press
column4: when I am asked have you any ideas of what you would do if you were there? And I said
column5: well
column6: yes. And I think that anyone that's seeking this position
column7: as well as other people
column8: probably
column9: have thought to themselves
column10: what about this
column11: what about that? These are just ideas of what I would think of if I were in that position and had access to the information
column12: and which I would know all the options that were open to me. I have never answered the question
column13: however; second
column14: the one that says
column15: well
column16: tell me
column17: what are some of those ideas? First of all
column18: I would be fearful that I might say something that was presently under way or in negotiations
column19: and thus expose it and endanger the hostages
column20: and sometimes
column21: I think some of my ideas might require quiet diplomacy where you don't say in advance
column22: or say to anyone
column23: what it is you're thinking of doing. Your question is difficult to answer
column24: because
column26: no one wants to say anything that would inadvertently delay
column27: in any way
column28: the return of those hostages if there if there is a chance that they're coming home soon
column29: or that might cause them harm. What I do think should be done
column30: once they are safely here with their families
column31: and that tragedy is over - we've endured this humiliation for just lacking one week of a year now - then
column32: I think
column33: it is time for us to have a complete investigation as to the diplomatic efforts that were made in the beginning
column34: why they have been there so long
column35: and when they came home
column36: what did we have to do in order to bring that about - what arrangements were made? And I would suggest that Congress should hold such an investigation. In the meantime
column37: I'm going to continue praying that they'll carne home.

column1: The degree of unpopularity of a regime when the choice is total authoritarianism totalitarianism
column2: I should say
column3: in the alternative government
column4: makes one wonder whether you are being helpful to the people. And we've been guilty of that. Because someone didn't meet exactly our standards of human rights
column5: even though they were an ally of ours
column6: instead of trying patiently to persuade them to change their ways
column7: we have
column8: in a number of instances
column9: aided a revolutionary overthrow which results in complete totalitarianism
column10: instead
column11: for those people. I think that this is a kind of a hypocritical policy when
column12: at the same time
column13: we're maintaining a detente with the one nation in the world where there are no human rights at all - the Soviet Union. Now
column14: there was a second phase in the Iranian affair in which we had something to do with that. And that was
column15: we had adequate warning that there was a threat to our embassy
column16: and we could have done what other embassies did - either strengthen our security there
column17: or remove our personnel before the kidnap and the takeover took place.

column1: I didn't hear any comment from Governor Reagan about what he would do to stop or reduce terrorism in the future. What the Western allies did decide to do is to stop all air flights - commercial air flights - to any nation involved in terrorism or the hijacking of air planes
column2: or the harboring of hijackers. Secondly
column3: we all committed ourselves
column4: as have all my predecessors in the Oval Office not to permit the spread of nuclear weapons to a terrorist nation
column5: or to any other nation that does not presently have those weapons or capabilities for explosives. Third
column6: not to make any sales of materiel or weapons to a nation which is involved in terrorist activities. And
column7: lastly
column8: not to deal with the PLO until and unless the PLO recognizes Israel's right to exist and recognizes UN Resolution 242 as a basis for Middle East peace. These are a few of the things to which our nation is committed
column9: and we will continue with these commitments.

column1: Yes. I have no quarrel whatsoever with the things that have been done
column2: because I believe it is high time that the civilized countries of the world made it plain that there is no room worldwide for terrorism; there will be no negotiation with terrorists of any kind. And while I have a last word here
column3: I would like to correct a misstatement of fact by the President. I have never made the statement that he suggested about nuclear proliferation and nuclear proliferation
column4: or the trying to halt it
column5: would be a major part of a foreign policy of mine.

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 4)	" Barbara
column4: one of the blights on this world is the threat and the activities of terrorists. At one of the recent economic summit conferences between myself and the other leaders of the western world
column5: we committed ourselves to take strong action against terrorism. Airplane hijacking was one of the elements of that commitment. There is no doubt that we have seen in recent years - in recent months - additional acts of violence against Jews in France and
column6: of course
column7: against those who live in Israel
column8: by the PLO and other terrorist organizations. Ultimately
column9: the most serious terrorist threat is if one of those radical nations
column10: who believe in terrorism as a policy
column11: should have atomic weapons. Both I and all my predecessors have had a deep commitment to controlling the proliferation of nuclear weapons. In countries like Libya or Iraq
column12: we have even alienated some of our closest trade partners because we have insisted upon the control of the spread of nuclear weapons to those potentially terrorist countries. When Governor Reagan has been asked about that
column13: he makes the very disturbing comment that non-proliferation
column14: or the control of the spread of nuclear weapons
column15: is none of our business. And recently when he was asked specifically about Iraq
column16: he said there is nothing we can do about it. This ultimate terrorist threat is the most fearsome of all
column17: and it's part of a pattern where our country must stand firm to control terrorism of all kinds.

column1: We will maintain our position of neutrality in the Iran and Iraq war. We have no plans to sell additional materiel or goods to Iran
column2: that might be of a warlike nature. When I made my decision to stop all trade with Iran as a result of the taking of our hostages
column3: I announced then
column4: and have consistently maintained since then
column5: that if the hostages are released safely
column6: we would make delivery on those items which Iran owns - which they have bought and paid for - also
column7: that the frozen Iranian assets would be released. That's been a consistent policy
column8: one I intend to carry out.

column2: you've asked that question twice. I think you ought to have at least one answer to it. I have been accused lately of having a secret plan with regard to the hostages. Now
column3: this comes from an answer that I've made at least 50 times during this campaign to the press
column4: when I am asked have you any ideas of what you would do if you were there? And I said
column5: well
column6: yes. And I think that anyone that's seeking this position
column7: as well as other people
column8: probably
column9: have thought to themselves
column10: what about this
column11: what about that? These are just ideas of what I would think of if I were in that position and had access to the information
column12: and which I would know all the options that were open to me. I have never answered the question
column13: however; second
column14: the one that says
column15: well
column16: tell me
column17: what are some of those ideas? First of all
column18: I would be fearful that I might say something that was presently under way or in negotiations
column19: and thus expose it and endanger the hostages
column20: and sometimes
column21: I think some of my ideas might require quiet diplomacy where you don't say in advance
column22: or say to anyone
column23: what it is you're thinking of doing. Your question is difficult to answer
column24: because
column26: no one wants to say anything that would inadvertently delay
column27: in any way
column28: the return of those hostages if there if there is a chance that they're coming home soon
column29: or that might cause them harm. What I do think should be done
column30: once they are safely here with their families
column31: and that tragedy is over - we've endured this humiliation for just lacking one week of a year now - then
column32: I think
column33: it is time for us to have a complete investigation as to the diplomatic efforts that were made in the beginning
column34: why they have been there so long
column35: and when they came home
column36: what did we have to do in order to bring that about - what arrangements were made? And I would suggest that Congress should hold such an investigation. In the meantime
column37: I'm going to continue praying that they'll carne home.

column1: The degree of unpopularity of a regime when the choice is total authoritarianism totalitarianism
column2: I should say
column3: in the alternative government
column4: makes one wonder whether you are being helpful to the people. And we've been guilty of that. Because someone didn't meet exactly our standards of human rights
column5: even though they were an ally of ours
column6: instead of trying patiently to persuade them to change their ways
column7: we have
column8: in a number of instances
column9: aided a revolutionary overthrow which results in complete totalitarianism
column10: instead
column11: for those people. I think that this is a kind of a hypocritical policy when
column12: at the same time
column13: we're maintaining a detente with the one nation in the world where there are no human rights at all - the Soviet Union. Now
column14: there was a second phase in the Iranian affair in which we had something to do with that. And that was
column15: we had adequate warning that there was a threat to our embassy
column16: and we could have done what other embassies did - either strengthen our security there
column17: or remove our personnel before the kidnap and the takeover took place.

column1: I didn't hear any comment from Governor Reagan about what he would do to stop or reduce terrorism in the future. What the Western allies did decide to do is to stop all air flights - commercial air flights - to any nation involved in terrorism or the hijacking of air planes
column2: or the harboring of hijackers. Secondly
column3: we all committed ourselves
column4: as have all my predecessors in the Oval Office not to permit the spread of nuclear weapons to a terrorist nation
column5: or to any other nation that does not presently have those weapons or capabilities for explosives. Third
column6: not to make any sales of materiel or weapons to a nation which is involved in terrorist activities. And
column7: lastly
column8: not to deal with the PLO until and unless the PLO recognizes Israel's right to exist and recognizes UN Resolution 242 as a basis for Middle East peace. These are a few of the things to which our nation is committed
column9: and we will continue with these commitments.

column1: Yes. I have no quarrel whatsoever with the things that have been done
column2: because I believe it is high time that the civilized countries of the world made it plain that there is no room worldwide for terrorism; there will be no negotiation with terrorists of any kind. And while I have a last word here
column3: I would like to correct a misstatement of fact by the President. I have never made the statement that he suggested about nuclear proliferation and nuclear proliferation
column4: or the trying to halt it
column5: would be a major part of a foreign policy of mine.

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 4)	" Barbara
column4: one of the blights on this world is the threat and the activities of terrorists. At one of the recent economic summit conferences between myself and the other leaders of the western world
column5: we committed ourselves to take strong action against terrorism. Airplane hijacking was one of the elements of that commitment. There is no doubt that we have seen in recent years - in recent months - additional acts of violence against Jews in France and
column6: of course
column7: against those who live in Israel
column8: by the PLO and other terrorist organizations. Ultimately
column9: the most serious terrorist threat is if one of those radical nations
column10: who believe in terrorism as a policy
column11: should have atomic weapons. Both I and all my predecessors have had a deep commitment to controlling the proliferation of nuclear weapons. In countries like Libya or Iraq
column12: we have even alienated some of our closest trade partners because we have insisted upon the control of the spread of nuclear weapons to those potentially terrorist countries. When Governor Reagan has been asked about that
column13: he makes the very disturbing comment that non-proliferation
column14: or the control of the spread of nuclear weapons
column15: is none of our business. And recently when he was asked specifically about Iraq
column16: he said there is nothing we can do about it. This ultimate terrorist threat is the most fearsome of all
column17: and it's part of a pattern where our country must stand firm to control terrorism of all kinds.

column1: We will maintain our position of neutrality in the Iran and Iraq war. We have no plans to sell additional materiel or goods to Iran
column2: that might be of a warlike nature. When I made my decision to stop all trade with Iran as a result of the taking of our hostages
column3: I announced then
column4: and have consistently maintained since then
column5: that if the hostages are released safely
column6: we would make delivery on those items which Iran owns - which they have bought and paid for - also
column7: that the frozen Iranian assets would be released. That's been a consistent policy
column8: one I intend to carry out.

column2: you've asked that question twice. I think you ought to have at least one answer to it. I have been accused lately of having a secret plan with regard to the hostages. Now
column3: this comes from an answer that I've made at least 50 times during this campaign to the press
column4: when I am asked have you any ideas of what you would do if you were there? And I said
column5: well
column6: yes. And I think that anyone that's seeking this position
column7: as well as other people
column8: probably
column9: have thought to themselves
column10: what about this
column11: what about that? These are just ideas of what I would think of if I were in that position and had access to the information
column12: and which I would know all the options that were open to me. I have never answered the question
column13: however; second
column14: the one that says
column15: well
column16: tell me
column17: what are some of those ideas? First of all
column18: I would be fearful that I might say something that was presently under way or in negotiations
column19: and thus expose it and endanger the hostages
column20: and sometimes
column21: I think some of my ideas might require quiet diplomacy where you don't say in advance
column22: or say to anyone
column23: what it is you're thinking of doing. Your question is difficult to answer
column24: because
column26: no one wants to say anything that would inadvertently delay
column27: in any way
column28: the return of those hostages if there if there is a chance that they're coming home soon
column29: or that might cause them harm. What I do think should be done
column30: once they are safely here with their families
column31: and that tragedy is over - we've endured this humiliation for just lacking one week of a year now - then
column32: I think
column33: it is time for us to have a complete investigation as to the diplomatic efforts that were made in the beginning
column34: why they have been there so long
column35: and when they came home
column36: what did we have to do in order to bring that about - what arrangements were made? And I would suggest that Congress should hold such an investigation. In the meantime
column37: I'm going to continue praying that they'll carne home.

column1: The degree of unpopularity of a regime when the choice is total authoritarianism totalitarianism
column2: I should say
column3: in the alternative government
column4: makes one wonder whether you are being helpful to the people. And we've been guilty of that. Because someone didn't meet exactly our standards of human rights
column5: even though they were an ally of ours
column6: instead of trying patiently to persuade them to change their ways
column7: we have
column8: in a number of instances
column9: aided a revolutionary overthrow which results in complete totalitarianism
column10: instead
column11: for those people. I think that this is a kind of a hypocritical policy when
column12: at the same time
column13: we're maintaining a detente with the one nation in the world where there are no human rights at all - the Soviet Union. Now
column14: there was a second phase in the Iranian affair in which we had something to do with that. And that was
column15: we had adequate warning that there was a threat to our embassy
column16: and we could have done what other embassies did - either strengthen our security there
column17: or remove our personnel before the kidnap and the takeover took place.

column1: I didn't hear any comment from Governor Reagan about what he would do to stop or reduce terrorism in the future. What the Western allies did decide to do is to stop all air flights - commercial air flights - to any nation involved in terrorism or the hijacking of air planes
column2: or the harboring of hijackers. Secondly
column3: we all committed ourselves
column4: as have all my predecessors in the Oval Office not to permit the spread of nuclear weapons to a terrorist nation
column5: or to any other nation that does not presently have those weapons or capabilities for explosives. Third
column6: not to make any sales of materiel or weapons to a nation which is involved in terrorist activities. And
column7: lastly
column8: not to deal with the PLO until and unless the PLO recognizes Israel's right to exist and recognizes UN Resolution 242 as a basis for Middle East peace. These are a few of the things to which our nation is committed
column9: and we will continue with these commitments.

column1: Yes. I have no quarrel whatsoever with the things that have been done
column2: because I believe it is high time that the civilized countries of the world made it plain that there is no room worldwide for terrorism; there will be no negotiation with terrorists of any kind. And while I have a last word here
column3: I would like to correct a misstatement of fact by the President. I have never made the statement that he suggested about nuclear proliferation and nuclear proliferation
column4: or the trying to halt it
column5: would be a major part of a foreign policy of mine.

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 5)	" Yes. I think I'm right because I believe that we must have a consistent foreign policy
column4: a strong America
column5: and a strong economy. And then
column6: as we build up our national security
column7: to restore our margin of safety
column8: we at the same time try to restrain the Soviet build-up
column9: which has been going forward at a rapid pace
column10: and for quite some time. The SALT II treaty was the result of negotiations that Mr. Carter's team entered into after he had asked the Soviet Union for a discussion of actual reduction of nuclear strategic weapons. And his emissary
column11: I think
column12: came home in 12 hours having heard a very definite nyet. But taking that one no from the Soviet Union
column13: we then went back into negotiations on their terms
column14: because Mr. Carter had canceled the B-I bomber
column15: delayed the MX
column16: delayed the Trident submarine
column17: delayed the cruise missile
column18: shut down the Missile Man - the three - the Minuteman missile production line
column19: and whatever other things that might have been done. The Soviet Union sat at the table knowing that we had gone forward with unilateral concessions without any reciprocation from them whatsoever. Now
column20: I have not blocked the SALT II treaty
column21: as Mr. Carter and Mr. Mondale suggest I have. It has been blocked by a Senate in which there is a Democratic majority. Indeed
column22: the Senate Armed Services Committee voted 10 to 0
column23: with seven abstentions
column24: against the SALT II treaty
column25: and declared that it was not in the national security interests of the United States. Besides which
column26: it is illegal
column27: because the law of the land
column29: says that we cannot accept a treaty in which we are not equal. And we are not equal in this treaty for one reason alone - our B-2 bombers are considered to be strategic weapons; their Backfire bombers are not.

column2: I'd be glad to. Inflation. unemployment
column3: the cities are all very important issues
column4: but they pale into insignificance in the life and duties of a President when compared with the control of nuclear weapons. Every President who has served in the Oval Office since Harry Truman has been dedicated to the proposition of controlling nuclear weapons. To negotiate with the Soviet Union a balanced
column5: controlled
column6: observable
column7: and then reducing levels of atomic weaponry
column8: there is a disturbing pattern in the attitude of Governor Reagan. He has never supported any of those arms control agreements - the limited test ban
column9: SALT I
column10: nor the Antiballistic Missile Treaty
column11: nor the Vladivostok Treaty negotiated with the Soviet Union by President Ford - and now he wants to throw into the wastebasket a treaty to control nuclear weapons on a balanced and equal basis between ourselves and the Soviet Union
column12: negotiated over a seven-year period
column13: by myself and my two Republican predecessors. The Senate has not voted yet on the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty. There have been preliminary skirmishing in the committees of the Senate
column14: but the Treaty has never come to the floor of the Senate for either a debate or a vote. It's understandable that a Senator in the preliminary debates can make an irresponsible statement
column15: or
column16: maybe
column17: an ill-advised statement. You've got 99 other senators to correct that mistake
column18: if it is a mistake. But when a man who hopes to be President says
column19: take this treaty
column20: discard it
column21: do not vote
column22: do not debate
column23: do not explore the issues
column24: do not finally capitalize on this long negotiation - that is a very dangerous and disturbing thing.

column1: Yes. Governor Reagan is making some very misleading and disturbing statements. He not only advocates the scrapping of this treaty - and I don't know that these men that he quotes are against the treaty in its final form - but he also advocates the possibility
column2: he said it's been a missing element
column3: of playing a trump card against the Soviet Union of a nuclear arms race
column4: and is insisting upon nuclear superiority by our own nation
column5: as a predication for negotiation in the future with the Soviet Union. If President Brezhnev said
column6: we will scrap this treaty
column7: negotiated under three American Presidents over a seven-year period of time
column8: we insist upon nuclear superiority as a basis for future negotiations
column9: and we believe that the launching of a nuclear arms race is a good basis for future negotiations
column10: it's obvious that I
column11: as President
column12: and all Americans
column13: would reject such a proposition. This would mean the resumption of a very dangerous nuclear arms race. It would be very disturbing to American people. It would change the basic tone and commitment that our nation has experienced ever since the Second World War
column14: with al Presidents
column15: Democratic and Republican. And it would also be very disturbing to our allies
column16: all of whom support this nuclear arms treaty. In addition to that
column17: the adversarial relationship between ourselves and the Soviet Union would undoubtedly deteriorate very rapidly. This attitude is extremely dangerous and belligerent in its tone
column18: although it's said with a quiet voice.

column1: I know the President's supposed to be replying to me
column2: but sometimes
column3: I have a hard time in connecting what he's saying
column4: with what I have said or what my positions are. I sometimes think he's like the witch doctor that gets mad when a good doctor comes along with a cure that'll work. My point I have made already
column5: Mr. President
column6: with regard to negotiating: it does not call for nuclear superiority on the part of the United States. It calls for a mutual reduction of these weapons
column7: as I say
column8: that neither of us can represent a threat to the other. And to suggest that the SALT II treaty that your negotiators negotiated was just a continuation
column9: and based on all of the preceding efforts by two previous Presidents
column10: is just not true. It was a new negotiation because
column11: as I say
column12: President Ford was within about 10% of having a solution that could be acceptable. And I think our allies would be very happy to go along with a fair and verifiable SALT agreement.

column2: to close out this discussion
column3: it would be better to put into perspective what we're talking about. I had a discussion with my daughter
column4: Amy
column5: the other day
column6: before I came here
column7: to ask her what the most important issue was. She said she thought nuclear weaponry - and the control of nuclear arms. This is a formidable force. Some of these weapons have 10 megatons of explosion. If you put 50 tons of TNT in each one of railroad cars
column8: you would have a carload of TNT - a trainload of TNT stretching across this nation. That's one major war explosion in a warhead. We have thousands
column9: equivalent of megaton
column10: or million tons
column11: of TNT warheads. The control of these weapons is the single major responsibility of a President
column12: and to cast out this commitment of all Presidents
column13: because of some slight technicalities that can be corrected
column14: is a very dangerous approach.

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 5)	" Yes. I think I'm right because I believe that we must have a consistent foreign policy
column4: a strong America
column5: and a strong economy. And then
column6: as we build up our national security
column7: to restore our margin of safety
column8: we at the same time try to restrain the Soviet build-up
column9: which has been going forward at a rapid pace
column10: and for quite some time. The SALT II treaty was the result of negotiations that Mr. Carter's team entered into after he had asked the Soviet Union for a discussion of actual reduction of nuclear strategic weapons. And his emissary
column11: I think
column12: came home in 12 hours having heard a very definite nyet. But taking that one no from the Soviet Union
column13: we then went back into negotiations on their terms
column14: because Mr. Carter had canceled the B-I bomber
column15: delayed the MX
column16: delayed the Trident submarine
column17: delayed the cruise missile
column18: shut down the Missile Man - the three - the Minuteman missile production line
column19: and whatever other things that might have been done. The Soviet Union sat at the table knowing that we had gone forward with unilateral concessions without any reciprocation from them whatsoever. Now
column20: I have not blocked the SALT II treaty
column21: as Mr. Carter and Mr. Mondale suggest I have. It has been blocked by a Senate in which there is a Democratic majority. Indeed
column22: the Senate Armed Services Committee voted 10 to 0
column23: with seven abstentions
column24: against the SALT II treaty
column25: and declared that it was not in the national security interests of the United States. Besides which
column26: it is illegal
column27: because the law of the land
column29: says that we cannot accept a treaty in which we are not equal. And we are not equal in this treaty for one reason alone - our B-2 bombers are considered to be strategic weapons; their Backfire bombers are not.

column2: I'd be glad to. Inflation. unemployment
column3: the cities are all very important issues
column4: but they pale into insignificance in the life and duties of a President when compared with the control of nuclear weapons. Every President who has served in the Oval Office since Harry Truman has been dedicated to the proposition of controlling nuclear weapons. To negotiate with the Soviet Union a balanced
column5: controlled
column6: observable
column7: and then reducing levels of atomic weaponry
column8: there is a disturbing pattern in the attitude of Governor Reagan. He has never supported any of those arms control agreements - the limited test ban
column9: SALT I
column10: nor the Antiballistic Missile Treaty
column11: nor the Vladivostok Treaty negotiated with the Soviet Union by President Ford - and now he wants to throw into the wastebasket a treaty to control nuclear weapons on a balanced and equal basis between ourselves and the Soviet Union
column12: negotiated over a seven-year period
column13: by myself and my two Republican predecessors. The Senate has not voted yet on the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty. There have been preliminary skirmishing in the committees of the Senate
column14: but the Treaty has never come to the floor of the Senate for either a debate or a vote. It's understandable that a Senator in the preliminary debates can make an irresponsible statement
column15: or
column16: maybe
column17: an ill-advised statement. You've got 99 other senators to correct that mistake
column18: if it is a mistake. But when a man who hopes to be President says
column19: take this treaty
column20: discard it
column21: do not vote
column22: do not debate
column23: do not explore the issues
column24: do not finally capitalize on this long negotiation - that is a very dangerous and disturbing thing.

column1: Yes. Governor Reagan is making some very misleading and disturbing statements. He not only advocates the scrapping of this treaty - and I don't know that these men that he quotes are against the treaty in its final form - but he also advocates the possibility
column2: he said it's been a missing element
column3: of playing a trump card against the Soviet Union of a nuclear arms race
column4: and is insisting upon nuclear superiority by our own nation
column5: as a predication for negotiation in the future with the Soviet Union. If President Brezhnev said
column6: we will scrap this treaty
column7: negotiated under three American Presidents over a seven-year period of time
column8: we insist upon nuclear superiority as a basis for future negotiations
column9: and we believe that the launching of a nuclear arms race is a good basis for future negotiations
column10: it's obvious that I
column11: as President
column12: and all Americans
column13: would reject such a proposition. This would mean the resumption of a very dangerous nuclear arms race. It would be very disturbing to American people. It would change the basic tone and commitment that our nation has experienced ever since the Second World War
column14: with al Presidents
column15: Democratic and Republican. And it would also be very disturbing to our allies
column16: all of whom support this nuclear arms treaty. In addition to that
column17: the adversarial relationship between ourselves and the Soviet Union would undoubtedly deteriorate very rapidly. This attitude is extremely dangerous and belligerent in its tone
column18: although it's said with a quiet voice.

column1: I know the President's supposed to be replying to me
column2: but sometimes
column3: I have a hard time in connecting what he's saying
column4: with what I have said or what my positions are. I sometimes think he's like the witch doctor that gets mad when a good doctor comes along with a cure that'll work. My point I have made already
column5: Mr. President
column6: with regard to negotiating: it does not call for nuclear superiority on the part of the United States. It calls for a mutual reduction of these weapons
column7: as I say
column8: that neither of us can represent a threat to the other. And to suggest that the SALT II treaty that your negotiators negotiated was just a continuation
column9: and based on all of the preceding efforts by two previous Presidents
column10: is just not true. It was a new negotiation because
column11: as I say
column12: President Ford was within about 10% of having a solution that could be acceptable. And I think our allies would be very happy to go along with a fair and verifiable SALT agreement.

column2: to close out this discussion
column3: it would be better to put into perspective what we're talking about. I had a discussion with my daughter
column4: Amy
column5: the other day
column6: before I came here
column7: to ask her what the most important issue was. She said she thought nuclear weaponry - and the control of nuclear arms. This is a formidable force. Some of these weapons have 10 megatons of explosion. If you put 50 tons of TNT in each one of railroad cars
column8: you would have a carload of TNT - a trainload of TNT stretching across this nation. That's one major war explosion in a warhead. We have thousands
column9: equivalent of megaton
column10: or million tons
column11: of TNT warheads. The control of these weapons is the single major responsibility of a President
column12: and to cast out this commitment of all Presidents
column13: because of some slight technicalities that can be corrected
column14: is a very dangerous approach.

column14: with al Presidents
column15: Democratic and Republican. And it would also be very disturbing to our allies
column16: all of whom support this nuclear arms treaty. In addition to that
column17: the adversarial relationship between ourselves and the Soviet Union would undoubtedly deteriorate very rapidly. This attitude is extremely dangerous and belligerent in its tone
column18: although it's said with a quiet voice.

column1: I know the President's supposed to be replying to me
column2: but sometimes
column3: I have a hard time in connecting what he's saying
column4: with what I have said or what my positions are. I sometimes think he's like the witch doctor that gets mad when a good doctor comes along with a cure that'll work. My point I have made already
column5: Mr. President
column6: with regard to negotiating: it does not call for nuclear superiority on the part of the United States. It calls for a mutual reduction of these weapons
column7: as I say
column8: that neither of us can represent a threat to the other. And to suggest that the SALT II treaty that your negotiators negotiated was just a continuation
column9: and based on all of the preceding efforts by two previous Presidents
column10: is just not true. It was a new negotiation because
column11: as I say
column12: President Ford was within about 10% of having a solution that could be acceptable. And I think our allies would be very happy to go along with a fair and verifiable SALT agreement.

column2: to close out this discussion
column3: it would be better to put into perspective what we're talking about. I had a discussion with my daughter
column4: Amy
column5: the other day
column6: before I came here
column7: to ask her what the most important issue was. She said she thought nuclear weaponry - and the control of nuclear arms. This is a formidable force. Some of these weapons have 10 megatons of explosion. If you put 50 tons of TNT in each one of railroad cars
column8: you would have a carload of TNT - a trainload of TNT stretching across this nation. That's one major war explosion in a warhead. We have thousands
column9: equivalent of megaton
column10: or million tons
column11: of TNT warheads. The control of these weapons is the single major responsibility of a President
column12: and to cast out this commitment of all Presidents
column13: because of some slight technicalities that can be corrected
column14: is a very dangerous approach.

column1: Yes. Governor Reagan is making some very misleading and disturbing statements. He not only advocates the scrapping of this treaty - and I don't know that these men that he quotes are against the treaty in its final form - but he also advocates the possibility
column2: he said it's been a missing element
column3: of playing a trump card against the Soviet Union of a nuclear arms race
column4: and is insisting upon nuclear superiority by our own nation
column5: as a predication for negotiation in the future with the Soviet Union. If President Brezhnev said
column6: we will scrap this treaty
column7: negotiated under three American Presidents over a seven-year period of time
column8: we insist upon nuclear superiority as a basis for future negotiations
column9: and we believe that the launching of a nuclear arms race is a good basis for future negotiations
column10: it's obvious that I
column11: as President
column12: and all Americans
column13: would reject such a proposition. This would mean the resumption of a very dangerous nuclear arms race. It would be very disturbing to American people. It would change the basic tone and commitment that our nation has experienced ever since the Second World War
column14: with al Presidents
column15: Democratic and Republican. And it would also be very disturbing to our allies
column16: all of whom support this nuclear arms treaty. In addition to that
column17: the adversarial relationship between ourselves and the Soviet Union would undoubtedly deteriorate very rapidly. This attitude is extremely dangerous and belligerent in its tone
column18: although it's said with a quiet voice.

column1: I know the President's supposed to be replying to me
column2: but sometimes
column3: I have a hard time in connecting what he's saying
column4: with what I have said or what my positions are. I sometimes think he's like the witch doctor that gets mad when a good doctor comes along with a cure that'll work. My point I have made already
column5: Mr. President
column6: with regard to negotiating: it does not call for nuclear superiority on the part of the United States. It calls for a mutual reduction of these weapons
column7: as I say
column8: that neither of us can represent a threat to the other. And to suggest that the SALT II treaty that your negotiators negotiated was just a continuation
column9: and based on all of the preceding efforts by two previous Presidents
column10: is just not true. It was a new negotiation because
column11: as I say
column12: President Ford was within about 10% of having a solution that could be acceptable. And I think our allies would be very happy to go along with a fair and verifiable SALT agreement.

column2: to close out this discussion
column3: it would be better to put into perspective what we're talking about. I had a discussion with my daughter
column4: Amy
column5: the other day
column6: before I came here
column7: to ask her what the most important issue was. She said she thought nuclear weaponry - and the control of nuclear arms. This is a formidable force. Some of these weapons have 10 megatons of explosion. If you put 50 tons of TNT in each one of railroad cars
column8: you would have a carload of TNT - a trainload of TNT stretching across this nation. That's one major war explosion in a warhead. We have thousands
column9: equivalent of megaton
column10: or million tons
column11: of TNT warheads. The control of these weapons is the single major responsibility of a President
column12: and to cast out this commitment of all Presidents
column13: because of some slight technicalities that can be corrected
column14: is a very dangerous approach.

column3: 5)	" Yes. I think I'm right because I believe that we must have a consistent foreign policy
column4: a strong America
column5: and a strong economy. And then
column6: as we build up our national security
column7: to restore our margin of safety
column8: we at the same time try to restrain the Soviet build-up
column9: which has been going forward at a rapid pace
column10: and for quite some time. The SALT II treaty was the result of negotiations that Mr. Carter's team entered into after he had asked the Soviet Union for a discussion of actual reduction of nuclear strategic weapons. And his emissary
column11: I think
column12: came home in 12 hours having heard a very definite nyet. But taking that one no from the Soviet Union
column13: we then went back into negotiations on their terms
column14: because Mr. Carter had canceled the B-I bomber
column15: delayed the MX
column16: delayed the Trident submarine
column17: delayed the cruise missile
column18: shut down the Missile Man - the three - the Minuteman missile production line
column19: and whatever other things that might have been done. The Soviet Union sat at the table knowing that we had gone forward with unilateral concessions without any reciprocation from them whatsoever. Now
column20: I have not blocked the SALT II treaty
column21: as Mr. Carter and Mr. Mondale suggest I have. It has been blocked by a Senate in which there is a Democratic majority. Indeed
column22: the Senate Armed Services Committee voted 10 to 0
column23: with seven abstentions
column24: against the SALT II treaty
column25: and declared that it was not in the national security interests of the United States. Besides which
column26: it is illegal
column27: because the law of the land
column29: says that we cannot accept a treaty in which we are not equal. And we are not equal in this treaty for one reason alone - our B-2 bombers are considered to be strategic weapons; their Backfire bombers are not.

column2: I'd be glad to. Inflation. unemployment

column4: but they pale into insignificance in the life and duties of a President when compared with the control of nuclear weapons. column5: controlled
column6: observable

column9: SALT I
column10: nor the Antiballistic Missile Treaty
column11: nor the Vladivostok Treaty negotiated with the Soviet Union by President Ford - and now he wants to throw into the wastebasket a treaty to control nuclear weapons on a balanced and equal basis between ourselves and the Soviet Union
column12: negotiated over a seven-year period
column13: by myself and my two Republican predecessors. The Senate has not voted yet on the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty. There have been preliminary skirmishing in the committees of the Senate
column14: but the Treaty has never come to the floor of the Senate for either a debate or a vote. It's understandable that a Senator in the preliminary debates can make an irresponsible statement

column1: Yes. Governor Reagan is making some very misleading and disturbing statements. He not only advocates the scrapping of this treaty - and I don't know that these men that he quotes are against the treaty in its final form - but he also advocates the possibility
column2: he said it's been a missing element
column3: of playing a trump card against the Soviet Union of a nuclear arms race
column4: and is insisting upon nuclear superiority by our own nation
column5: as a predication for negotiation in the future with the Soviet Union. If President Brezhnev said
column6: we will scrap this treaty
column7: negotiated under three American Presidents over a seven-year period of time
column8: we insist upon nuclear superiority as a basis for future negotiations
column9: and we believe that the launching of a nuclear arms race is a good basis for future negotiations
column10: it's obvious that I
column11: as President
column12: and all Americans
column13: would reject such a proposition. This would mean the resumption of a very dangerous nuclear arms race. It would be very disturbing to American people. It would change the basic tone and commitment that our nation has experienced ever since the Second World War
column14: with al Presidents
column15: Democratic and Republican. And it would also be very disturbing to our allies
column16: all of whom support this nuclear arms treaty. In addition to that
column17: the adversarial relationship between ourselves and the Soviet Union would undoubtedly deteriorate very rapidly. This attitude is extremely dangerous and belligerent in its tone
column18: although it's said with a quiet voice.

column1: I know the President's supposed to be replying to me
column2: but sometimes
column3: I have a hard time in connecting what he's saying
column4: with what I have said or what my positions are. I sometimes think he's like the witch doctor that gets mad when a good doctor comes along with a cure that'll work. My point I have made already
column5: Mr. President
column6: with regard to negotiating: it does not call for nuclear superiority on the part of the United States. It calls for a mutual reduction of these weapons
column7: as I say
column8: that neither of us can represent a threat to the other. And to suggest that the SALT II treaty that your negotiators negotiated was just a continuation
column9: and based on all of the preceding efforts by two previous Presidents
column10: is just not true. It was a new negotiation because
column11: as I say
column12: President Ford was within about 10% of having a solution that could be acceptable. And I think our allies would be very happy to go along with a fair and verifiable SALT agreement.

column2: to close out this discussion
column3: it would be better to put into perspective what we're talking about. I had a discussion with my daughter
column4: Amy
column5: the other day
column6: before I came here
column7: to ask her what the most important issue was. She said she thought nuclear weaponry - and the control of nuclear arms. This is a formidable force. Some of these weapons have 10 megatons of explosion. If you put 50 tons of TNT in each one of railroad cars
column8: you would have a carload of TNT - a trainload of TNT stretching across this nation. That's one major war explosion in a warhead. We have thousands
column9: equivalent of megaton
column10: or million tons
column11: of TNT warheads. The control of these weapons is the single major responsibility of a President
column12: and to cast out this commitment of all Presidents
column13: because of some slight technicalities that can be corrected
column14: is a very dangerous approach.
