column2: '28Oct'
column3: 6)	" I don't think there's any doubt that
column4: in the future
column5: the cost of oil is going to go up. What I've had as a basic commitment since I've been President is to reduce our dependence on foreign oil. It can only be done in two ways: one
column6: to conserve energy - to stop the waste of energy - and
column7: secondly
column8: to produce more American energy. We've been very successful in both cases. We've now reduced the importing of foreign oil in the last year alone by one-third. We imported today 2 million barrels of oil less than we did the same date just a year ago. This commitment has been opening up a very bright vista for our nation in the future
column9: because with the windfall profits tax as a base
column10: we now have an opportunity to use American technology and American ability and American natural resources to expand rapidly the production of synthetic fuels
column11: yes; to expand rapidly the production of solar energy
column12: yes; and also to produce the traditional kinds of American energy. We will drill more oil and gas wells this year than any year in history. We'll produce more coal this year than any year in history. We are exporting more coal this year than any year in history. And we have an opportunity now with improved transportation systems and improved loading facilities in our ports
column13: to see a very good opportunity on a world international market
column14: to replace OPEC oil with American coal as a basic energy source. This exciting future will not only give us more energy security
column15: but will also open up vast opportunities for Americans to live a better life and to have millions of new jobs associated with this new and very dynamic industry now in prospect because of the new energy policy that we've put into effect.

column1: I'm not so sure that it means steadily higher fuel costs
column2: but I do believe that this nation has been portrayed for too long a time to the people as being energy-poor when it is energy-rich. The coal that the President mentioned - yes
column3: we have it - and yet one-eighth of our total coal resources is not being utilized at all right now. The mines are closed down; there are 22000 miners out of work. Most of this is due to regulations which either interfere with the mining of it or prevent the burning of it:. With our modern technology
column4: yes
column5: we can burn our coal within the limits of the Clean Air Act. I think
column6: as technology improves
column7: we'll be able to do even better with that. The other thing is that we have only leased out - begun to explore - 2% of our outer continental shelf for oil
column8: where it is believed
column9: by everyone familiar with that fuel and that source of energy
column10: that there are vast supplies yet to be found. Our Government has
column11: in the last year or so
column12: taken out of multiple use millions of acres of public lands that once were - well
column13: they were public lands subject to multiple use - exploration for minerals and so forth. It is believed that probably 70% of the potential oil in the United States is probably hidden in those lands
column14: and no one is allowed to even go and explore to find out if it is there. This is particularly true of the recent efforts to shut down part of Alaska. Nuclear power: There were 36 power plants planned in this country. And let me add the word safety; it must be done with the utmost of safety. But 32 of those have given up and canceled their plans to build
column15: and again
column16: because Government regulations and permits
column17: and so forth
column18: take - make it take - more than twice as long to build a nuclear plant in the United States as it does to build one in Japan or in Western Europe. We have the sources here. We are energy rich
column19: and coal is one of the great potentials we have.

column2: we have this year the opportunity
column3: which we'll realize
column4: to produce 800 million tons of coal - an unequaled record in the history of our country. Governor Reagan says that this is not a good achievement
column5: and he blames restraints on coal production on regulations - regulations that affect the life and the health and safety of miners
column6: and also regulations that protect the purity of our air and the quality our water and our land. We cannot cast aside these regulations. We have a chance in the next 15 years
column7: insisting upon the health and safety of workers in the mines
column8: and also preserving the same high air and water pollution standards
column9: to triple the amount of coal we produce. Governor Reagan's approach to our energy policy
column10: which has already proven its effectiveness
column11: is to repeal
column12: or to change substantially
column13: the windfall profits tax - to return a major portion of $227 billion back to the oil companies; to do away with the Department of Energy; to short-circuit our synthetic fuels program; to put a minimal emphasis on solar power; to emphasize strongly nuclear power plants as a major source of energy in the future. He wants to put all our eggs in one basket and give that basket to the major oil companies.

column2: of course
column3: of my position. I just happen to believe that free enterprise can do a better job of producing the things that people need than government can. The Department of Energy has a multi-billion-dollar budget in excess of $10 billion. It hasn't produced a quart of oil or a lump of coal
column4: or anything else in the line of energy. And for Mr. Carter to suggest that I want to do away with the safety laws and with the laws that pertain to clean water and clean air
column5: and so forth. As Governor of California
column6: I took charge of passing the strictest air pollution laws in the United States - the strictest air quality law that has even been adopted in the United States. And we created an OSHA - an Occupational Safety and Health Agency - for the protection of employees before the Federal Government had one in place. And to this day
column7: not one of its decisions or rulings has ever been challenged. So
column8: I think some of those charges are missing the point. I am suggesting that there are literally thousands of unnecessary regulations that invade every facet of business
column9: and indeed
column10: very much of our personal lives
column11: that are unnecessary; that Government can do without; that have added $130 billion to the cost of production in this country; and that are contributing their part to inflation. And I would like to see us a little more free
column12: as we once were.

column3: 6)	" I don't think there's any doubt that
column4: in the future
column5: the cost of oil is going to go up. What I've had as a basic commitment since I've been President is to reduce our dependence on foreign oil. It can only be done in two ways: one
column6: to conserve energy - to stop the waste of energy - and
column7: secondly
column8: to produce more American energy. We've been very successful in both cases. We've now reduced the importing of foreign oil in the last year alone by one-third. We imported today 2 million barrels of oil less than we did the same date just a year ago. This commitment has been opening up a very bright vista for our nation in the future
column9: because with the windfall profits tax as a base
column10: we now have an opportunity to use American technology and American ability and American natural resources to expand rapidly the production of synthetic fuels
column11: yes; to expand rapidly the production of solar energy
column12: yes; and also to produce the traditional kinds of American energy. We will drill more oil and gas wells this year than any year in history. We'll produce more coal this year than any year in history. We are exporting more coal this year than any year in history. And we have an opportunity now with improved transportation systems and improved loading facilities in our ports
column13: to see a very good opportunity on a world international market
column14: to replace OPEC oil with American coal as a basic energy source. This exciting future will not only give us more energy security
column15: but will also open up vast opportunities for Americans to live a better life and to have millions of new jobs associated with this new and very dynamic industry now in prospect because of the new energy policy that we've put into effect.

column1: I'm not so sure that it means steadily higher fuel costs
column2: but I do believe that this nation has been portrayed for too long a time to the people as being energy-poor when it is energy-rich. The coal that the President mentioned - yes
column3: we have it - and yet one-eighth of our total coal resources is not being utilized at all right now. The mines are closed down; there are 22000 miners out of work. Most of this is due to regulations which either interfere with the mining of it or prevent the burning of it:. With our modern technology
column4: yes

column14: and no one is allowed to even go and explore to find out if it is there. This is particularly true of the recent efforts to shut down part of Alaska. Nuclear power: There were 36 power plants planned in this country. And let me add the word safety; it must be done with the utmost of safety. But 32 of those have given up and canceled their plans to build

column18: take - make it take - more than twice as long to build a nuclear plant in the United States as it does to build one in Japan or in Western Europe. We have the sources here. We are energy rich
column19: and coal is one of the great potentials we have.

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 6)	" I don't think there's any doubt that
column4: in the future
column5: the cost of oil is going to go up. What I've had as a basic commitment since I've been President is to reduce our dependence on foreign oil. It can only be done in two ways: one
column6: to conserve energy - to stop the waste of energy - and
column7: secondly
column8: to produce more American energy. We've been very successful in both cases. We've now reduced the importing of foreign oil in the last year alone by one-third. We imported today 2 million barrels of oil less than we did the same date just a year ago. This commitment has been opening up a very bright vista for our nation in the future
column9: because with the windfall profits tax as a base
column10: we now have an opportunity to use American technology and American ability and American natural resources to expand rapidly the production of synthetic fuels
column11: yes; to expand rapidly the production of solar energy
column12: yes; and also to produce the traditional kinds of American energy. We will drill more oil and gas wells this year than any year in history. We'll produce more coal this year than any year in history. We are exporting more coal this year than any year in history. And we have an opportunity now with improved transportation systems and improved loading facilities in our ports
column13: to see a very good opportunity on a world international market
column14: to replace OPEC oil with American coal as a basic energy source. This exciting future will not only give us more energy security
column15: but will also open up vast opportunities for Americans to live a better life and to have millions of new jobs associated with this new and very dynamic industry now in prospect because of the new energy policy that we've put into effect.

column1: I'm not so sure that it means steadily higher fuel costs
column2: but I do believe that this nation has been portrayed for too long a time to the people as being energy-poor when it is energy-rich. The coal that the President mentioned - yes
column3: we have it - and yet one-eighth of our total coal resources is not being utilized at all right now. The mines are closed down; there are 22000 miners out of work. Most of this is due to regulations which either interfere with the mining of it or prevent the burning of it:. With our modern technology
column4: yes
column5: we can burn our coal within the limits of the Clean Air Act. I think
column6: as technology improves
column7: we'll be able to do even better with that. The other thing is that we have only leased out - begun to explore - 2% of our outer continental shelf for oil
column8: where it is believed
column9: by everyone familiar with that fuel and that source of energy
column10: that there are vast supplies yet to be found. Our Government has
column11: in the last year or so
column12: taken out of multiple use millions of acres of public lands that once were - well
column13: they were public lands subject to multiple use - exploration for minerals and so forth. It is believed that probably 70% of the potential oil in the United States is probably hidden in those lands
column14: and no one is allowed to even go and explore to find out if it is there. This is particularly true of the recent efforts to shut down part of Alaska. Nuclear power: There were 36 power plants planned in this country. And let me add the word safety; it must be done with the utmost of safety. But 32 of those have given up and canceled their plans to build
column15: and again
column16: because Government regulations and permits
column17: and so forth
column18: take - make it take - more than twice as long to build a nuclear plant in the United States as it does to build one in Japan or in Western Europe. We have the sources here. We are energy rich
column19: and coal is one of the great potentials we have.

column2: we have this year the opportunity
column3: which we'll realize
column4: to produce 800 million tons of coal - an unequaled record in the history of our country. Governor Reagan says that this is not a good achievement
column5: and he blames restraints on coal production on regulations - regulations that affect the life and the health and safety of miners
column6: and also regulations that protect the purity of our air and the quality our water and our land. We cannot cast aside these regulations. We have a chance in the next 15 years
column7: insisting upon the health and safety of workers in the mines
column8: and also preserving the same high air and water pollution standards
column9: to triple the amount of coal we produce. Governor Reagan's approach to our energy policy
column10: which has already proven its effectiveness
column11: is to repeal
column12: or to change substantially
column13: the windfall profits tax - to return a major portion of $227 billion back to the oil companies; to do away with the Department of Energy; to short-circuit our synthetic fuels program; to put a minimal emphasis on solar power; to emphasize strongly nuclear power plants as a major source of energy in the future. He wants to put all our eggs in one basket and give that basket to the major oil companies.

column2: of course
column3: of my position. I just happen to believe that free enterprise can do a better job of producing the things that people need than government can. The Department of Energy has a multi-billion-dollar budget in excess of $10 billion. It hasn't produced a quart of oil or a lump of coal
column4: or anything else in the line of energy. And for Mr. Carter to suggest that I want to do away with the safety laws and with the laws that pertain to clean water and clean air
column5: and so forth. As Governor of California
column6: I took charge of passing the strictest air pollution laws in the United States - the strictest air quality law that has even been adopted in the United States. And we created an OSHA - an Occupational Safety and Health Agency - for the protection of employees before the Federal Government had one in place. And to this day
column7: not one of its decisions or rulings has ever been challenged. So
column8: I think some of those charges are missing the point. I am suggesting that there are literally thousands of unnecessary regulations that invade every facet of business
column9: and indeed
column10: very much of our personal lives
column11: that are unnecessary; that Government can do without; that have added $130 billion to the cost of production in this country; and that are contributing their part to inflation. And I would like to see us a little more free
column12: as we once were.

column1: Sure. As a matter of fact

column3: and this is a very well-known fact. Also

column7: amen. The offshore drilling rights is a question that Governor Reagan raises often. As a matter of fact

column9: 100% of all the offshore lands would be open for exploration
column10: and 95% of all the Alaska lands

column13: proposed more land to be drilled than has been opened up for drilling since this program first started in 1954. So we're not putting restraints on American exploration
column14: we're encouraging it in every way we can.

column1: Yes. If it is a well-known fact that I opposed air pollution laws in California

column6: I must say

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 6)	" I don't think there's any doubt that
column4: in the future
column5: the cost of oil is going to go up. What I've had as a basic commitment since I've been President is to reduce our dependence on foreign oil. It can only be done in two ways: one
column6: to conserve energy - to stop the waste of energy - and
column7: secondly
column8: to produce more American energy. We've been very successful in both cases. We've now reduced the importing of foreign oil in the last year alone by one-third. We imported today 2 million barrels of oil less than we did the same date just a year ago. This commitment has been opening up a very bright vista for our nation in the future
column9: because with the windfall profits tax as a base
column10: we now have an opportunity to use American technology and American ability and American natural resources to expand rapidly the production of synthetic fuels
column11: yes; to expand rapidly the production of solar energy
column12: yes; and also to produce the traditional kinds of American energy. We will drill more oil and gas wells this year than any year in history. We'll produce more coal this year than any year in history. We are exporting more coal this year than any year in history. And we have an opportunity now with improved transportation systems and improved loading facilities in our ports
column13: to see a very good opportunity on a world international market
column14: to replace OPEC oil with American coal as a basic energy source. This exciting future will not only give us more energy security
column15: but will also open up vast opportunities for Americans to live a better life and to have millions of new jobs associated with this new and very dynamic industry now in prospect because of the new energy policy that we've put into effect.

column1: I'm not so sure that it means steadily higher fuel costs
column2: but I do believe that this nation has been portrayed for too long a time to the people as being energy-poor when it is energy-rich. The coal that the President mentioned - yes
column3: we have it - and yet one-eighth of our total coal resources is not being utilized at all right now. The mines are closed down; there are 22000 miners out of work. Most of this is due to regulations which either interfere with the mining of it or prevent the burning of it:. With our modern technology
column4: yes
column5: we can burn our coal within the limits of the Clean Air Act. I think
column6: as technology improves
column7: we'll be able to do even better with that. The other thing is that we have only leased out - begun to explore - 2% of our outer continental shelf for oil
column8: where it is believed
column9: by everyone familiar with that fuel and that source of energy
column10: that there are vast supplies yet to be found. Our Government has
column11: in the last year or so
column12: taken out of multiple use millions of acres of public lands that once were - well
column13: they were public lands subject to multiple use - exploration for minerals and so forth. It is believed that probably 70% of the potential oil in the United States is probably hidden in those lands
column14: and no one is allowed to even go and explore to find out if it is there. This is particularly true of the recent efforts to shut down part of Alaska. Nuclear power: There were 36 power plants planned in this country. And let me add the word safety; it must be done with the utmost of safety. But 32 of those have given up and canceled their plans to build
column15: and again
column16: because Government regulations and permits
column17: and so forth
column18: take - make it take - more than twice as long to build a nuclear plant in the United States as it does to build one in Japan or in Western Europe. We have the sources here. We are energy rich
column19: and coal is one of the great potentials we have.

column2: we have this year the opportunity
column3: which we'll realize
column4: to produce 800 million tons of coal - an unequaled record in the history of our country. Governor Reagan says that this is not a good achievement
column5: and he blames restraints on coal production on regulations - regulations that affect the life and the health and safety of miners
column6: and also regulations that protect the purity of our air and the quality our water and our land. We cannot cast aside these regulations. We have a chance in the next 15 years
column7: insisting upon the health and safety of workers in the mines
column8: and also preserving the same high air and water pollution standards
column9: to triple the amount of coal we produce. Governor Reagan's approach to our energy policy
column10: which has already proven its effectiveness
column11: is to repeal
column12: or to change substantially
column13: the windfall profits tax - to return a major portion of $227 billion back to the oil companies; to do away with the Department of Energy; to short-circuit our synthetic fuels program; to put a minimal emphasis on solar power; to emphasize strongly nuclear power plants as a major source of energy in the future. He wants to put all our eggs in one basket and give that basket to the major oil companies.

column2: of course
column3: of my position. I just happen to believe that free enterprise can do a better job of producing the things that people need than government can. The Department of Energy has a multi-billion-dollar budget in excess of $10 billion. It hasn't produced a quart of oil or a lump of coal
column4: or anything else in the line of energy. And for Mr. Carter to suggest that I want to do away with the safety laws and with the laws that pertain to clean water and clean air
column5: and so forth. As Governor of California
column6: I took charge of passing the strictest air pollution laws in the United States - the strictest air quality law that has even been adopted in the United States. And we created an OSHA - an Occupational Safety and Health Agency - for the protection of employees before the Federal Government had one in place. And to this day
column7: not one of its decisions or rulings has ever been challenged. So
column8: I think some of those charges are missing the point. I am suggesting that there are literally thousands of unnecessary regulations that invade every facet of business
column9: and indeed
column10: very much of our personal lives
column11: that are unnecessary; that Government can do without; that have added $130 billion to the cost of production in this country; and that are contributing their part to inflation. And I would like to see us a little more free
column12: as we once were.

column1: Sure. As a matter of fact
column2: . the air pollution standard laws that were passed in California were passed over the objections of Governor Reagan
column3: and this is a very well-known fact. Also
column4: recently
column5: when someone suggested that the Occupational Safety and Health Act should be abolished
column6: Governor Reagan responded
column7: amen. The offshore drilling rights is a question that Governor Reagan raises often. As a matter of fact
column8: in the proposal for the Alaska lands legislation
column9: 100% of all the offshore lands would be open for exploration
column10: and 95% of all the Alaska lands
column11: where it is suspected or believed that minerals might exist. We have
column12: with our five-year plan for the leasing of offshore lands
column13: proposed more land to be drilled than has been opened up for drilling since this program first started in 1954. So we're not putting restraints on American exploration
column14: we're encouraging it in every way we can.

column1: Yes. If it is a well-known fact that I opposed air pollution laws in California
column2: the only thing I can possibly think of is that the President must be suggesting the law that the Federal Government tried to impose on the State of California - not a law
column3: but regulations - that would have made it impossible to drive an automobile within the city limits of any California city
column4: or to have a place to put it if you did drive it against their regulations. It would have destroyed the economy of California
column5: and
column6: I must say
column7: we had the support of Congress when we pointed out how ridiculous this attempt was by the Environmental Protection Agency. We still have the strictest air control
column8: or air pollution laws in the country. As for offshore oiling
column9: only 2% now is so leased and is producing oil. The rest
column10: as to whether the lands are going to be opened in the next five years or so - we're already five years behind in what we should be doing. There is more oil now
column11: in the wells that have been drilled
column12: than has been taken out in 121 years that they've been drilled.

column3: 6)	" I don't think there's any doubt that
column4: in the future
column5: the cost of oil is going to go up. What I've had as a basic commitment since I've been President is to reduce our dependence on foreign oil. It can only be done in two ways: one
column6: to conserve energy - to stop the waste of energy - and
column7: secondly
column8: to produce more American energy. We've been very successful in both cases. We've now reduced the importing of foreign oil in the last year alone by one-third. We imported today 2 million barrels of oil less than we did the same date just a year ago. This commitment has been opening up a very bright vista for our nation in the future
column9: because with the windfall profits tax as a base
column10: we now have an opportunity to use American technology and American ability and American natural resources to expand rapidly the production of synthetic fuels
column11: yes; to expand rapidly the production of solar energy
column12: yes; and also to produce the traditional kinds of American energy. We will drill more oil and gas wells this year than any year in history. We'll produce more coal this year than any year in history. We are exporting more coal this year than any year in history. And we have an opportunity now with improved transportation systems and improved loading facilities in our ports
column13: to see a very good opportunity on a world international market
column14: to replace OPEC oil with American coal as a basic energy source. This exciting future will not only give us more energy security
column15: but will also open up vast opportunities for Americans to live a better life and to have millions of new jobs associated with this new and very dynamic industry now in prospect because of the new energy policy that we've put into effect.

column1: I'm not so sure that it means steadily higher fuel costs

column3: 6)	" I don't think there's any doubt that
column4: in the future
column5: the cost of oil is going to go up. What I've had as a basic commitment since I've been President is to reduce our dependence on foreign oil. It can only be done in two ways: one
column6: to conserve energy - to stop the waste of energy - and
column7: secondly
column8: to produce more American energy. We've been very successful in both cases. We've now reduced the importing of foreign oil in the last year alone by one-third. We imported today 2 million barrels of oil less than we did the same date just a year ago. This commitment has been opening up a very bright vista for our nation in the future
column9: because with the windfall profits tax as a base
column10: we now have an opportunity to use American technology and American ability and American natural resources to expand rapidly the production of synthetic fuels
column11: yes; to expand rapidly the production of solar energy
column12: yes; and also to produce the traditional kinds of American energy. We will drill more oil and gas wells this year than any year in history. We'll produce more coal this year than any year in history. We are exporting more coal this year than any year in history. And we have an opportunity now with improved transportation systems and improved loading facilities in our ports
column13: to see a very good opportunity on a world international market
column14: to replace OPEC oil with American coal as a basic energy source. This exciting future will not only give us more energy security
column15: but will also open up vast opportunities for Americans to live a better life and to have millions of new jobs associated with this new and very dynamic industry now in prospect because of the new energy policy that we've put into effect.

column1: I'm not so sure that it means steadily higher fuel costs
column2: but I do believe that this nation has been portrayed for too long a time to the people as being energy-poor when it is energy-rich. The coal that the President mentioned - yes
column3: we have it - and yet one-eighth of our total coal resources is not being utilized at all right now. The mines are closed down; there are 22000 miners out of work. Most of this is due to regulations which either interfere with the mining of it or prevent the burning of it:. With our modern technology
column4: yes
column5: we can burn our coal within the limits of the Clean Air Act. I think

column14: and no one is allowed to even go and explore to find out if it is there. This is particularly true of the recent efforts to shut down part of Alaska. Nuclear power: There were 36 power plants planned in this country. And let me add the word safety; it must be done with the utmost of safety. But 32 of those have given up and canceled their plans to build
column15: and again
column16: because Government regulations and permits
column17: and so forth
column18: take - make it take - more than twice as long to build a nuclear plant in the United States as it does to build one in Japan or in Western Europe. We have the sources here. We are energy rich
column19: and coal is one of the great potentials we have.

He wants to put all our eggs in one basket and give that basket to the major oil companies.

column3: of my position. I just happen to believe that free enterprise can do a better job of producing the things that people need than government can. The Department of Energy has a multi-billion-dollar budget in excess of $10 billion. It hasn't produced a quart of oil or a lump of coal
column4: or anything else in the line of energy. And for Mr. Carter to suggest that I want to do away with the safety laws and with the laws that pertain to clean water and clean air

column3: 6)	" I don't think there's any doubt that
column4: in the future
column5: the cost of oil is going to go up. What I've had as a basic commitment since I've been President is to reduce our dependence on foreign oil. It can only be done in two ways: one
column6: to conserve energy - to stop the waste of energy - and
column7: secondly
column8: to produce more American energy. We've been very successful in both cases. We've now reduced the importing of foreign oil in the last year alone by one-third. We imported today 2 million barrels of oil less than we did the same date just a year ago. This commitment has been opening up a very bright vista for our nation in the future
column9: because with the windfall profits tax as a base
column10: we now have an opportunity to use American technology and American ability and American natural resources to expand rapidly the production of synthetic fuels
column11: yes; to expand rapidly the production of solar energy
column12: yes; and also to produce the traditional kinds of American energy. We will drill more oil and gas wells this year than any year in history. We'll produce more coal this year than any year in history. We are exporting more coal this year than any year in history. And we have an opportunity now with improved transportation systems and improved loading facilities in our ports
column13: to see a very good opportunity on a world international market
column14: to replace OPEC oil with American coal as a basic energy source. This exciting future will not only give us more energy security
column15: but will also open up vast opportunities for Americans to live a better life and to have millions of new jobs associated with this new and very dynamic industry now in prospect because of the new energy policy that we've put into effect.

column1: I'm not so sure that it means steadily higher fuel costs
column2: but I do believe that this nation has been portrayed for too long a time to the people as being energy-poor when it is energy-rich. The coal that the President mentioned - yes
column3: we have it - and yet one-eighth of our total coal resources is not being utilized at all right now. The mines are closed down; there are 22000 miners out of work. Most of this is due to regulations which either interfere with the mining of it or prevent the burning of it:. With our modern technology
column4: yes
column5: we can burn our coal within the limits of the Clean Air Act. I think

column7: we'll be able to do even better with that. The other thing is that we have only leased out - begun to explore - 2% of our outer continental shelf for oil
column8: where it is believed

column10: that there are vast supplies yet to be found. Our Government has
column11: in the last year or so
column12: taken out of multiple use millions of acres of public lands that once were - well
column13: they were public lands subject to multiple use - exploration for minerals and so forth. It is believed that probably 70% of the potential oil in the United States is probably hidden in those lands
column14: and no one is allowed to even go and explore to find out if it is there. This is particularly true of the recent efforts to shut down part of Alaska. Nuclear power: There were 36 power plants planned in this country. And let me add the word safety; it must be done with the utmost of safety. But 32 of those have given up and canceled their plans to build
column15: and again

column17: and so forth
column18: take - make it take - more than twice as long to build a nuclear plant in the United States as it does to build one in Japan or in Western Europe. We have the sources here. We are energy rich
column19: and coal is one of the great potentials we have.

column2: we have this year the opportunity
column3: which we'll realize
column4: to produce 800 million tons of coal - an unequaled record in the history of our country. Governor Reagan says that this is not a good achievement
column5: and he blames restraints on coal production on regulations - regulations that affect the life and the health and safety of miners
column6: and also regulations that protect the purity of our air and the quality our water and our land. We cannot cast aside these regulations. We have a chance in the next 15 years
column7: insisting upon the health and safety of workers in the mines
column8: and also preserving the same high air and water pollution standards
column9: to triple the amount of coal we produce. Governor Reagan's approach to our energy policy

column11: is to repeal

He wants to put all our eggs in one basket and give that basket to the major oil companies.

column3: of my position. I just happen to believe that free enterprise can do a better job of producing the things that people need than government can. The Department of Energy has a multi-billion-dollar budget in excess of $10 billion. It hasn't produced a quart of oil or a lump of coal
column4: or anything else in the line of energy. And for Mr. Carter to suggest that I want to do away with the safety laws and with the laws that pertain to clean water and clean air
column5: and so forth. As Governor of California

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 6)	" I don't think there's any doubt that
column4: in the future
column5: the cost of oil is going to go up. What I've had as a basic commitment since I've been President is to reduce our dependence on foreign oil. It can only be done in two ways: one
column6: to conserve energy - to stop the waste of energy - and
column7: secondly
column8: to produce more American energy. We've been very successful in both cases. We've now reduced the importing of foreign oil in the last year alone by one-third. We imported today 2 million barrels of oil less than we did the same date just a year ago. This commitment has been opening up a very bright vista for our nation in the future
column9: because with the windfall profits tax as a base
column10: we now have an opportunity to use American technology and American ability and American natural resources to expand rapidly the production of synthetic fuels
column11: yes; to expand rapidly the production of solar energy
column12: yes; and also to produce the traditional kinds of American energy. We will drill more oil and gas wells this year than any year in history. We'll produce more coal this year than any year in history. We are exporting more coal this year than any year in history. And we have an opportunity now with improved transportation systems and improved loading facilities in our ports
column13: to see a very good opportunity on a world international market
column14: to replace OPEC oil with American coal as a basic energy source. This exciting future will not only give us more energy security
column15: but will also open up vast opportunities for Americans to live a better life and to have millions of new jobs associated with this new and very dynamic industry now in prospect because of the new energy policy that we've put into effect.

column1: I'm not so sure that it means steadily higher fuel costs
column2: but I do believe that this nation has been portrayed for too long a time to the people as being energy-poor when it is energy-rich. The coal that the President mentioned - yes
column3: we have it - and yet one-eighth of our total coal resources is not being utilized at all right now. The mines are closed down; there are 22000 miners out of work. Most of this is due to regulations which either interfere with the mining of it or prevent the burning of it:. With our modern technology
column4: yes
column5: we can burn our coal within the limits of the Clean Air Act. I think
column6: as technology improves
column7: we'll be able to do even better with that. The other thing is that we have only leased out - begun to explore - 2% of our outer continental shelf for oil
column8: where it is believed
column9: by everyone familiar with that fuel and that source of energy
column10: that there are vast supplies yet to be found. Our Government has
column11: in the last year or so
column12: taken out of multiple use millions of acres of public lands that once were - well
column13: they were public lands subject to multiple use - exploration for minerals and so forth. It is believed that probably 70% of the potential oil in the United States is probably hidden in those lands
column14: and no one is allowed to even go and explore to find out if it is there. This is particularly true of the recent efforts to shut down part of Alaska. Nuclear power: There were 36 power plants planned in this country. And let me add the word safety; it must be done with the utmost of safety. But 32 of those have given up and canceled their plans to build
column15: and again
column16: because Government regulations and permits
column17: and so forth
column18: take - make it take - more than twice as long to build a nuclear plant in the United States as it does to build one in Japan or in Western Europe. We have the sources here. We are energy rich
column19: and coal is one of the great potentials we have.

column2: we have this year the opportunity
column3: which we'll realize
column4: to produce 800 million tons of coal - an unequaled record in the history of our country. Governor Reagan says that this is not a good achievement
column5: and he blames restraints on coal production on regulations - regulations that affect the life and the health and safety of miners
column6: and also regulations that protect the purity of our air and the quality our water and our land. We cannot cast aside these regulations. We have a chance in the next 15 years
column7: insisting upon the health and safety of workers in the mines
column8: and also preserving the same high air and water pollution standards
column9: to triple the amount of coal we produce. Governor Reagan's approach to our energy policy
column10: which has already proven its effectiveness
column11: is to repeal
column12: or to change substantially
column13: the windfall profits tax - to return a major portion of $227 billion back to the oil companies; to do away with the Department of Energy; to short-circuit our synthetic fuels program; to put a minimal emphasis on solar power; to emphasize strongly nuclear power plants as a major source of energy in the future. He wants to put all our eggs in one basket and give that basket to the major oil companies.

column2: of course
column3: of my position. I just happen to believe that free enterprise can do a better job of producing the things that people need than government can. The Department of Energy has a multi-billion-dollar budget in excess of $10 billion. It hasn't produced a quart of oil or a lump of coal
column4: or anything else in the line of energy. And for Mr. Carter to suggest that I want to do away with the safety laws and with the laws that pertain to clean water and clean air
column5: and so forth. As Governor of California
column6: I took charge of passing the strictest air pollution laws in the United States - the strictest air quality law that has even been adopted in the United States. And we created an OSHA - an Occupational Safety and Health Agency - for the protection of employees before the Federal Government had one in place. And to this day
column7: not one of its decisions or rulings has ever been challenged. So
column8: I think some of those charges are missing the point. I am suggesting that there are literally thousands of unnecessary regulations that invade every facet of business
column9: and indeed
column10: very much of our personal lives
column11: that are unnecessary; that Government can do without; that have added $130 billion to the cost of production in this country; and that are contributing their part to inflation. And I would like to see us a little more free
column12: as we once were.

column9: 100% of all the offshore lands would be open for exploration

column13: proposed more land to be drilled than has been opened up for drilling since this program first started in 1954. So we're not putting restraints on American exploration
column14: we're encouraging it in every way we can.

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 6)	" I don't think there's any doubt that
column4: in the future
column5: the cost of oil is going to go up. What I've had as a basic commitment since I've been President is to reduce our dependence on foreign oil. It can only be done in two ways: one
column6: to conserve energy - to stop the waste of energy - and
column7: secondly
column8: to produce more American energy. We've been very successful in both cases. We've now reduced the importing of foreign oil in the last year alone by one-third. We imported today 2 million barrels of oil less than we did the same date just a year ago. This commitment has been opening up a very bright vista for our nation in the future
column9: because with the windfall profits tax as a base
column10: we now have an opportunity to use American technology and American ability and American natural resources to expand rapidly the production of synthetic fuels
column11: yes; to expand rapidly the production of solar energy
column12: yes; and also to produce the traditional kinds of American energy. We will drill more oil and gas wells this year than any year in history. We'll produce more coal this year than any year in history. We are exporting more coal this year than any year in history. And we have an opportunity now with improved transportation systems and improved loading facilities in our ports
column13: to see a very good opportunity on a world international market
column14: to replace OPEC oil with American coal as a basic energy source. This exciting future will not only give us more energy security
column15: but will also open up vast opportunities for Americans to live a better life and to have millions of new jobs associated with this new and very dynamic industry now in prospect because of the new energy policy that we've put into effect.

column1: I'm not so sure that it means steadily higher fuel costs
column2: but I do believe that this nation has been portrayed for too long a time to the people as being energy-poor when it is energy-rich. The coal that the President mentioned - yes
column3: we have it - and yet one-eighth of our total coal resources is not being utilized at all right now. The mines are closed down; there are 22000 miners out of work. Most of this is due to regulations which either interfere with the mining of it or prevent the burning of it:. With our modern technology
column4: yes
column5: we can burn our coal within the limits of the Clean Air Act. I think
column6: as technology improves
column7: we'll be able to do even better with that. The other thing is that we have only leased out - begun to explore - 2% of our outer continental shelf for oil
column8: where it is believed
column9: by everyone familiar with that fuel and that source of energy
column10: that there are vast supplies yet to be found. Our Government has
column11: in the last year or so
column12: taken out of multiple use millions of acres of public lands that once were - well
column13: they were public lands subject to multiple use - exploration for minerals and so forth. It is believed that probably 70% of the potential oil in the United States is probably hidden in those lands
column14: and no one is allowed to even go and explore to find out if it is there. This is particularly true of the recent efforts to shut down part of Alaska. Nuclear power: There were 36 power plants planned in this country. And let me add the word safety; it must be done with the utmost of safety. But 32 of those have given up and canceled their plans to build
column15: and again
column16: because Government regulations and permits
column17: and so forth
column18: take - make it take - more than twice as long to build a nuclear plant in the United States as it does to build one in Japan or in Western Europe. We have the sources here. We are energy rich
column19: and coal is one of the great potentials we have.

column2: we have this year the opportunity
column3: which we'll realize
column4: to produce 800 million tons of coal - an unequaled record in the history of our country. Governor Reagan says that this is not a good achievement
column5: and he blames restraints on coal production on regulations - regulations that affect the life and the health and safety of miners
column6: and also regulations that protect the purity of our air and the quality our water and our land. We cannot cast aside these regulations. We have a chance in the next 15 years
column7: insisting upon the health and safety of workers in the mines
column8: and also preserving the same high air and water pollution standards
column9: to triple the amount of coal we produce. Governor Reagan's approach to our energy policy
column10: which has already proven its effectiveness
column11: is to repeal
column12: or to change substantially
column13: the windfall profits tax - to return a major portion of $227 billion back to the oil companies; to do away with the Department of Energy; to short-circuit our synthetic fuels program; to put a minimal emphasis on solar power; to emphasize strongly nuclear power plants as a major source of energy in the future. He wants to put all our eggs in one basket and give that basket to the major oil companies.

column2: of course
column3: of my position. I just happen to believe that free enterprise can do a better job of producing the things that people need than government can. The Department of Energy has a multi-billion-dollar budget in excess of $10 billion. It hasn't produced a quart of oil or a lump of coal
column4: or anything else in the line of energy. And for Mr. Carter to suggest that I want to do away with the safety laws and with the laws that pertain to clean water and clean air
column5: and so forth. As Governor of California
column6: I took charge of passing the strictest air pollution laws in the United States - the strictest air quality law that has even been adopted in the United States. And we created an OSHA - an Occupational Safety and Health Agency - for the protection of employees before the Federal Government had one in place. And to this day
column7: not one of its decisions or rulings has ever been challenged. So
column8: I think some of those charges are missing the point. I am suggesting that there are literally thousands of unnecessary regulations that invade every facet of business
column9: and indeed
column10: very much of our personal lives
column11: that are unnecessary; that Government can do without; that have added $130 billion to the cost of production in this country; and that are contributing their part to inflation. And I would like to see us a little more free
column12: as we once were.

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 7)	" The Social Security system was based on a false premise
column4: with regard to how fast the number of workers would increase and how fast the number of retirees would increase. It is actuarially out of balance
column5: and this first became evident about 16 years ago
column6: and some of us were voicing warnings then. Now
column7: it is trillions of dollars out of balance
column8: and the only answer that has come so far is the biggest single tax increase in our nation's history - the payroll tax increase for Social Security - which will only put a band-aid on this and postpone the day of reckoning by a few years at most. What is needed is a study that I have proposed by a task force of experts to look into this entire problem as to how it can be reformed and made actuarially sound
column9: but with the premise that no one presently dependent on Social Security is going to have the rug pulled out from under them and not get their check. We cannot frighten
column10: as we have with the threats and the campaign rhetoric that has gone on in this campaign
column11: our senior citizens - leave them thinking that in some way
column12: they're endangered and they would have no place to turn. They must continue to get those checks
column13: and I believe that the system can be put on a sound actuarial basis. But it's going to take some study and some work
column14: and not just passing a tax increase to let the load - or the roof - fall in on the next administration.

column1: As long as there is a Democratic President in the White House
column2: we will have a strong and viable Social Security System
column3: free of the threat of bankruptcy. Although Governor Reagan has changed his position lately
column4: on four different occasions
column5: he has advocated making Social Security a voluntary system
column6: which would
column7: in effect
column8: very quickly bankrupt it. I noticed also in The Wall Street Journal early this week
column9: that a preliminary report of his task force advocates making Social Security more sound by reducing the adjustment in Social Security for the retired people to compensate for the impact of inflation. These kinds of approaches are very dangerous to the security
column10: the well being and the peace of mind of the retired people of this country and those approaching retirement age. But no matter what it takes in the future to keep Social Security sound
column11: it must be kept that way. And although there was a serious threat to the Social Security System and its integrity during the 1976 campaign and when I became President
column12: the action of the Democratic Congress working with me has been to put Social Security back on a sound financial basis. That is the way it will stay.

column2: that just isn't true. It has
column3: as I said
column4: delayed the actuarial imbalance falling on us for just a few years with that increase in taxes
column5: and I don't believe we can go on increasing the tax
column6: because the problem for the young people today is that they are paying in far more than they can ever expect to get out. Now
column7: again this statement that somehow
column8: I wanted to destroy it and I just changed my tune
column9: that I am for voluntary Social Security
column10: which would mean the ruin of it. Mr. President
column11: the voluntary thing that I suggested many years ago was that with a young man orphaned and raised by an aunt who died
column12: his aunt was ineligible for Social Security insurance because she was not his mother. And I suggested that if this is an insurance program
column13: certainly the person who is paying in should be able to name his own beneficiary. That is the closest I have ever come to anything voluntary with Social Security. I
column14: too
column15: am pledged to a Social Security program that will reassure these senior citizens of ours that they are going to continue to get their money. There are some changes that I would like to make. I would like to make a change in the regulation that discriminates against a wife who works and finds that she then is faced with a choice between her father's or her husband's benefits
column16: if he dies first
column17: or what she has paid in; but it does not recognize that she has also been paying in herself
column18: and she is entitled to more than she presently can get. I'd like to change that.

column1: These constant suggestions that the basic Social Security System should be changed does call for concern and consternation among the aged of our country. It is obvious that we should have a commitment to them
column2: that Social Security benefits should not be taxed and that there would be no peremptory change in the standards by which Social Security payments are made to retired people. We also need to continue to index Social Security payments
column3: so that if inflation rises
column4: the Social Security payments would rise a commensurate degree to let the buying power of a Social Security check continue intact. In the past
column5: the relationship between Social Security and Medicare has been very important to providing some modicum of aid for senior citizens in the retention of health benefits. Governor Reagan
column6: as a matter of fact
column7: began his political career campaigning around this nation against Medicare. Now
column8: we have an opportunity to move toward national health insurance
column9: with an emphasis on the prevention of disease
column10: an emphasis on out-patient care
column11: not in-patient care; an emphasis on hospital cost containment to hold down the cost of hospital care far those who are ill
column12: an emphasis on catastrophic health insurance
column13: so that if a family is threatened with being wiped out economically because of a very high medical bill
column14: then the insurance would help pay for it. These are the kinds of elements of a national health insurance
column15: important to the American people. Governor Reagan
column16: again
column17: typically is against such a proposal.

column2: there was another piece of legislation meeting the same problem before the Congress. I happened to favor the other piece of legislation and thought that it would be better for the senior citizens and provide better care than the one that was finally passed. I was not opposing the principle of providing care for them. I was opposing one piece of legislation versus another. There is something else about Social Security. Of course
column3: it doesn't come out of the payroll tax. It comes out of a general fund
column4: but something should be done about it. I think it is disgraceful that the Disability Insurance Fund in Social Security finds checks going every month to tens of thousands of people who are locked up in our institutions for crime or for mental illness
column5: and they are receiving disability checks from Social Security every month while a state institution provides for all of their needs and their care.

column1: I think this debate on Social Security
column2: Medicare
column3: national health insurance typifies
column4: as vividly any other subject tonight
column5: the basic historical differences between the Democratic Party and Republican Party. The allusions to basic changes in the minimum wage is another
column6: and the deleterious comments that Governor Reagan has made about unemployment compensation. These commitments that the Democratic Party has historically made to the working families of this nation have been extremely important to the growth in their stature and in a better quality of life for them. I noticed recently that Governor Reagan frequently quotes Democratic presidents in his acceptance address. I have never heard a candidate for President
column7: who is a Republican
column8: quote a Republican president
column9: but when they get in office
column10: they try to govern like Republicans. So
column11: it is good fo the American people to remember that there is a sharp basic historical difference between Governor Reagan and me on these crucial issues - also
column12: between the two parties that we represent.

What is needed is a study that I have proposed by a task force of experts to look into this entire problem as to how it can be reformed and made actuarially sound
column9: but with the premise that no one presently dependent on Social Security is going to have the rug pulled out from under them and not get their check. We cannot frighten

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 7)	" The Social Security system was based on a false premise
column4: with regard to how fast the number of workers would increase and how fast the number of retirees would increase. It is actuarially out of balance
column5: and this first became evident about 16 years ago
column6: and some of us were voicing warnings then. Now
column7: it is trillions of dollars out of balance
column8: and the only answer that has come so far is the biggest single tax increase in our nation's history - the payroll tax increase for Social Security - which will only put a band-aid on this and postpone the day of reckoning by a few years at most. What is needed is a study that I have proposed by a task force of experts to look into this entire problem as to how it can be reformed and made actuarially sound
column9: but with the premise that no one presently dependent on Social Security is going to have the rug pulled out from under them and not get their check. We cannot frighten
column10: as we have with the threats and the campaign rhetoric that has gone on in this campaign
column11: our senior citizens - leave them thinking that in some way
column12: they're endangered and they would have no place to turn. They must continue to get those checks
column13: and I believe that the system can be put on a sound actuarial basis. But it's going to take some study and some work
column14: and not just passing a tax increase to let the load - or the roof - fall in on the next administration.

column1: As long as there is a Democratic President in the White House
column2: we will have a strong and viable Social Security System
column3: free of the threat of bankruptcy. Although Governor Reagan has changed his position lately
column4: on four different occasions
column5: he has advocated making Social Security a voluntary system
column6: which would
column7: in effect
column8: very quickly bankrupt it. I noticed also in The Wall Street Journal early this week
column9: that a preliminary report of his task force advocates making Social Security more sound by reducing the adjustment in Social Security for the retired people to compensate for the impact of inflation. These kinds of approaches are very dangerous to the security
column10: the well being and the peace of mind of the retired people of this country and those approaching retirement age. But no matter what it takes in the future to keep Social Security sound
column11: it must be kept that way. And although there was a serious threat to the Social Security System and its integrity during the 1976 campaign and when I became President
column12: the action of the Democratic Congress working with me has been to put Social Security back on a sound financial basis. That is the way it will stay.

column2: that just isn't true. It has
column3: as I said
column4: delayed the actuarial imbalance falling on us for just a few years with that increase in taxes
column5: and I don't believe we can go on increasing the tax
column6: because the problem for the young people today is that they are paying in far more than they can ever expect to get out. Now
column7: again this statement that somehow
column8: I wanted to destroy it and I just changed my tune
column9: that I am for voluntary Social Security
column10: which would mean the ruin of it. Mr. President
column11: the voluntary thing that I suggested many years ago was that with a young man orphaned and raised by an aunt who died
column12: his aunt was ineligible for Social Security insurance because she was not his mother. And I suggested that if this is an insurance program
column13: certainly the person who is paying in should be able to name his own beneficiary. That is the closest I have ever come to anything voluntary with Social Security. I
column14: too
column15: am pledged to a Social Security program that will reassure these senior citizens of ours that they are going to continue to get their money. There are some changes that I would like to make. I would like to make a change in the regulation that discriminates against a wife who works and finds that she then is faced with a choice between her father's or her husband's benefits
column16: if he dies first
column17: or what she has paid in; but it does not recognize that she has also been paying in herself
column18: and she is entitled to more than she presently can get. I'd like to change that.

column1: These constant suggestions that the basic Social Security System should be changed does call for concern and consternation among the aged of our country. It is obvious that we should have a commitment to them
column2: that Social Security benefits should not be taxed and that there would be no peremptory change in the standards by which Social Security payments are made to retired people. We also need to continue to index Social Security payments
column3: so that if inflation rises
column4: the Social Security payments would rise a commensurate degree to let the buying power of a Social Security check continue intact. In the past
column5: the relationship between Social Security and Medicare has been very important to providing some modicum of aid for senior citizens in the retention of health benefits. Governor Reagan
column6: as a matter of fact
column7: began his political career campaigning around this nation against Medicare. Now
column8: we have an opportunity to move toward national health insurance
column9: with an emphasis on the prevention of disease
column10: an emphasis on out-patient care
column11: not in-patient care; an emphasis on hospital cost containment to hold down the cost of hospital care far those who are ill
column12: an emphasis on catastrophic health insurance
column13: so that if a family is threatened with being wiped out economically because of a very high medical bill
column14: then the insurance would help pay for it. These are the kinds of elements of a national health insurance
column15: important to the American people. Governor Reagan
column16: again
column17: typically is against such a proposal.

column2: there was another piece of legislation meeting the same problem before the Congress. I happened to favor the other piece of legislation and thought that it would be better for the senior citizens and provide better care than the one that was finally passed. I was not opposing the principle of providing care for them. I was opposing one piece of legislation versus another. There is something else about Social Security. Of course
column3: it doesn't come out of the payroll tax. It comes out of a general fund
column4: but something should be done about it. I think it is disgraceful that the Disability Insurance Fund in Social Security finds checks going every month to tens of thousands of people who are locked up in our institutions for crime or for mental illness
column5: and they are receiving disability checks from Social Security every month while a state institution provides for all of their needs and their care.

column1: I think this debate on Social Security
column2: Medicare
column3: national health insurance typifies
column4: as vividly any other subject tonight
column5: the basic historical differences between the Democratic Party and Republican Party. The allusions to basic changes in the minimum wage is another
column6: and the deleterious comments that Governor Reagan has made about unemployment compensation. These commitments that the Democratic Party has historically made to the working families of this nation have been extremely important to the growth in their stature and in a better quality of life for them. I noticed recently that Governor Reagan frequently quotes Democratic presidents in his acceptance address. I have never heard a candidate for President
column7: who is a Republican
column8: quote a Republican president
column9: but when they get in office
column10: they try to govern like Republicans. So
column11: it is good fo the American people to remember that there is a sharp basic historical difference between Governor Reagan and me on these crucial issues - also
column12: between the two parties that we represent.

column2: there was another piece of legislation meeting the same problem before the Congress. I happened to favor the other piece of legislation and thought that it would be better for the senior citizens and provide better care than the one that was finally passed. I was not opposing the principle of providing care for them. I was opposing one piece of legislation versus another. There is something else about Social Security. Of course
column3: it doesn't come out of the payroll tax. It comes out of a general fund
column4: but something should be done about it. I think it is disgraceful that the Disability Insurance Fund in Social Security finds checks going every month to tens of thousands of people who are locked up in our institutions for crime or for mental illness
column5: and they are receiving disability checks from Social Security every month while a state institution provides for all of their needs and their care.

column1: I think this debate on Social Security
column2: Medicare
column3: national health insurance typifies
column4: as vividly any other subject tonight
column5: the basic historical differences between the Democratic Party and Republican Party. The allusions to basic changes in the minimum wage is another
column6: and the deleterious comments that Governor Reagan has made about unemployment compensation. These commitments that the Democratic Party has historically made to the working families of this nation have been extremely important to the growth in their stature and in a better quality of life for them. I noticed recently that Governor Reagan frequently quotes Democratic presidents in his acceptance address. I have never heard a candidate for President

column3: 7)	" The Social Security system was based on a false premise
column4: with regard to how fast the number of workers would increase and how fast the number of retirees would increase. It is actuarially out of balance
column5: and this first became evident about 16 years ago
column6: and some of us were voicing warnings then. Now
column7: it is trillions of dollars out of balance
column8: and the only answer that has come so far is the biggest single tax increase in our nation's history - the payroll tax increase for Social Security - which will only put a band-aid on this and postpone the day of reckoning by a few years at most. What is needed is a study that I have proposed by a task force of experts to look into this entire problem as to how it can be reformed and made actuarially sound
column9: but with the premise that no one presently dependent on Social Security is going to have the rug pulled out from under them and not get their check. We cannot frighten

column12: they're endangered and they would have no place to turn. They must continue to get those checks
column13: and I believe that the system can be put on a sound actuarial basis. But it's going to take some study and some work

column1: As long as there is a Democratic President in the White House

column3: free of the threat of bankruptcy. Although Governor Reagan has changed his position lately
column4: on four different occasions

column6: which would

column8: very quickly bankrupt it. I noticed also in The Wall Street Journal early this week
column9: that a preliminary report of his task force advocates making Social Security more sound by reducing the adjustment in Social Security for the retired people to compensate for the impact of inflation. These kinds of approaches are very dangerous to the security
column10: the well being and the peace of mind of the retired people of this country and those approaching retirement age. But no matter what it takes in the future to keep Social Security sound
column11: it must be kept that way. And although there was a serious threat to the Social Security System and its integrity during the 1976 campaign and when I became President
column12: the action of the Democratic Congress working with me has been to put Social Security back on a sound financial basis. That is the way it will stay.

column7: again this statement that somehow

There are some changes that I would like to make. I would like to make a change in the regulation that discriminates against a wife who works and finds that she then is faced with a choice between her father's or her husband's benefits
column16: if he dies first

column18: and she is entitled to more than she presently can get. I'd like to change that.

column1: These constant suggestions that the basic Social Security System should be changed does call for concern and consternation among the aged of our country. It is obvious that we should have a commitment to them
column2: that Social Security benefits should not be taxed and that there would be no peremptory change in the standards by which Social Security payments are made to retired people. We also need to continue to index Social Security payments
column3: so that if inflation rises
column4: the Social Security payments would rise a commensurate degree to let the buying power of a Social Security check continue intact. In the past
column5: the relationship between Social Security and Medicare has been very important to providing some modicum of aid for senior citizens in the retention of health benefits. Governor Reagan
column6: as a matter of fact
column7: began his political career campaigning around this nation against Medicare. Now
column8: we have an opportunity to move toward national health insurance
column9: with an emphasis on the prevention of disease
column10: an emphasis on out-patient care
column11: not in-patient care; an emphasis on hospital cost containment to hold down the cost of hospital care far those who are ill
column12: an emphasis on catastrophic health insurance
column13: so that if a family is threatened with being wiped out economically because of a very high medical bill
column14: then the insurance would help pay for it. These are the kinds of elements of a national health insurance
column15: important to the American people. Governor Reagan
column16: again
column17: typically is against such a proposal.

column2: there was another piece of legislation meeting the same problem before the Congress. I happened to favor the other piece of legislation and thought that it would be better for the senior citizens and provide better care than the one that was finally passed. I was not opposing the principle of providing care for them. I was opposing one piece of legislation versus another. There is something else about Social Security. Of course
column3: it doesn't come out of the payroll tax. It comes out of a general fund
column4: but something should be done about it. I think it is disgraceful that the Disability Insurance Fund in Social Security finds checks going every month to tens of thousands of people who are locked up in our institutions for crime or for mental illness
column5: and they are receiving disability checks from Social Security every month while a state institution provides for all of their needs and their care.

column1: I think this debate on Social Security
column2: Medicare
column3: national health insurance typifies
column4: as vividly any other subject tonight
column5: the basic historical differences between the Democratic Party and Republican Party. The allusions to basic changes in the minimum wage is another
column6: and the deleterious comments that Governor Reagan has made about unemployment compensation. These commitments that the Democratic Party has historically made to the working families of this nation have been extremely important to the growth in their stature and in a better quality of life for them. I noticed recently that Governor Reagan frequently quotes Democratic presidents in his acceptance address. I have never heard a candidate for President
column7: who is a Republican

column9: but when they get in office
column10: they try to govern like Republicans. So
column11: it is good fo the American people to remember that there is a sharp basic historical difference between Governor Reagan and me on these crucial issues - also
column12: between the two parties that we represent.
