column2: '28Oct'
column3: 7)	" The Social Security system was based on a false premise
column4: with regard to how fast the number of workers would increase and how fast the number of retirees would increase. It is actuarially out of balance
column5: and this first became evident about 16 years ago
column6: and some of us were voicing warnings then. Now
column7: it is trillions of dollars out of balance
column8: and the only answer that has come so far is the biggest single tax increase in our nation's history - the payroll tax increase for Social Security - which will only put a band-aid on this and postpone the day of reckoning by a few years at most. What is needed is a study that I have proposed by a task force of experts to look into this entire problem as to how it can be reformed and made actuarially sound
column9: but with the premise that no one presently dependent on Social Security is going to have the rug pulled out from under them and not get their check. We cannot frighten
column10: as we have with the threats and the campaign rhetoric that has gone on in this campaign
column11: our senior citizens - leave them thinking that in some way
column12: they're endangered and they would have no place to turn. They must continue to get those checks
column13: and I believe that the system can be put on a sound actuarial basis. But it's going to take some study and some work
column14: and not just passing a tax increase to let the load - or the roof - fall in on the next administration.

column1: As long as there is a Democratic President in the White House
column2: we will have a strong and viable Social Security System
column3: free of the threat of bankruptcy. Although Governor Reagan has changed his position lately
column4: on four different occasions
column5: he has advocated making Social Security a voluntary system
column6: which would
column7: in effect
column8: very quickly bankrupt it. I noticed also in The Wall Street Journal early this week
column9: that a preliminary report of his task force advocates making Social Security more sound by reducing the adjustment in Social Security for the retired people to compensate for the impact of inflation. These kinds of approaches are very dangerous to the security
column10: the well being and the peace of mind of the retired people of this country and those approaching retirement age. But no matter what it takes in the future to keep Social Security sound
column11: it must be kept that way. And although there was a serious threat to the Social Security System and its integrity during the 1976 campaign and when I became President
column12: the action of the Democratic Congress working with me has been to put Social Security back on a sound financial basis. That is the way it will stay.

column2: that just isn't true. It has
column3: as I said
column4: delayed the actuarial imbalance falling on us for just a few years with that increase in taxes
column5: and I don't believe we can go on increasing the tax
column6: because the problem for the young people today is that they are paying in far more than they can ever expect to get out. Now
column7: again this statement that somehow
column8: I wanted to destroy it and I just changed my tune
column9: that I am for voluntary Social Security
column10: which would mean the ruin of it. Mr. President
column11: the voluntary thing that I suggested many years ago was that with a young man orphaned and raised by an aunt who died
column12: his aunt was ineligible for Social Security insurance because she was not his mother. And I suggested that if this is an insurance program
column13: certainly the person who is paying in should be able to name his own beneficiary. That is the closest I have ever come to anything voluntary with Social Security. I
column14: too
column15: am pledged to a Social Security program that will reassure these senior citizens of ours that they are going to continue to get their money. There are some changes that I would like to make. I would like to make a change in the regulation that discriminates against a wife who works and finds that she then is faced with a choice between her father's or her husband's benefits
column16: if he dies first
column17: or what she has paid in; but it does not recognize that she has also been paying in herself
column18: and she is entitled to more than she presently can get. I'd like to change that.

column1: These constant suggestions that the basic Social Security System should be changed does call for concern and consternation among the aged of our country. It is obvious that we should have a commitment to them
column2: that Social Security benefits should not be taxed and that there would be no peremptory change in the standards by which Social Security payments are made to retired people. We also need to continue to index Social Security payments
column3: so that if inflation rises
column4: the Social Security payments would rise a commensurate degree to let the buying power of a Social Security check continue intact. In the past
column5: the relationship between Social Security and Medicare has been very important to providing some modicum of aid for senior citizens in the retention of health benefits. Governor Reagan
column6: as a matter of fact
column7: began his political career campaigning around this nation against Medicare. Now
column8: we have an opportunity to move toward national health insurance
column9: with an emphasis on the prevention of disease
column10: an emphasis on out-patient care
column11: not in-patient care; an emphasis on hospital cost containment to hold down the cost of hospital care far those who are ill
column12: an emphasis on catastrophic health insurance
column13: so that if a family is threatened with being wiped out economically because of a very high medical bill
column14: then the insurance would help pay for it. These are the kinds of elements of a national health insurance
column15: important to the American people. Governor Reagan
column16: again
column17: typically is against such a proposal.

column2: there was another piece of legislation meeting the same problem before the Congress. I happened to favor the other piece of legislation and thought that it would be better for the senior citizens and provide better care than the one that was finally passed. I was not opposing the principle of providing care for them. I was opposing one piece of legislation versus another. There is something else about Social Security. Of course
column3: it doesn't come out of the payroll tax. It comes out of a general fund
column4: but something should be done about it. I think it is disgraceful that the Disability Insurance Fund in Social Security finds checks going every month to tens of thousands of people who are locked up in our institutions for crime or for mental illness
column5: and they are receiving disability checks from Social Security every month while a state institution provides for all of their needs and their care.

column1: I think this debate on Social Security
column2: Medicare
column3: national health insurance typifies
column4: as vividly any other subject tonight
column5: the basic historical differences between the Democratic Party and Republican Party. The allusions to basic changes in the minimum wage is another
column6: and the deleterious comments that Governor Reagan has made about unemployment compensation. These commitments that the Democratic Party has historically made to the working families of this nation have been extremely important to the growth in their stature and in a better quality of life for them. I noticed recently that Governor Reagan frequently quotes Democratic presidents in his acceptance address. I have never heard a candidate for President
column7: who is a Republican
column8: quote a Republican president
column9: but when they get in office
column10: they try to govern like Republicans. So
column11: it is good fo the American people to remember that there is a sharp basic historical difference between Governor Reagan and me on these crucial issues - also
column12: between the two parties that we represent.

column12: the action of the Democratic Congress working with me has been to put Social Security back on a sound financial basis. That is the way it will stay.

column2: that just isn't true. It has
column3: as I said
column4: delayed the actuarial imbalance falling on us for just a few years with that increase in taxes
column5: and I don't believe we can go on increasing the tax
column6: because the problem for the young people today is that they are paying in far more than they can ever expect to get out. Now
column7: again this statement that somehow
column8: I wanted to destroy it and I just changed my tune
column9: that I am for voluntary Social Security
column10: which would mean the ruin of it. Mr. President
column11: the voluntary thing that I suggested many years ago was that with a young man orphaned and raised by an aunt who died
column12: his aunt was ineligible for Social Security insurance because she was not his mother. And I suggested that if this is an insurance program
column13: certainly the person who is paying in should be able to name his own beneficiary. That is the closest I have ever come to anything voluntary with Social Security. I
column14: too
column15: am pledged to a Social Security program that will reassure these senior citizens of ours that they are going to continue to get their money. There are some changes that I would like to make. I would like to make a change in the regulation that discriminates against a wife who works and finds that she then is faced with a choice between her father's or her husband's benefits
column16: if he dies first
column17: or what she has paid in; but it does not recognize that she has also been paying in herself
column18: and she is entitled to more than she presently can get. I'd like to change that.

column1: These constant suggestions that the basic Social Security System should be changed does call for concern and consternation among the aged of our country. It is obvious that we should have a commitment to them
column2: that Social Security benefits should not be taxed and that there would be no peremptory change in the standards by which Social Security payments are made to retired people. We also need to continue to index Social Security payments
column3: so that if inflation rises
column4: the Social Security payments would rise a commensurate degree to let the buying power of a Social Security check continue intact. In the past
column5: the relationship between Social Security and Medicare has been very important to providing some modicum of aid for senior citizens in the retention of health benefits. Governor Reagan
column6: as a matter of fact
column7: began his political career campaigning around this nation against Medicare. Now
column8: we have an opportunity to move toward national health insurance
column9: with an emphasis on the prevention of disease
column10: an emphasis on out-patient care
column11: not in-patient care; an emphasis on hospital cost containment to hold down the cost of hospital care far those who are ill
column12: an emphasis on catastrophic health insurance
column13: so that if a family is threatened with being wiped out economically because of a very high medical bill
column14: then the insurance would help pay for it. These are the kinds of elements of a national health insurance
column15: important to the American people. Governor Reagan
column16: again
column17: typically is against such a proposal.

column2: there was another piece of legislation meeting the same problem before the Congress. I happened to favor the other piece of legislation and thought that it would be better for the senior citizens and provide better care than the one that was finally passed. I was not opposing the principle of providing care for them. I was opposing one piece of legislation versus another. There is something else about Social Security. Of course
column3: it doesn't come out of the payroll tax. It comes out of a general fund
column4: but something should be done about it. I think it is disgraceful that the Disability Insurance Fund in Social Security finds checks going every month to tens of thousands of people who are locked up in our institutions for crime or for mental illness
column5: and they are receiving disability checks from Social Security every month while a state institution provides for all of their needs and their care.

column1: I think this debate on Social Security
column2: Medicare
column3: national health insurance typifies
column4: as vividly any other subject tonight
column5: the basic historical differences between the Democratic Party and Republican Party. The allusions to basic changes in the minimum wage is another
column6: and the deleterious comments that Governor Reagan has made about unemployment compensation. These commitments that the Democratic Party has historically made to the working families of this nation have been extremely important to the growth in their stature and in a better quality of life for them. I noticed recently that Governor Reagan frequently quotes Democratic presidents in his acceptance address. I have never heard a candidate for President
column7: who is a Republican
column8: quote a Republican president
column9: but when they get in office
column10: they try to govern like Republicans. So
column11: it is good fo the American people to remember that there is a sharp basic historical difference between Governor Reagan and me on these crucial issues - also
column12: between the two parties that we represent.

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 8)	" Barbara
column4: reluctant as I am to say anything critical about Governor Reagan
column5: I will try to answer your question. First of all
column6: there is the historical perspective that I just described. This is a contest between a Democrat in the mainstream of my party
column7: as exemplified by the actions that I have taken in the Oval Office the last four years
column8: as contrasted with Governor Reagan
column9: who in most cases does typify his party
column10: but in some cases
column11: there is a radical departure by him from the heritage of Eisenhower and others. The most important crucial difference in this election campaign
column12: in my judgment
column13: is the approach to the control of nuclear weaponry and the inclination to control or not to control the spread of atomic weapons to other nations who don't presently have it
column14: particularly terrorist nations. The inclination that Governor Reagan has exemplified in many troubled times since he has been running for President - I think since 1968 - to inject American military forces in places like North Korea
column15: to put a blockade around Cuba this year
column16: or in some instances
column17: to project American forces into a fishing dispute against the small nation of Ecuador on the west coast of South America. This is typical of his long-standing inclination
column18: on the use of American power
column19: not to resolve disputes diplomatically and peacefully
column20: but to show that the exercise of military power is best proven by the actual use of it. Obviously
column21: no President wants war
column22: and I certainly do not believe that Governor Reagan
column23: if he were President
column24: would want war
column25: but a President in the Oval Office has to make a judgment on almost a daily basis about how to exercise the enormous power of our country for peace
column26: through diplomacy
column27: or in a careless way in a belligerent attitude which has exemplified his attitudes in the past.

column2: Barbara
column3: I believe that there is a fundamental difference - and I think it has been evident in most of the answers that Mr. Carter has given tonight - that he seeks the solution to anything as another opportunity for a Federal Government program. I happen to believe that the Federal Government has usurped powers of autonomy and authority that belong back at the state and local level. It has imposed on the individual freedoms of the people
column4: and there are more of these things that could be solved by the people themselves
column5: if they were given a chance
column6: or by the levels of government that were closer to them. Now
column7: as to why I should be and he shouldn't be
column8: when he was a candidate in 1976
column9: President Carter invented a thing he called the misery index. He added the rate of unemployment and the rate of inflation
column10: and it came
column11: at that time
column12: to 12.5% under President Ford. He said that no man with that size misery index has a right to seek reelection to the Presidency. Today
column13: by his own decision
column14: the misery index is in excess of 20%
column15: and I think this must suggest something. But
column16: when I had quoted a Democratic President
column17: as the President says
column18: I was a Democrat. I said many foolish things back in those days. But the President that I quoted had made a promise
column19: a Democratic promise
column20: and I quoted him because it was never kept. And today
column21: you would find that that promise is at the very heart of what Republicanism represents in this country today. That's why I believe there are going to be millions of Democrats that are going to vote with us this time around
column22: because they too want that promise kept. It was a promise for less government and less taxes and more freedom for the people.

column1: I mentioned the radical departure of Governor Reagan from the principles or ideals of historical perspective of his own party. I don't think that can be better illustrated than in the case of guaranteeing women equal rights under the Constitution of our nation. For 40 years
column2: the Republican Party platforms called for guaranteeing women equal rights with a constitutional amendment. Six predecessors of mine who served in the Oval Office called for this guarantee of women's rights. Governor Reagan and his new Republican Party have departed from this commitment - a very severe blow to the opportunity for women to finally correct discrimination under which they have suffered. When a man and a women do the same amount of work
column3: a man gets paid $1.00
column4: a women only gets paid 59 cents. And the equal rights amendment only says that equality of rights shall not be abridged for omen b the Federal Government or by he state governments. That is all it says a simple guarantee of equality of opportunity which typifies the Democratic arty
column5: and which is a very important commitment of mine
column6: as contrasted with Governor Reagan's radical departure from the long-standing policy of his own party.

column2: once again
column3: I happen to be against the amendment
column4: because I think the amendment will take this problem out of the hands of elected legislators and put it in the hands f unelected judges. I am for equal rights
column5: and while you have been in office for four ears and not one single state - and most f them have a majority of Democratic legislators - has added to the ratification r voted to ratify the equal rights amendment. While I was Governor
column6: more than eight years ago
column7: I found 14 separate instances where women were discriminated against in the body of California law
column8: and I had passed and signed into law 14 statutes that eliminated those discriminations
column9: including the economic ones that you have just mentioned - equal pay and so forth. I believe that if in all these years that we have spent trying to get the amendment
column10: that we had spent as much time correcting these laws
column11: as we did in California - and we were the first to do it. If I were President
column12: I would also now take a look at the hundreds of Federal regulations which discriminate against women and which go right on while everyone is looking for an amendment. I would have someone ride herd on those regulations
column13: and we would start eliminating those discriminations in the Federal Government against women.

column2: I'm a Southerner
column3: and I share the basic beliefs of my region that an excessive government intrusion into the private affairs of American citizens and also into the private affairs of the free enterprise system. One of the commitments that I made was to deregulate the major industries of this country. We've been remarkably successful
column4: with the help of a Democratic Congress. We have deregulated the air industry
column5: the rail industry
column6: the trucking industry
column7: financial institutions. We're now working on the communications industry. In addition to that
column8: I believe that this element of discrimination is something that the South has seen so vividly as a blight on our region of the country which has now been corrected - not only racial discrimination but discrimination against people that have to work for a living - because we have been trying to pick ourselves up by our bootstraps
column9: since the long depression years
column10: and lead a full and useful life in the affairs of this country. We have made remarkable success. It is part of my consciousness and of my commitment to continue this progress. So
column11: my heritage as a Southerner
column12: my experience in the Oval Office
column13: convinces me that what I have just described is a proper course for the future.

column2: my last word is again to say this: We were talking about this very simple amendment and women's rights. And I make it plain again: I am for women's rights. But I would like to call the attention of the people to the fact that that so-called simple amendment would be used by mischievous men to destroy discriminations that properly belong
column3: by law
column4: to women respecting the physical differences between the two sexes
column5: labor laws that protect them against things that would be physically harmful to them. Those would all
column6: could all be challenged by men. And the same would be true with regard to combat service in the military and so forth. I thought that was the subject we were supposed to be on. But
column7: if we're talking about how much we think about the working people and so forth
column8: I'm the only fellow who ever ran for this job who was six times President of his own union and still has a lifetime membership in that union.

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 8)	" Barbara
column4: reluctant as I am to say anything critical about Governor Reagan
column5: I will try to answer your question. First of all
column6: there is the historical perspective that I just described. This is a contest between a Democrat in the mainstream of my party
column7: as exemplified by the actions that I have taken in the Oval Office the last four years
column8: as contrasted with Governor Reagan
column9: who in most cases does typify his party
column10: but in some cases
column11: there is a radical departure by him from the heritage of Eisenhower and others. The most important crucial difference in this election campaign
column12: in my judgment
column13: is the approach to the control of nuclear weaponry and the inclination to control or not to control the spread of atomic weapons to other nations who don't presently have it
column14: particularly terrorist nations. The inclination that Governor Reagan has exemplified in many troubled times since he has been running for President - I think since 1968 - to inject American military forces in places like North Korea
column15: to put a blockade around Cuba this year
column16: or in some instances
column17: to project American forces into a fishing dispute against the small nation of Ecuador on the west coast of South America. This is typical of his long-standing inclination
column18: on the use of American power
column19: not to resolve disputes diplomatically and peacefully
column20: but to show that the exercise of military power is best proven by the actual use of it. Obviously
column21: no President wants war
column22: and I certainly do not believe that Governor Reagan
column23: if he were President
column24: would want war
column25: but a President in the Oval Office has to make a judgment on almost a daily basis about how to exercise the enormous power of our country for peace
column26: through diplomacy
column27: or in a careless way in a belligerent attitude which has exemplified his attitudes in the past.

column2: Barbara
column3: I believe that there is a fundamental difference - and I think it has been evident in most of the answers that Mr. Carter has given tonight - that he seeks the solution to anything as another opportunity for a Federal Government program. I happen to believe that the Federal Government has usurped powers of autonomy and authority that belong back at the state and local level. It has imposed on the individual freedoms of the people
column4: and there are more of these things that could be solved by the people themselves
column5: if they were given a chance
column6: or by the levels of government that were closer to them. Now
column7: as to why I should be and he shouldn't be
column8: when he was a candidate in 1976
column9: President Carter invented a thing he called the misery index. He added the rate of unemployment and the rate of inflation
column10: and it came
column11: at that time
column12: to 12.5% under President Ford. He said that no man with that size misery index has a right to seek reelection to the Presidency. Today
column13: by his own decision
column14: the misery index is in excess of 20%
column15: and I think this must suggest something. But
column16: when I had quoted a Democratic President
column17: as the President says
column18: I was a Democrat. I said many foolish things back in those days. But the President that I quoted had made a promise
column19: a Democratic promise
column20: and I quoted him because it was never kept. And today
column21: you would find that that promise is at the very heart of what Republicanism represents in this country today. That's why I believe there are going to be millions of Democrats that are going to vote with us this time around
column22: because they too want that promise kept. It was a promise for less government and less taxes and more freedom for the people.

column1: I mentioned the radical departure of Governor Reagan from the principles or ideals of historical perspective of his own party. I don't think that can be better illustrated than in the case of guaranteeing women equal rights under the Constitution of our nation. For 40 years
column2: the Republican Party platforms called for guaranteeing women equal rights with a constitutional amendment. Six predecessors of mine who served in the Oval Office called for this guarantee of women's rights. Governor Reagan and his new Republican Party have departed from this commitment - a very severe blow to the opportunity for women to finally correct discrimination under which they have suffered. When a man and a women do the same amount of work
column3: a man gets paid $1.00
column4: a women only gets paid 59 cents. And the equal rights amendment only says that equality of rights shall not be abridged for omen b the Federal Government or by he state governments. That is all it says a simple guarantee of equality of opportunity which typifies the Democratic arty
column5: and which is a very important commitment of mine
column6: as contrasted with Governor Reagan's radical departure from the long-standing policy of his own party.

column2: once again
column3: I happen to be against the amendment
column4: because I think the amendment will take this problem out of the hands of elected legislators and put it in the hands f unelected judges. I am for equal rights
column5: and while you have been in office for four ears and not one single state - and most f them have a majority of Democratic legislators - has added to the ratification r voted to ratify the equal rights amendment. While I was Governor
column6: more than eight years ago
column7: I found 14 separate instances where women were discriminated against in the body of California law
column8: and I had passed and signed into law 14 statutes that eliminated those discriminations
column9: including the economic ones that you have just mentioned - equal pay and so forth. I believe that if in all these years that we have spent trying to get the amendment
column10: that we had spent as much time correcting these laws
column11: as we did in California - and we were the first to do it. If I were President
column12: I would also now take a look at the hundreds of Federal regulations which discriminate against women and which go right on while everyone is looking for an amendment. I would have someone ride herd on those regulations
column13: and we would start eliminating those discriminations in the Federal Government against women.

column2: I'm a Southerner
column3: and I share the basic beliefs of my region that an excessive government intrusion into the private affairs of American citizens and also into the private affairs of the free enterprise system. One of the commitments that I made was to deregulate the major industries of this country. We've been remarkably successful
column4: with the help of a Democratic Congress. We have deregulated the air industry
column5: the rail industry
column6: the trucking industry
column7: financial institutions. We're now working on the communications industry. In addition to that
column8: I believe that this element of discrimination is something that the South has seen so vividly as a blight on our region of the country which has now been corrected - not only racial discrimination but discrimination against people that have to work for a living - because we have been trying to pick ourselves up by our bootstraps
column9: since the long depression years
column10: and lead a full and useful life in the affairs of this country. We have made remarkable success. It is part of my consciousness and of my commitment to continue this progress. So
column11: my heritage as a Southerner
column12: my experience in the Oval Office
column13: convinces me that what I have just described is a proper course for the future.

column2: my last word is again to say this: We were talking about this very simple amendment and women's rights. And I make it plain again: I am for women's rights. But I would like to call the attention of the people to the fact that that so-called simple amendment would be used by mischievous men to destroy discriminations that properly belong
column3: by law
column4: to women respecting the physical differences between the two sexes
column5: labor laws that protect them against things that would be physically harmful to them. Those would all
column6: could all be challenged by men. And the same would be true with regard to combat service in the military and so forth. I thought that was the subject we were supposed to be on. But
column7: if we're talking about how much we think about the working people and so forth
column8: I'm the only fellow who ever ran for this job who was six times President of his own union and still has a lifetime membership in that union.

column5: I will try to answer your question. First of all
column6: there is the historical perspective that I just described. This is a contest between a Democrat in the mainstream of my party
column7: as exemplified by the actions that I have taken in the Oval Office the last four years
column8: as contrasted with Governor Reagan
column9: who in most cases does typify his party
column10: but in some cases
column11: there is a radical departure by him from the heritage of Eisenhower and others. The most important crucial difference in this election campaign
column12: in my judgment
column13: is the approach to the control of nuclear weaponry and the inclination to control or not to control the spread of atomic weapons to other nations who don't presently have it
column14: particularly terrorist nations. The inclination that Governor Reagan has exemplified in many troubled times since he has been running for President - I think since 1968 - to inject American military forces in places like North Korea
column15: to put a blockade around Cuba this year
column16: or in some instances

column18: on the use of American power

column20: but to show that the exercise of military power is best proven by the actual use of it. Obviously
column21: no President wants war
column22: and I certainly do not believe that Governor Reagan
column23: if he were President
column24: would want war
column25: but a President in the Oval Office has to make a judgment on almost a daily basis about how to exercise the enormous power of our country for peace
column26: through diplomacy
column27: or in a careless way in a belligerent attitude which has exemplified his attitudes in the past.

column2: Barbara
column3: I believe that there is a fundamental difference - and I think it has been evident in most of the answers that Mr. Carter has given tonight - that he seeks the solution to anything as another opportunity for a Federal Government program. I happen to believe that the Federal Government has usurped powers of autonomy and authority that belong back at the state and local level. It has imposed on the individual freedoms of the people
column4: and there are more of these things that could be solved by the people themselves
column5: if they were given a chance
column6: or by the levels of government that were closer to them. Now
column7: as to why I should be and he shouldn't be
column8: when he was a candidate in 1976
column9: President Carter invented a thing he called the misery index. He added the rate of unemployment and the rate of inflation
column10: and it came
column11: at that time
column12: to 12.5% under President Ford. He said that no man with that size misery index has a right to seek reelection to the Presidency. Today
column13: by his own decision
column14: the misery index is in excess of 20%
column15: and I think this must suggest something. But
column16: when I had quoted a Democratic President
column17: as the President says
column18: I was a Democrat. I said many foolish things back in those days. But the President that I quoted had made a promise
column19: a Democratic promise
column20: and I quoted him because it was never kept. And today
column21: you would find that that promise is at the very heart of what Republicanism represents in this country today. That's why I believe there are going to be millions of Democrats that are going to vote with us this time around
column22: because they too want that promise kept. It was a promise for less government and less taxes and more freedom for the people.

column1: I mentioned the radical departure of Governor Reagan from the principles or ideals of historical perspective of his own party. I don't think that can be better illustrated than in the case of guaranteeing women equal rights under the Constitution of our nation. For 40 years
column2: the Republican Party platforms called for guaranteeing women equal rights with a constitutional amendment. Six predecessors of mine who served in the Oval Office called for this guarantee of women's rights. Governor Reagan and his new Republican Party have departed from this commitment - a very severe blow to the opportunity for women to finally correct discrimination under which they have suffered. When a man and a women do the same amount of work
column3: a man gets paid $1.00
column4: a women only gets paid 59 cents. And the equal rights amendment only says that equality of rights shall not be abridged for omen b the Federal Government or by he state governments. That is all it says a simple guarantee of equality of opportunity which typifies the Democratic arty
column5: and which is a very important commitment of mine
column6: as contrasted with Governor Reagan's radical departure from the long-standing policy of his own party.

column2: once again
column3: I happen to be against the amendment
column4: because I think the amendment will take this problem out of the hands of elected legislators and put it in the hands f unelected judges. I am for equal rights
column5: and while you have been in office for four ears and not one single state - and most f them have a majority of Democratic legislators - has added to the ratification r voted to ratify the equal rights amendment. While I was Governor
column6: more than eight years ago
column7: I found 14 separate instances where women were discriminated against in the body of California law
column8: and I had passed and signed into law 14 statutes that eliminated those discriminations
column9: including the economic ones that you have just mentioned - equal pay and so forth. I believe that if in all these years that we have spent trying to get the amendment
column10: that we had spent as much time correcting these laws
column11: as we did in California - and we were the first to do it. If I were President
column12: I would also now take a look at the hundreds of Federal regulations which discriminate against women and which go right on while everyone is looking for an amendment. I would have someone ride herd on those regulations
column13: and we would start eliminating those discriminations in the Federal Government against women.

column2: I'm a Southerner
column3: and I share the basic beliefs of my region that an excessive government intrusion into the private affairs of American citizens and also into the private affairs of the free enterprise system. One of the commitments that I made was to deregulate the major industries of this country. We've been remarkably successful
column4: with the help of a Democratic Congress. We have deregulated the air industry
column5: the rail industry
column6: the trucking industry
column7: financial institutions. We're now working on the communications industry. In addition to that
column8: I believe that this element of discrimination is something that the South has seen so vividly as a blight on our region of the country which has now been corrected - not only racial discrimination but discrimination against people that have to work for a living - because we have been trying to pick ourselves up by our bootstraps
column9: since the long depression years
column10: and lead a full and useful life in the affairs of this country. We have made remarkable success. It is part of my consciousness and of my commitment to continue this progress. So
column11: my heritage as a Southerner
column12: my experience in the Oval Office
column13: convinces me that what I have just described is a proper course for the future.

column2: my last word is again to say this: We were talking about this very simple amendment and women's rights. And I make it plain again: I am for women's rights. But I would like to call the attention of the people to the fact that that so-called simple amendment would be used by mischievous men to destroy discriminations that properly belong
column3: by law
column4: to women respecting the physical differences between the two sexes
column5: labor laws that protect them against things that would be physically harmful to them. Those would all
column6: could all be challenged by men. And the same would be true with regard to combat service in the military and so forth. I thought that was the subject we were supposed to be on. But
column7: if we're talking about how much we think about the working people and so forth
column8: I'm the only fellow who ever ran for this job who was six times President of his own union and still has a lifetime membership in that union.

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 8)	" Barbara
column4: reluctant as I am to say anything critical about Governor Reagan
column5: I will try to answer your question. First of all
column6: there is the historical perspective that I just described. This is a contest between a Democrat in the mainstream of my party
column7: as exemplified by the actions that I have taken in the Oval Office the last four years
column8: as contrasted with Governor Reagan
column9: who in most cases does typify his party
column10: but in some cases
column11: there is a radical departure by him from the heritage of Eisenhower and others. The most important crucial difference in this election campaign
column12: in my judgment
column13: is the approach to the control of nuclear weaponry and the inclination to control or not to control the spread of atomic weapons to other nations who don't presently have it
column14: particularly terrorist nations. The inclination that Governor Reagan has exemplified in many troubled times since he has been running for President - I think since 1968 - to inject American military forces in places like North Korea
column15: to put a blockade around Cuba this year
column16: or in some instances
column17: to project American forces into a fishing dispute against the small nation of Ecuador on the west coast of South America. This is typical of his long-standing inclination
column18: on the use of American power
column19: not to resolve disputes diplomatically and peacefully
column20: but to show that the exercise of military power is best proven by the actual use of it. Obviously
column21: no President wants war
column22: and I certainly do not believe that Governor Reagan
column23: if he were President
column24: would want war
column25: but a President in the Oval Office has to make a judgment on almost a daily basis about how to exercise the enormous power of our country for peace
column26: through diplomacy
column27: or in a careless way in a belligerent attitude which has exemplified his attitudes in the past.

column2: Barbara
column3: I believe that there is a fundamental difference - and I think it has been evident in most of the answers that Mr. Carter has given tonight - that he seeks the solution to anything as another opportunity for a Federal Government program. I happen to believe that the Federal Government has usurped powers of autonomy and authority that belong back at the state and local level. It has imposed on the individual freedoms of the people
column4: and there are more of these things that could be solved by the people themselves
column5: if they were given a chance
column6: or by the levels of government that were closer to them. Now
column7: as to why I should be and he shouldn't be
column8: when he was a candidate in 1976
column9: President Carter invented a thing he called the misery index. He added the rate of unemployment and the rate of inflation
column10: and it came
column11: at that time
column12: to 12.5% under President Ford. He said that no man with that size misery index has a right to seek reelection to the Presidency. Today
column13: by his own decision
column14: the misery index is in excess of 20%
column15: and I think this must suggest something. But
column16: when I had quoted a Democratic President
column17: as the President says
column18: I was a Democrat. I said many foolish things back in those days. But the President that I quoted had made a promise
column19: a Democratic promise
column20: and I quoted him because it was never kept. And today
column21: you would find that that promise is at the very heart of what Republicanism represents in this country today. That's why I believe there are going to be millions of Democrats that are going to vote with us this time around
column22: because they too want that promise kept. It was a promise for less government and less taxes and more freedom for the people.

column1: I mentioned the radical departure of Governor Reagan from the principles or ideals of historical perspective of his own party. I don't think that can be better illustrated than in the case of guaranteeing women equal rights under the Constitution of our nation. For 40 years
column2: the Republican Party platforms called for guaranteeing women equal rights with a constitutional amendment. Six predecessors of mine who served in the Oval Office called for this guarantee of women's rights. Governor Reagan and his new Republican Party have departed from this commitment - a very severe blow to the opportunity for women to finally correct discrimination under which they have suffered. When a man and a women do the same amount of work
column3: a man gets paid $1.00
column4: a women only gets paid 59 cents. And the equal rights amendment only says that equality of rights shall not be abridged for omen b the Federal Government or by he state governments. That is all it says a simple guarantee of equality of opportunity which typifies the Democratic arty
column5: and which is a very important commitment of mine
column6: as contrasted with Governor Reagan's radical departure from the long-standing policy of his own party.

column2: once again
column3: I happen to be against the amendment
column4: because I think the amendment will take this problem out of the hands of elected legislators and put it in the hands f unelected judges. I am for equal rights
column5: and while you have been in office for four ears and not one single state - and most f them have a majority of Democratic legislators - has added to the ratification r voted to ratify the equal rights amendment. While I was Governor
column6: more than eight years ago
column7: I found 14 separate instances where women were discriminated against in the body of California law
column8: and I had passed and signed into law 14 statutes that eliminated those discriminations
column9: including the economic ones that you have just mentioned - equal pay and so forth. I believe that if in all these years that we have spent trying to get the amendment
column10: that we had spent as much time correcting these laws
column11: as we did in California - and we were the first to do it. If I were President
column12: I would also now take a look at the hundreds of Federal regulations which discriminate against women and which go right on while everyone is looking for an amendment. I would have someone ride herd on those regulations
column13: and we would start eliminating those discriminations in the Federal Government against women.

column2: I'm a Southerner
column3: and I share the basic beliefs of my region that an excessive government intrusion into the private affairs of American citizens and also into the private affairs of the free enterprise system. One of the commitments that I made was to deregulate the major industries of this country. We've been remarkably successful
column4: with the help of a Democratic Congress. We have deregulated the air industry
column5: the rail industry
column6: the trucking industry
column7: financial institutions. We're now working on the communications industry. In addition to that
column8: I believe that this element of discrimination is something that the South has seen so vividly as a blight on our region of the country which has now been corrected - not only racial discrimination but discrimination against people that have to work for a living - because we have been trying to pick ourselves up by our bootstraps
column9: since the long depression years
column10: and lead a full and useful life in the affairs of this country. We have made remarkable success. It is part of my consciousness and of my commitment to continue this progress. So
column11: my heritage as a Southerner
column12: my experience in the Oval Office
column13: convinces me that what I have just described is a proper course for the future.

column2: my last word is again to say this: We were talking about this very simple amendment and women's rights. And I make it plain again: I am for women's rights. But I would like to call the attention of the people to the fact that that so-called simple amendment would be used by mischievous men to destroy discriminations that properly belong
column3: by law
column4: to women respecting the physical differences between the two sexes
column5: labor laws that protect them against things that would be physically harmful to them. Those would all
column6: could all be challenged by men. And the same would be true with regard to combat service in the military and so forth. I thought that was the subject we were supposed to be on. But
column7: if we're talking about how much we think about the working people and so forth
column8: I'm the only fellow who ever ran for this job who was six times President of his own union and still has a lifetime membership in that union.

column2: '28Oct'
column3: 8)	" Barbara
column4: reluctant as I am to say anything critical about Governor Reagan
column5: I will try to answer your question. First of all
column6: there is the historical perspective that I just described. This is a contest between a Democrat in the mainstream of my party
column7: as exemplified by the actions that I have taken in the Oval Office the last four years
column8: as contrasted with Governor Reagan
column9: who in most cases does typify his party
column10: but in some cases
column11: there is a radical departure by him from the heritage of Eisenhower and others. The most important crucial difference in this election campaign
column12: in my judgment
column13: is the approach to the control of nuclear weaponry and the inclination to control or not to control the spread of atomic weapons to other nations who don't presently have it
column14: particularly terrorist nations. The inclination that Governor Reagan has exemplified in many troubled times since he has been running for President - I think since 1968 - to inject American military forces in places like North Korea
column15: to put a blockade around Cuba this year
column16: or in some instances
column17: to project American forces into a fishing dispute against the small nation of Ecuador on the west coast of South America. This is typical of his long-standing inclination
column18: on the use of American power
column19: not to resolve disputes diplomatically and peacefully
column20: but to show that the exercise of military power is best proven by the actual use of it. Obviously
column21: no President wants war
column22: and I certainly do not believe that Governor Reagan
column23: if he were President
column24: would want war
column25: but a President in the Oval Office has to make a judgment on almost a daily basis about how to exercise the enormous power of our country for peace
column26: through diplomacy
column27: or in a careless way in a belligerent attitude which has exemplified his attitudes in the past.

column2: Barbara
column3: I believe that there is a fundamental difference - and I think it has been evident in most of the answers that Mr. Carter has given tonight - that he seeks the solution to anything as another opportunity for a Federal Government program. I happen to believe that the Federal Government has usurped powers of autonomy and authority that belong back at the state and local level. It has imposed on the individual freedoms of the people
column4: and there are more of these things that could be solved by the people themselves
column5: if they were given a chance
column6: or by the levels of government that were closer to them. Now
column7: as to why I should be and he shouldn't be
column8: when he was a candidate in 1976
column9: President Carter invented a thing he called the misery index. He added the rate of unemployment and the rate of inflation
column10: and it came
column11: at that time
column12: to 12.5% under President Ford. He said that no man with that size misery index has a right to seek reelection to the Presidency. Today
column13: by his own decision
column14: the misery index is in excess of 20%
column15: and I think this must suggest something. But
column16: when I had quoted a Democratic President
column17: as the President says
column18: I was a Democrat. I said many foolish things back in those days. But the President that I quoted had made a promise
column19: a Democratic promise
column20: and I quoted him because it was never kept. And today
column21: you would find that that promise is at the very heart of what Republicanism represents in this country today. That's why I believe there are going to be millions of Democrats that are going to vote with us this time around
column22: because they too want that promise kept. It was a promise for less government and less taxes and more freedom for the people.

column1: I mentioned the radical departure of Governor Reagan from the principles or ideals of historical perspective of his own party. I don't think that can be better illustrated than in the case of guaranteeing women equal rights under the Constitution of our nation. For 40 years
column2: the Republican Party platforms called for guaranteeing women equal rights with a constitutional amendment. Six predecessors of mine who served in the Oval Office called for this guarantee of women's rights. Governor Reagan and his new Republican Party have departed from this commitment - a very severe blow to the opportunity for women to finally correct discrimination under which they have suffered. When a man and a women do the same amount of work
column3: a man gets paid $1.00
column4: a women only gets paid 59 cents. And the equal rights amendment only says that equality of rights shall not be abridged for omen b the Federal Government or by he state governments. That is all it says a simple guarantee of equality of opportunity which typifies the Democratic arty
column5: and which is a very important commitment of mine
column6: as contrasted with Governor Reagan's radical departure from the long-standing policy of his own party.

column2: once again
column3: I happen to be against the amendment
column4: because I think the amendment will take this problem out of the hands of elected legislators and put it in the hands f unelected judges. I am for equal rights
column5: and while you have been in office for four ears and not one single state - and most f them have a majority of Democratic legislators - has added to the ratification r voted to ratify the equal rights amendment. While I was Governor
column6: more than eight years ago
column7: I found 14 separate instances where women were discriminated against in the body of California law
column8: and I had passed and signed into law 14 statutes that eliminated those discriminations
column9: including the economic ones that you have just mentioned - equal pay and so forth. I believe that if in all these years that we have spent trying to get the amendment
column10: that we had spent as much time correcting these laws
column11: as we did in California - and we were the first to do it. If I were President
column12: I would also now take a look at the hundreds of Federal regulations which discriminate against women and which go right on while everyone is looking for an amendment. I would have someone ride herd on those regulations
column13: and we would start eliminating those discriminations in the Federal Government against women.

column2: I'm a Southerner
column3: and I share the basic beliefs of my region that an excessive government intrusion into the private affairs of American citizens and also into the private affairs of the free enterprise system. One of the commitments that I made was to deregulate the major industries of this country. We've been remarkably successful
column4: with the help of a Democratic Congress. We have deregulated the air industry
column5: the rail industry
column6: the trucking industry
column7: financial institutions. We're now working on the communications industry. In addition to that
column8: I believe that this element of discrimination is something that the South has seen so vividly as a blight on our region of the country which has now been corrected - not only racial discrimination but discrimination against people that have to work for a living - because we have been trying to pick ourselves up by our bootstraps
column9: since the long depression years
column10: and lead a full and useful life in the affairs of this country. We have made remarkable success. It is part of my consciousness and of my commitment to continue this progress. So
column11: my heritage as a Southerner
column12: my experience in the Oval Office
column13: convinces me that what I have just described is a proper course for the future.

column2: my last word is again to say this: We were talking about this very simple amendment and women's rights. And I make it plain again: I am for women's rights. But I would like to call the attention of the people to the fact that that so-called simple amendment would be used by mischievous men to destroy discriminations that properly belong
column3: by law
column4: to women respecting the physical differences between the two sexes
column5: labor laws that protect them against things that would be physically harmful to them. Those would all
column6: could all be challenged by men. And the same would be true with regard to combat service in the military and so forth. I thought that was the subject we were supposed to be on. But
column7: if we're talking about how much we think about the working people and so forth
column8: I'm the only fellow who ever ran for this job who was six times President of his own union and still has a lifetime membership in that union.

We have made remarkable success. column8: when he was a candidate in 1976
column9: President Carter invented a thing he called the misery index. He added the rate of unemployment and the rate of inflation
column10: and it came
column11: at that time
column12: to 12.5% under President Ford. He said that no man with that size misery index has a right to seek reelection to the Presidency. Today
column13: by his own decision
column14: the misery index is in excess of 20%
column15: and I think this must suggest something. But
column16: when I had quoted a Democratic President
column17: as the President says
column18: I was a Democrat. I said many foolish things back in those days. But the President that I quoted had made a promise
column19: a Democratic promise
column20: and I quoted him because it was never kept. And today
column21: you would find that that promise is at the very heart of what Republicanism represents in this country today. That's why I believe there are going to be millions of Democrats that are going to vote with us this time around
column22: because they too want that promise kept. It was a promise for less government and less taxes and more freedom for the people.

column1: I mentioned the radical departure of Governor Reagan from the principles or ideals of historical perspective of his own party. I don't think that can be better illustrated than in the case of guaranteeing women equal rights under the Constitution of our nation. For 40 years
column2: the Republican Party platforms called for guaranteeing women equal rights with a constitutional amendment. Six predecessors of mine who served in the Oval Office called for this guarantee of women's rights. Governor Reagan and his new Republican Party have departed from this commitment - a very severe blow to the opportunity for women to finally correct discrimination under which they have suffered. When a man and a women do the same amount of work
column3: a man gets paid $1.00
column4: a women only gets paid 59 cents. And the equal rights amendment only says that equality of rights shall not be abridged for omen b the Federal Government or by he state governments. That is all it says a simple guarantee of equality of opportunity which typifies the Democratic arty
column5: and which is a very important commitment of mine
column6: as contrasted with Governor Reagan's radical departure from the long-standing policy of his own party.

column2: once again
column3: I happen to be against the amendment
column4: because I think the amendment will take this problem out of the hands of elected legislators and put it in the hands f unelected judges. I am for equal rights
column5: and while you have been in office for four ears and not one single state - and most f them have a majority of Democratic legislators - has added to the ratification r voted to ratify the equal rights amendment. While I was Governor
column6: more than eight years ago
column7: I found 14 separate instances where women were discriminated against in the body of California law
column8: and I had passed and signed into law 14 statutes that eliminated those discriminations
column9: including the economic ones that you have just mentioned - equal pay and so forth. I believe that if in all these years that we have spent trying to get the amendment
column10: that we had spent as much time correcting these laws
column11: as we did in California - and we were the first to do it. If I were President
column12: I would also now take a look at the hundreds of Federal regulations which discriminate against women and which go right on while everyone is looking for an amendment. I would have someone ride herd on those regulations
column13: and we would start eliminating those discriminations in the Federal Government against women.

column2: I'm a Southerner
column3: and I share the basic beliefs of my region that an excessive government intrusion into the private affairs of American citizens and also into the private affairs of the free enterprise system. One of the commitments that I made was to deregulate the major industries of this country. We've been remarkably successful
column4: with the help of a Democratic Congress. We have deregulated the air industry
column5: the rail industry
column6: the trucking industry
column7: financial institutions. We're now working on the communications industry. In addition to that
column8: I believe that this element of discrimination is something that the South has seen so vividly as a blight on our region of the country which has now been corrected - not only racial discrimination but discrimination against people that have to work for a living - because we have been trying to pick ourselves up by our bootstraps
column9: since the long depression years
column10: and lead a full and useful life in the affairs of this country. We have made remarkable success. It is part of my consciousness and of my commitment to continue this progress. So
column11: my heritage as a Southerner
column12: my experience in the Oval Office
column13: convinces me that what I have just described is a proper course for the future.

column2: my last word is again to say this: We were talking about this very simple amendment and women's rights. And I make it plain again: I am for women's rights. But I would like to call the attention of the people to the fact that that so-called simple amendment would be used by mischievous men to destroy discriminations that properly belong
column3: by law
column4: to women respecting the physical differences between the two sexes
column5: labor laws that protect them against things that would be physically harmful to them. Those would all
column6: could all be challenged by men. And the same would be true with regard to combat service in the military and so forth. I thought that was the subject we were supposed to be on. But
column7: if we're talking about how much we think about the working people and so forth
column8: I'm the only fellow who ever ran for this job who was six times President of his own union and still has a lifetime membership in that union.

column2: I'm a Southerner
column3: and I share the basic beliefs of my region that an excessive government intrusion into the private affairs of American citizens and also into the private affairs of the free enterprise system. One of the commitments that I made was to deregulate the major industries of this country. We've been remarkably successful
column4: with the help of a Democratic Congress. We have deregulated the air industry

column7: financial institutions. We're now working on the communications industry. In addition to that

column9: since the long depression years
column10: and lead a full and useful life in the affairs of this country. We have made remarkable success. It is part of my consciousness and of my commitment to continue this progress. So
column11: my heritage as a Southerner

column13: convinces me that what I have just described is a proper course for the future.

than eight years ago, I found 14 separate instances where women were discriminated against in the body of California law, and I had passed and signed into law 14 statutes that eliminated those discriminations, including the economic ones that you have just mentioned  equal pay and so forth', 'I believe that if in all these years that we have spent trying to get the amendment, that we had column2: '28Oct'
column3: 8)	" Barbara
column4: reluctant as I am to say anything critical about Governor Reagan
column5: I will try to answer your question. First of all
column6: there is the historical perspective that I just described. This is a contest between a Democrat in the mainstream of my party
column7: as exemplified by the actions that I have taken in the Oval Office the last four years
column8: as contrasted with Governor Reagan
column9: who in most cases does typify his party
column10: but in some cases
column11: there is a radical departure by him from the heritage of Eisenhower and others. The most important crucial difference in this election campaign
column12: in my judgment
column13: is the approach to the control of nuclear weaponry and the inclination to control or not to control the spread of atomic weapons to other nations who don't presently have it
column14: particularly terrorist nations. The inclination that Governor Reagan has exemplified in many troubled times since he has been running for President - I think since 1968 - to inject American military forces in places like North Korea
column15: to put a blockade around Cuba this year
column16: or in some instances
column17: to project American forces into a fishing dispute against the small nation of Ecuador on the west coast of South America. This is typical of his long-standing inclination
column18: on the use of American power
column19: not to resolve disputes diplomatically and peacefully
column20: but to show that the exercise of military power is best proven by the actual use of it. Obviously
column21: no President wants war
column22: and I certainly do not believe that Governor Reagan
column23: if he were President
column24: would want war
column25: but a President in the Oval Office has to make a judgment on almost a daily basis about how to exercise the enormous power of our country for peace
column26: through diplomacy
column27: or in a careless way in a belligerent attitude which has exemplified his attitudes in the past.

column2: Barbara
column3: I believe that there is a fundamental difference - and I think it has been evident in most of the answers that Mr. Carter has given tonight - that he seeks the solution to anything as another opportunity for a Federal Government program. I happen to believe that the Federal Government has usurped powers of autonomy and authority that belong back at the state and local level. It has imposed on the individual freedoms of the people
column4: and there are more of these things that could be solved by the people themselves
column5: if they were given a chance
column6: or by the levels of government that were closer to them. Now
column7: as to why I should be and he shouldn't be
column8: when he was a candidate in 1976
column9: President Carter invented a thing he called the misery index. He added the rate of unemployment and the rate of inflation
column10: and it came
column11: at that time
column12: to 12.5% under President Ford. He said that no man with that size misery index has a right to seek reelection to the Presidency. Today
column13: by his own decision
column14: the misery index is in excess of 20%
column15: and I think this must suggest something. But
column16: when I had quoted a Democratic President
column17: as the President says
column18: I was a Democrat. I said many foolish things back in those days. But the President that I quoted had made a promise
column19: a Democratic promise
column20: and I quoted him because it was never kept. And today
column21: you would find that that promise is at the very heart of what Republicanism represents in this country today. That's why I believe there are going to be millions of Democrats that are going to vote with us this time around
column22: because they too want that promise kept. It was a promise for less government and less taxes and more freedom for the people.

column1: I mentioned the radical departure of Governor Reagan from the principles or ideals of historical perspective of his own party. I don't think that can be better illustrated than in the case of guaranteeing women equal rights under the Constitution of our nation. For 40 years
column2: the Republican Party platforms called for guaranteeing women equal rights with a constitutional amendment. Six predecessors of mine who served in the Oval Office called for this guarantee of women's rights. Governor Reagan and his new Republican Party have departed from this commitment - a very severe blow to the opportunity for women to finally correct discrimination under which they have suffered. When a man and a women do the same amount of work
column3: a man gets paid $1.00
column4: a women only gets paid 59 cents. And the equal rights amendment only says that equality of rights shall not be abridged for omen b the Federal Government or by he state governments. That is all it says a simple guarantee of equality of opportunity which typifies the Democratic arty
column5: and which is a very important commitment of mine
column6: as contrasted with Governor Reagan's radical departure from the long-standing policy of his own party.

column2: once again
column3: I happen to be against the amendment
column4: because I think the amendment will take this problem out of the hands of elected legislators and put it in the hands f unelected judges. I am for equal rights
column5: and while you have been in office for four ears and not one single state - and most f them have a majority of Democratic legislators - has added to the ratification r voted to ratify the equal rights amendment. While I was Governor
column6: more than eight years ago
column7: I found 14 separate instances where women were discriminated against in the body of California law
column8: and I had passed and signed into law 14 statutes that eliminated those discriminations
column9: including the economic ones that you have just mentioned - equal pay and so forth. I believe that if in all these years that we have spent trying to get the amendment
column10: that we had spent as much time correcting these laws
column11: as we did in California - and we were the first to do it. If I were President
column12: I would also now take a look at the hundreds of Federal regulations which discriminate against women and which go right on while everyone is looking for an amendment. I would have someone ride herd on those regulations
column13: and we would start eliminating those discriminations in the Federal Government against women.

column2: I'm a Southerner
column3: and I share the basic beliefs of my region that an excessive government intrusion into the private affairs of American citizens and also into the private affairs of the free enterprise system. One of the commitments that I made was to deregulate the major industries of this country. We've been remarkably successful
column4: with the help of a Democratic Congress. We have deregulated the air industry
column5: the rail industry
column6: the trucking industry
column7: financial institutions. We're now working on the communications industry. In addition to that
column8: I believe that this element of discrimination is something that the South has seen so vividly as a blight on our region of the country which has now been corrected - not only racial discrimination but discrimination against people that have to work for a living - because we have been trying to pick ourselves up by our bootstraps
column9: since the long depression years
column10: and lead a full and useful life in the affairs of this country. We have made remarkable success. It is part of my consciousness and of my commitment to continue this progress. So
column11: my heritage as a Southerner
column12: my experience in the Oval Office
column13: convinces me that what I have just described is a proper course for the future.

column2: my last word is again to say this: We were talking about this very simple amendment and women's rights. And I make it plain again: I am for women's rights. But I would like to call the attention of the people to the fact that that so-called simple amendment would be used by mischievous men to destroy discriminations that properly belong
column3: by law
column4: to women respecting the physical differences between the two sexes
column5: labor laws that protect them against things that would be physically harmful to them. Those would all
column6: could all be challenged by men. And the same would be true with regard to combat service in the military and so forth. I thought that was the subject we were supposed to be on. But
column7: if we're talking about how much we think about the working people and so forth
column8: I'm the only fellow who ever ran for this job who was six times President of his own union and still has a lifetime membership in that union.
